[#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] Accordingly, the scrutineers report’s discussion of procedural issues and invalid-vote causation can help the PRA evaluate whether voting results may have been affected by how the process operated in practice, in the same way the PRA considers other turnout-related factors such as whether members were fully and clearly informed and whether they had adequate facilities and opportunity to vote. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97]

question: If there are lots of invalid votes in a merger vote, what extra details does the PRA want in the scrutineers report, and how does that help the PRA decide whether the Merger Resolutions votes really reflect members’ views (not just whether turnout was low)?
gold_answer: Where invalid votes appear significant, the PRA would find it helpful for the scrutineers report to do two extra things: describe any procedural difficulties encountered and explain why votes were treated as invalid. [#SRC:2c0f6dd7f7e57586] That added detail supports the PRA’s assessment of the criterion focused on whether the votes on the Merger Resolutions do not represent the views of the members, which is mainly concerned with the risk of a merger being approved by a small and unrepresentative vote. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] The PRA does not treat a very low turnout, by itself, as automatically meaning the criterion applies; instead it evaluates turnout in context and considers other factors that may have affected participation. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] In that context, the scrutineers report is one of the inputs the PRA considers on the conduct and counting of votes, including the number of and reasons for invalid proxy votes. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] By adding analysis of procedural problems and invalid-vote reasons, the report can help the PRA understand whether the voting process itself may have influenced the results and therefore whether the recorded votes are likely to reflect members’ views. [#SRC:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]

question: For a firm that has created a record in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015, what retention period and PRA access obligation applies to each version of that record when the firm is complying with 5.8, and how is the start of the retention period determined?
gold_answer: Where a firm has a record that was created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015, the firm is required to apply the 5.8 compliance framework to that record. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] In practical terms, this means the firm must retain each version of the relevant record for ten years, with the ten-year period running from the date that particular version is replaced by a more current version. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] The same retention approach also applies to each version of the management responsibilities map, and the firm must be able to supply both the map and the record to the PRA if the PRA asks for them. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] Accordingly, for the specific population of records captured by the “as at 31 December 2015” condition, the firm should treat version control and supersession dates as the trigger for calculating the ten-year retention window, and ensure the retained versions are retrievable for PRA requests. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]

question: If a firm has a record that was made under SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and existed on 31 December 2015, how long does it need to keep each version, when does the clock start, and what does it need to do if the PRA asks for it?
gold_answer: If the firm has a record that was created in line with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and is within the scope described as at 31 December 2015, the firm must follow the 5.8 requirement for that record. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] Under that approach, each version of the record must be kept for ten years, and the ten-year period starts on the date that version is replaced by a newer, more up-to-date record. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] The same rule is stated to apply to each version of the management responsibilities map, so the firm should keep version histories for both items using the supersession date as the retention trigger. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] In addition to keeping the versions for the full period, the firm must be able to provide the retained versions to the PRA if the PRA requests them. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] This ties the specific “record created … as at 31 December 2015” population to a concrete retention-and-production outcome: ten-year retention per version, measured from supersession, plus readiness to deliver to the PRA on request. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]

question: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets that is expected to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing to ensure sufficient liquid funds, what features must the stress testing include in terms of (i) how the credit union may meet the expectation through its own analysis and RAS, (ii) the types of scenarios and outflows to be assessed (including any retail-book elements), and (iii) the PRA’s anticipated engagement on methods and assumptions?
gold_answer: A credit union with more than £50 million in total assets is expected to perform periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually to support holding sufficient liquid funds, and that testing should be structured so it meaningfully evaluates stressed outflows. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The expectation can be met through the credit union’s own analysis, provided it is anchored in a clearly articulated RAS that specifies the duration and type of stress (or stresses) the credit union intends to withstand. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] The stress tests are expected to cover a range of severe but plausible scenarios, and this includes combined scenarios rather than only single-factor events. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] In applying the annual (or more frequent) testing cycle, the credit union should ensure the analysis explicitly considers the impact of stressed outflows, consistent with the purpose of demonstrating sufficient liquid funds. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The PRA also expects to engage with the credit union on the chosen methodology and the assumptions used, including how the credit union assesses likely run-off for different elements of the retail book, which should therefore be addressed within the stress-testing design and documentation. [#SRC:505c78059496b268]

question: When a firm is required to establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures for risk management, internal control, internal audit and (where relevant) outsourcing, what specific content must those policies include, and how must that content align with the firm’s overall business strategy?
gold_answer: A firm must not only have written policies and adequate procedures covering at least risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing, but must also ensure those policies are drafted with specific operational content and strategic alignment. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] In practice, the written policies for these areas must clearly describe (i) who is responsible for what, (ii) the objectives being pursued, (iii) the processes to be followed, and (iv) the reporting procedures that will be used. [#SRC:d73247674d265abb] The firm must also ensure that these responsibilities, objectives, processes and reporting procedures are consistent with the firm’s overall business strategy, meaning the policy design and governance arrangements should not conflict with how the firm intends to run its business. [#SRC:d73247674d265abb] This linkage matters because the obligation to “establish, implement and maintain” written policies and procedures is not satisfied by generic documentation; the policies must be sufficiently detailed to set out the required elements and must be coherent with the firm’s strategic direction. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] [#SRC:d73247674d265abb]

question: If a firm has to keep written policies and procedures for risk management, internal control, internal audit and (if relevant) outsourcing, what should those policies spell out, and what do they need to match at a high level?
gold_answer: The firm’s written policies and procedures must cover at least risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing, and they must be established, implemented and maintained on an ongoing basis. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] Beyond simply existing in writing, the firm must ensure the policies clearly set out the key building blocks for how each area will operate: the relevant responsibilities, the objectives, the processes to be applied, and the reporting procedures to be used. [#SRC:d73247674d265abb] The firm must also ensure that all of those elements—responsibilities, objectives, processes and reporting procedures—are consistent with the firm’s overall business strategy, so the way the firm manages and reports on these control functions aligns with how it intends to conduct its business. [#SRC:d73247674d265abb] Put differently, the requirement to maintain written policies and adequate procedures is tied to the expectation that the documents are specific enough to allocate accountability and describe how work and reporting will be done, and that the resulting framework fits the firm’s strategic approach rather than operating in isolation. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] [#SRC:d73247674d265abb]

question: If you are working out the add-on for a hedging set (the add-on mentioned in Articles 280a to 280f), what does ‘ε’ stand for, and where do you get the value of εj for hedging set j?
gold_answer: In the add-on calculation for a hedging set referred to in Articles 280a to 280f, ε is the “hedging set supervisory factor coefficient” used for that calculation. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] When you need the coefficient for a particular hedging set j, it is written as εj, meaning the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient of hedging set j. [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c] The value is not defined directly in the add-on provision itself; instead, εj is determined by following Article 280. [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c] So, to complete the add-on calculation under Articles 280a to 280f, you use ε as the relevant coefficient concept, and you obtain the hedging-set-specific coefficient εj by applying the determination approach specified in Article 280. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c]

question: Where an institution is a client and seeks to calculate own funds requirements for its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member under Article 306 (subject to the stated conditions), how does the rule for a multi-level client structure constrain a lower-level client’s ability to apply the relevant treatment, and what must be true across the structure for the calculation approach to be available?
gold_answer: An institution that is a client may use the Article 306 calculation approach for own funds requirements on its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member only if the specified conditions for that approach are satisfied, and this is not displaced by the separate rule on multi-level client structures. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] Where the institution is a lower-level client accessing CCP services through a higher-level client in a multi-level client structure, the institution’s ability to apply the relevant treatment is constrained by an “all levels” condition: it may apply the treatment referenced for lower-level clients only if the conditions attached to the applicable paragraph are met at every level of the multi-level structure. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] In practice, this means the institution cannot treat compliance at its own level as sufficient; it must ensure that the conditions required by the relevant treatment paragraph are satisfied not just for itself, but also for each intermediary level through which it accesses the CCP. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] Accordingly, when the institution is relying on the client-based calculation approach for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member, it must also check whether it sits within a multi-level client structure and, if so, confirm that the paragraph-specific conditions are met throughout the chain, because the treatment is only available on that basis. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b]

question: If an institution is a client and wants to use Article 306 to calculate own funds requirements for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member, what extra check applies when it is a lower-level client in a multi-level client structure?
gold_answer: The institution can use the Article 306 method for calculating own funds requirements for its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member only if the conditions for that method are met. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] If the institution is not just a client but specifically a lower-level client that accesses the services of a CCP through a higher-level client in a multi-level client structure, it must also satisfy an additional structural requirement before it can apply the relevant treatment: the conditions in the applicable paragraph must be met at every level of the multi-level structure. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] This means the institution needs to look beyond its own arrangements and confirm that each level in the chain meets the paragraph’s conditions, because the treatment is only available when the conditions hold throughout the structure. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] Put together, the institution’s use of the client-based Article 306 calculation approach depends on meeting the stated conditions for that approach and, where the client relationship is multi-level, ensuring the paragraph-specific conditions are satisfied at each level of the client chain. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b]

question: When a firm uses transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) to restructure an asset for inclusion in the MA portfolio, how should it assess whether the unrestructured asset remains an appropriate match over time (consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and changing operating conditions), and what limits apply where the unrestructured asset would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements (including the PPP)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat intra-group restructuring (including via loans or derivatives) as acceptable for MA portfolio purposes only to the extent the resulting restructured asset can meet the MA eligibility conditions, and it should base that assessment on the nature of the underlying asset being restructured. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] In doing so, the firm is expected to evaluate the suitability of the restructuring arrangements by first considering whether the asset in its unrestructured form is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that aligns with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and accounts for potential changes in operating conditions. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] The PRA also draws a clear boundary: it would not expect firms to use arrangements of the kind described in paragraph 2.55 (or arrangements that have the same substantive effect) to bring into the MA portfolio assets that, in unrestructured form, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including PPP requirements. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] Additionally, where an asset’s inherent characteristics make it infeasible to restructure into an MA-eligible form, the firm should be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to support ongoing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions over time. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] This time-horizon focus links directly to the PRA’s expectation to test continuing appropriateness of the unrestructured asset against the restructuring duration and changing conditions. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]

question: If a firm wants to use an insurance-group transaction (like a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset so it can go into the MA portfolio, what does the PRA expect the firm to check about (1) whether the unrestructured asset stays suitable over the life of the restructuring as conditions change, and (2) whether the unrestructured asset already fails Solvency II requirements (including the PPP)?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation is that a firm should only rely on an insurance-group transaction (including a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset for MA portfolio inclusion if the restructured asset can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions, and the firm should consider the underlying asset when judging whether those conditions will be met. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] As part of assessing the suitability of the restructuring arrangements, the firm is expected to start by asking whether the asset in its unrestructured form is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and anticipates that operating conditions may change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] The PRA also indicates a restriction: it would not expect firms to use arrangements described in paragraph 2.55 (or arrangements that effectively do the same thing) for assets that, before restructuring, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including PPP requirements. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] Finally, because some assets may be inherently infeasible to restructure into MA-eligible assets, the firm should be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to ensure the MA eligibility conditions continue to be satisfied over time. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]

question: If the Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary is supposed to go out with the meeting notice, what happens if someone who should get it doesn’t receive it? When is that treated as an “accidental omission,” and when is it not (for example, if there’s a computer mailing-list problem or management decides not to send to a group)?
gold_answer: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the meeting notice to every person who is entitled to receive it, so a missing delivery is assessed in the same overall context as notice delivery. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] For meeting validity, the scrutineers’ report may properly take into account that an accidental failure to give notice, or a person’s non-receipt of the notice, does not automatically invalidate what the meeting does. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] But the society should not treat every mistake as “accidental.” [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] The “accidental omission” idea does not include systemic failures to send notices, such as not sending to new shareholders or borrowers, or leaving out a whole group/class because a computer programme fault caused them to be missing from the mailing list. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] Also, authority indicates that “accidental” and “non-receipt” do not cover all “error,” including a management mistake where management wrongly decides not to send notices to particular persons or groups. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] So, isolated accidental lapses may be treated differently from systemic or management-driven exclusions when evaluating notice compliance and reporting. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0]

question: Where a firm enters into a material non-outsourcing third party arrangement (i.e., not within Notifications 2.3(1)(e)), what is the firm expected to do to remain compliant with Fundamental Rule 7’s requirement to disclose to the PRA matters of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice, and how should the firm align its internal notification approach and timing?
gold_answer: A firm should treat a material non-outsourcing third party arrangement as potentially notifiable to the PRA where it amounts to information the PRA would reasonably expect to be told, and it should notify the PRA in a way that reflects the same approach and timing used for material outsourcing notifications. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] This expectation follows from Fundamental Rule 7, which requires the firm to engage with regulators openly and cooperatively and to disclose to the PRA, in an appropriate manner, anything about the firm that the PRA would reasonably expect notice of. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] In practice, this means: - Even though Notifications 2.3(1)(e) is framed as applying only to material outsourcing, the firm should still bring material non-outsourcing third party arrangements to the PRA’s attention when they fall within the “reasonably expect notice” concept. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] - The firm should follow a similar manner and timeframe to that described for notifying the PRA about material outsourcing arrangements (as referenced in the source text). [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] - The firm may choose to implement a single internal framework that covers notifications for both material outsourcing and material non-outsourcing third party arrangements to the PRA. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] Overall, the compliance objective is to ensure disclosures are made to the PRA in an appropriate, open, and cooperative way when the PRA would reasonably expect notice, regardless of whether the arrangement is outsourcing. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97]

question: If a firm has a big third-party deal that is not outsourcing, does it still need to tell the PRA, and can it use the same internal process and timing it uses for outsourcing notifications?
gold_answer: Yes—if the non-outsourcing third-party arrangement is material and would be something the PRA would reasonably expect to be told about, the firm is expected to bring it to the PRA’s attention even though the specific Notifications 2.3(1)(e) trigger is described as applying to material outsourcing. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] This is because Fundamental Rule 7 requires the firm to deal with regulators openly and cooperatively and to disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm that the PRA would reasonably expect notice of. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] Operationally, the source text indicates the PRA expects firms to notify it about these material non-outsourcing arrangements in a similar manner and timeframe to the approach referenced for outsourcing notifications. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] To make this easier and more consistent, a firm may decide to build one internal notification framework that covers both material outsourcing and material non-outsourcing third party arrangements for PRA notification. [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] So, while the arrangement is not “outsourcing,” the key test is whether it is the kind of information the PRA would reasonably expect notice of, and the firm should handle the notification in a way that aligns with the outsourcing-style process and timing described in the source. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97]

question: When assessing recovery capacity, how should a firm treat the combined impact of recovery options under different types of stress, and how does this differ from scenario testing in terms of option selection and dependencies?
gold_answer: A firm should treat recovery capacity as an assessment of the total financial benefits it could credibly realise across a range of stresses, and it should do so by evaluating the combined impact of all options that could credibly be realised together under different types of stress. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b] This combined-impact assessment must explicitly take account of dependencies between options, because the analysis is about what can be realised together rather than viewing each option in isolation. [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e] In practice, this means the firm’s recovery capacity work should (i) identify the set of options that could credibly be realised together, (ii) assess their total benefits under different stress types, and (iii) reflect how dependencies between options affect the combined outcome. [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e] The firm should also distinguish this recovery capacity assessment from scenario testing: scenario testing is framed around specific scenario conditions and focuses on which options would likely be selected in response to those particular conditions, rather than calculating the total benefits of all options that could be realised together. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b] Accordingly, recovery capacity is a total-capacity measure under a range of stresses with option interdependencies considered, while scenario testing is a selection exercise tied to individual scenario conditions. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b]

question: How should a PRA-regulated firm determine whether an outsourcing or other third-party arrangement that is not within scope of OCIR can still trigger the PRA notification expectation for ‘material outsourcing,’ and what timing does the PRA expect for that notification?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm should treat the notification obligation as potentially applying even where an arrangement is not within scope of OCIR, because non-OCIR outsourcing and even non-outsourcing third-party arrangements may still be “material outsourcing” if they could affect the PRA’s objectives outside an OCIR context. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] The TARGET text indicates that examples of arrangements that may be material on this basis include those involving personal or sensitive data or those carrying high reputational risk, which are concrete indicators the firm can use when assessing materiality beyond OCIR scope. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] Once the firm concludes the arrangement is material outsourcing (whether due to OCIR applicability or due to potential impact on the PRA’s objectives), the SOURCE text requires notification to the PRA when entering into, or significantly changing, that material outsourcing arrangement. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] The PRA expects the firm to submit the notification before entering into the outsourcing arrangement, and also before an arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become material. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] The PRA will consider how timely the firm’s notifications are when assessing compliance with Fundamental Rule 7. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]

question: When maintaining a model inventory that must document a model’s operating boundaries, how should the firm describe those boundaries and the risk implication of using the model outside them, given the definition of operating boundaries as a sample data range (including multivariate variance-covariance relationships)?
gold_answer: The model inventory should record each model’s operating boundaries as part of documenting the model’s purpose and use, and it should do so in a way that reflects that operating boundaries are the conditions under which model performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] In describing those operating boundaries, the firm should characterize them as the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of the statistical model, including (where relevant) the empirical variance-covariance relationships in multivariate settings. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] The inventory entry should also link the boundary description to the model’s intended versus actual use by indicating whether the model is being applied within that sample data range or is being extrapolated beyond it. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] Where the model is used beyond its operating boundaries—such as in shock or stressed economic conditions reflected by macroeconomic indices—the inventory should flag that this extrapolation should be assumed to involve increased model risk. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] This boundary-and-risk articulation should sit alongside the other required inventory elements (assumptions/limitations, validation findings, and governance details) so that boundary exceedances can be understood in context and tracked for remediation where applicable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]

question: In the model inventory, what should you write about a model’s “operating boundaries,” and what should you note if the model is used outside those boundaries (for example, during stressed economic conditions)?
gold_answer: In the model inventory, you should include the model’s operating boundaries as part of the information describing the model’s purpose and use, including the boundaries under which model performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] You should describe those operating boundaries using the definition that they are the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of a statistical model, and in multivariate cases this includes the empirical variance-covariance relationships reflected in that sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] You should also connect this boundary description to how the model is actually being used by noting whether the use stays within the sample data range or goes beyond it (i.e., extrapolation). [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] If the model is used outside its operating boundaries—such as when macroeconomic indices reflect shock or stressed economic conditions—you should record that this kind of extrapolation should be assumed to increase model risk. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] Keeping this information in the inventory supports tracking related validation indicators and any outstanding remediation actions when boundary exceedances are relevant to model functioning. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]

question: If a firm has to add its dependants’ asset exposure onto its own exposure amount, how do you work out each dependant’s exposure figure before adding it?
gold_answer: Where the firm’s exposure amount to certain assets is being adjusted to reflect dependants, the firm must increase its exposure amount (as worked out using 18 to 22) by an amount that represents any exposure its dependants have to assets of the same description. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] The dependant part is not calculated using a separate method: for the specific purpose of this dependant add-on, the exposure of each dependant must be calculated by applying the same provisions (18 to 22) to that dependant as if the dependant were a firm to which those provisions apply, even if the dependant is not actually such a firm. [#SRC:d0975ff530ed6e30] Practically, that means you (i) determine the firm’s exposure to the relevant assets under 18 to 22, (ii) separately run 18 to 22 for each dependant on a “treat it like a firm” basis to get each dependant’s exposure to assets of that description, and (iii) increase the firm’s exposure amount by the dependant exposure amount, but only to the extent there is any such dependant exposure. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] [#SRC:d0975ff530ed6e30]

question: When applying the expectations in this SS, which insurers are within scope, and how does the PRA’s supervisory framework model (as described in the March 2016 ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’) support that scoping decision, particularly in light of the PRA’s view on cost impacts for smaller insurers and the risk-profile expectations for larger firms?
gold_answer: The expectations in this SS are intended to apply only to significant firms, specifically Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms, rather than to all insurers. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] This scoping is justified by the PRA’s view that smaller insurers—often operating in a single locality or niche—would face disproportionate costs if they sought to meet the SS expectations, whereas larger firms with complex risk profiles should aim to meet or exceed those expectations when complying with regulatory requirements. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] The March 2016 document ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ provides the supervisory-framework linkage for this limitation by explaining that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model. [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3] Read together, the SS sets the practical application boundary (significant firms only) and the March 2016 supervisory approach supplies the definitional basis for treating Category 1 and 2 firms as “significant” for that boundary. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]

question: If a firm wants to know whether it needs to follow the expectations in this SS, what firm categories does the PRA limit them to, and where is it explained that those categories are treated as “significant” in the PRA’s supervision model?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the expectations in this SS as applying only if it is a significant firm, meaning a Category 1 or Category 2 PRA-regulated firm. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] The PRA limits the SS expectations this way because it considers the cost of trying to meet them would be disproportionate for smaller insurers (many of which operate in one locality or a niche market), while larger firms with complex risk profiles are expected to seek to meet or exceed the PRA’s expectations when complying with regulatory requirements. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] To confirm what “significant” means in this context, the March 2016 document titled ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ explains that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model. [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3] Using both texts together, the SS tells you the expectations are scoped to Category 1 and 2 only, and the March 2016 supervisory approach provides the basis for treating those categories as significant for that scoping decision. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]

question: For an assigned asset that does not use published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks, and that has a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1–5, what must a firm with a matching adjustment permission do to ensure the basic fundamental spread reflects differences in credit quality by rating notch, and what related adjustment requirement is referenced alongside this notch-based treatment?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must ensure that, for an assigned asset with a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5, the fundamental spread is adjusted from the credit quality step attributed to the asset so that it reflects the corresponding rating notch, and it must do so following the approach specified in 6.3 and 6.4. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This notch-based adjustment is part of the broader requirement to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic fundamental spread (where possible and appropriate) for assigned assets that do not use published fundamental spread tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] In the same context, the framework also points to a related requirement under Matching Adjustment 6.1 that the probability of default is adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, aligning the PD treatment with the basic fundamental spread’s notch sensitivity. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] Accordingly, when the asset falls within credit quality steps 1–5 and is not in the category using published government/central bank tables, the firm’s compliance outcome is to implement a rating-notch-reflective adjustment to the fundamental spread while also recognizing that the PD is expected to be notch-adjusted under 6.1 on the same “where possible and appropriate” basis. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1]

question: If an assigned asset is not using the published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks, and it has a credit rating (or internal credit assessment) that maps to credit quality steps 1–5, what does a firm with a matching adjustment permission need to do so the basic FS reflects the rating notch, and what other notch-related adjustment is mentioned?
gold_answer: For an assigned asset with a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5, a firm with a matching adjustment permission must adjust the fundamental spread that comes from the asset’s credit quality step so it reflects the corresponding rating notch, applying the method set out in 6.3 and 6.4. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This requirement sits within a broader expectation that firms reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic fundamental spread (where possible and appropriate) for all assigned assets that do not use published fundamental spread tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] Alongside adjusting the basic fundamental spread, the text also highlights that Matching Adjustment 6.1 requires the probability of default to be adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, so the notch concept is applied consistently beyond just the fundamental spread. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] In practice, when both conditions apply (no use of the published government/central bank tables, and a mapping to steps 1–5), the firm should implement the notch-reflective fundamental spread adjustment under 6.3 and 6.4 and recognize the parallel notch-based PD adjustment requirement under 6.1. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1]

question: How should a critical third party evidence to the regulators its ability to comply with this Part when its obligations include regular assessment of the effectiveness of its incident management playbook, including an exercise with a representative sample of firms within 12 months of Treasury designation and at least biennially thereafter?
gold_answer: A critical third party should be prepared to show the regulators, using concrete outputs from its incident management playbook governance, that it can meet the Part’s requirements, including the specific cadence and scope for testing the playbook. [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] In practice, the demonstration should cover both (i) that the playbook’s effectiveness is assessed on a regular basis and (ii) that an appropriate playbook exercise is actually undertaken with a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] The demonstration should also make clear that the first such exercise occurs within 12 months after the critical third party is designated by the Treasury, and that the exercise is repeated at least every two years thereafter. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] Because the requirement is framed as an ability to demonstrate compliance to the regulators, the critical third party should retain and be able to present evidence that these assessments and exercises occurred and were aligned to the required timing and sampling approach. [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] This linkage between the regulators-facing demonstration and the playbook assessment/exercise obligations is central to showing compliance with the Part. [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d]

question: What does a critical third party need to be able to show regulators, and how do the playbook checks and exercises (including the 12-month and biennial timing) help prove that?
gold_answer: A critical third party must be able to demonstrate to the regulators that it can comply with this Part, and one way to do that is to point to how it meets the incident management playbook obligations described in the Part. [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] Specifically, it has to assess the effectiveness of its incident management playbook on a regular basis, and that regular assessment includes running an appropriate playbook exercise with a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] The timing of that exercise is also part of what should be demonstrated: the first exercise must be completed within 12 months of the critical third party being designated by the Treasury, and then the exercise must occur at least every two years after that. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] To make the demonstration meaningful to regulators, the critical third party should be able to present evidence that these assessments and exercises were carried out in line with the required scope (representative sample) and schedule (12 months, then biennially). [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d]

question: For the purposes of calculating the TPs, when a firm with a matching adjustment permission has an assigned asset mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), how should it address variation in credit quality by rating notch in the adjustment to the fundamental spread, and what additional consideration applies to that adjustment?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must adjust the fundamental spread that is derived from the credit quality step attributed to an assigned asset so that the adjustment reflects the corresponding rating notch, where the asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive). [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This notch-reflective adjustment is part of the approach used for calculating the TPs, and the firm must also consider the materiality of the impact of the adjustment to the fundamental spread when allowing for variation in credit quality by rating notch for those TP calculations. [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8] In practice, this means the firm should not treat the credit quality step alone as sufficient for the fundamental spread outcome when a corresponding rating notch exists; instead, it must modify the fundamental spread derived from that step to align with the notch. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] At the same time, because the framework explicitly highlights the materiality of the impact of the adjustment to the fundamental spread for notch-based variation, the firm should evaluate how significant the notch-driven change is in the context of the TP calculation. [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8]

question: If an assigned asset is in credit quality steps 1–5 and the firm has a matching adjustment permission, what does the firm need to do to the fundamental spread to account for the rating notch, and what should it think about when doing this for TP calculations?
gold_answer: When an assigned asset has a credit rating or an internal credit assessment of a comparable standard that maps to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), a firm with a matching adjustment permission must change the fundamental spread it gets from that credit quality step so the result reflects the corresponding rating notch. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This is not just a mechanical step: for the purposes of calculating the TPs, the firm must also take into account how material (i.e., how significant) the impact is of adjusting the fundamental spread to allow for variation in credit quality by rating notch. [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8] Put together, the requirement is to (1) start from the fundamental spread derived from the credit quality step attributed to the asset, (2) adjust it to reflect the rating notch, and (3) consider the materiality of the impact of that notch-based adjustment in the TP calculation context. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8]

question: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, how should a firm reconcile the general prohibition on splitting contract obligations with the ability to include a component of a with-profits annuity contract in an MA portfolio, and what evidence and policy statements does the PRA expect in that case?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the default position as not dividing the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, and only depart from that approach where the part being separated qualifies as an eligible element. [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379] In the specific case of a with-profits annuity contract, a component may be included in an MA portfolio only if it is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, can be organised and managed separately in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise satisfies the MA eligibility conditions—i.e., the firm should frame any “splitting” as the isolation of an eligible element rather than a general partitioning of obligations. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7] To support that treatment, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the liabilities included in the MA portfolio are limited to contractually guaranteed elements and do not rely on future premiums or future investment performance. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7] The PRA also expects the firm to articulate a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses will be added within the MA portfolio or handled elsewhere, so that any future changes do not undermine the basis on which the eligible element was identified. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]

question: When calculating the percentage required for the amount determined under 7.8 relative to the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), how must a firm treat sums recoverable under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period, and at what stage does that deduction affect the denominator used for the percentage expression?
gold_answer: A firm must present the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), meaning the 7.7 amount is the reference base (denominator) for the percentage expression. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] In establishing that 7.7 reference base, the firm must first reduce the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2) by deducting the total sum that is recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts that were ceded during the relevant period. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Accordingly, the deduction for reinsurance recoverables is applied to the 7.7 amount before the firm uses that 7.7 figure to express the 7.8 amount as a percentage. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] This sequencing matters because the rule on expressing 7.8 as a percentage explicitly ties the percentage to the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), while the reinsurance rule specifies an adjustment that must be made “from” that 7.7 amount based on recoverables under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]

question: If a firm has worked out an amount under 7.8 and needs to show it as a percentage of the amount under 7.7 (1) or (2), does it have to subtract reinsurance recoveries from the 7.7 amount first, and which reinsurance contracts count?
gold_answer: Yes. The firm’s output must show the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), so the 7.7 amount is the figure the percentage is based on. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] Before using that 7.7 figure for the percentage calculation, the firm must deduct, from the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Only reinsurance contracts that were ceded during the relevant period are included in the deduction described, because the deduction is defined by reference to contracts ceded during that period. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Putting the two requirements together, the firm first adjusts the 7.7 (1) or (2) amount by removing the specified reinsurance recoverables, and then expresses the 7.8 amount as a percentage of that (deducted) 7.7 amount. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] This approach follows directly from the instruction to deduct recoverables “from” the 7.7 amount and the separate instruction to use the 7.7 amount as the base for the percentage expression of 7.8. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23]

question: For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, how should the firm integrate the guidance on fire drills and playbooks into its UK recovery planning, including when a fire drill must be performed relative to recovery plan submissions and what to do if the PRA requests more detailed UK playbook work?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK should treat fire drills and playbooks as connected elements of its UK recovery planning: it should consider the relevant guidance on fire drills and playbooks, and be prepared to do additional UK playbook work if the PRA asks for it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] In parallel, the firm must plan fire drill exercises around its recovery plan submission cycle, because the PRA expects at least one ‘live’ simulation exercise on the recovery plan before each submission, while also ensuring there is at least one such exercise every three years. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] If the PRA explicitly requests more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of the firm’s UK recovery planning, the firm should contact its supervisor to discuss whether that request applies to it and how to proceed. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] The firm should also recognize that the submission frequency for the recovery plan is set by the PRA on a firm-by-firm basis (with larger firms often on an annual cycle), which in turn drives how often the pre-submission fire drill expectation will arise. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]

question: If a UK subsidiary is part of a group based outside the UK, what does it need to do about fire drill exercises and UK playbooks when getting ready to send its recovery plan to the PRA?
gold_answer: The UK subsidiary should link its UK recovery planning work on playbooks with the PRA’s expectations for fire drill exercises on the recovery plan. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Specifically, it should run a fire drill exercise that is a ‘live’ simulation where the firm acts out key parts of its response to a designed scenario, because this is used to test how effective the recovery plan is in a live setting. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] The PRA expects at least one such fire drill to be completed before each time the recovery plan is submitted to the PRA, and there must be at least one fire drill every three years even if submissions are less frequent. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] Alongside that fire-drill planning, the subsidiary should consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced for UK subsidiaries of non-UK groups, and if the PRA explicitly asks for more detailed UK playbook work as part of UK recovery planning, the firm should contact its supervisor to discuss whether the request applies. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Because the PRA sets recovery plan submission frequency firm-by-firm (often annually for larger firms), the firm should align its fire drill timing to that PRA-determined cycle. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]

question: When an Institution changes how it calculates the exposure value of derivative positions by moving between a single exposure value for transactions within a contractual netting agreement and separate exposure values per transaction, what notification to competent authorities is required, and what calculation approach applies depending on whether the Article 274(1) conditions are met?
gold_answer: An Institution that starts using, stops using, or switches between calculation methods for the exposure value of its derivative positions must notify the competent authorities of the relevant method it uses or ceases to use, as applicable, where that method is one of those set out in Section 4 or 5. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] In applying the calculation itself, the Institution may compute a single exposure value covering all transactions within a contractual netting agreement only when all conditions in Article 274(1) are satisfied; if those conditions are not met, it must instead compute an exposure value separately for each transaction. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Where separate calculation is required, each transaction is treated as its own netting set, which means the exposure value is determined on a transaction-by-transaction basis rather than aggregated under the contractual netting agreement. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Accordingly, the compliance action is twofold: (i) determine whether the Article 274(1) conditions permit a single exposure value across the contractual netting agreement or require separate exposure values per transaction, and (ii) notify the competent authorities of the Section 4 or 5 method being used or discontinued in connection with that exposure-value calculation for derivative positions. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]

question: For a CRR firm preparing its self-assessment of its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances, how must it incorporate (i) additional risks arising from elsewhere in its group and (ii) the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services, including the disruption scenario and the scope of entities to be assessed?
gold_answer: A CRR firm’s self-assessment must go beyond its own operations by identifying extra risks to staying within impact tolerances that come from elsewhere in its group, and it must also be informed by the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services. [#SRC:525172756112897c] In practice, the CRR consolidation entity’s work that informs the self-assessment includes an assessment of whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group that provides an important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service when facing a severe but plausible disruption to its operations. [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] The linkage is that the self-assessment’s group-risk identification is complemented by (and should take account of) the consolidation-group-wide testing of resilience against a defined disruption scenario for each important group business service. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] Accordingly, the CRR firm should ensure its self-assessment reflects both (i) group-derived risks affecting its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances and (ii) the consolidation entity’s conclusions about whether each relevant consolidation group member can remain within the applicable impact tolerance under severe-but-plausible disruption conditions. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]

question: For a firm within scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations, how should the bank reflect its chosen booking model in contingency planning for winding down trading books, and how does the PRA’s proportional application of those expectations interact with the potential resolution impediments described for a global booking model under an MPE strategy?
gold_answer: A bank that is within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations should ensure that its contingency plans for winding down trading books in a solvent and orderly manner explicitly incorporate the implications of the booking model it has adopted, because the PRA expects the booking model to be fully taken into account in those plans. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] This planning focus sits alongside the PRA’s statement that it will apply the booking-arrangements expectations proportionately to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity the firm undertakes, meaning the depth and intensity of the bank’s implementation should be calibrated to that activity profile. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236] In practice, where the bank uses a global booking model, it should treat the model’s group inter-connectivity as a factor that can complicate post-resolution restructuring and, under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy, can become an impediment to resolution that the bank should address through its planning. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] The proportionality principle does not remove the need to address those model-driven risks; rather, it frames how extensively the bank evidences and operationalises the integration of booking-model considerations into wind-down and resolution-related contingency plans, in line with its investment banking or sales and trading footprint. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]

question: When the PRA assesses a firm’s ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP (and, for major UK firms, alongside the Bank’s annual stress test (AST)), what specific aspects of the firm’s projected stress results and scenario impacts does the assessment focus on?
gold_answer: In the SREP, the PRA’s assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing is directed at judging whether the firm’s stress-testing outputs and supporting rationale are credible, and for major UK firms this SREP work is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). [#SRC:7a56cad9ade1c41e] Within that assessment, the PRA evaluates the credibility and reasonableness of the firm’s projected stress results and the assumptions used to build those projections. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] The assessment then concentrates on how the stress scenario adversely affects the firm’s capital position, specifically where it reduces capital resources and increases capital requirements. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] It also examines the nature and severity of the scenario that underpins the stress results, as part of determining whether the projected outcomes are reasonable. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] Finally, the assessment considers the reasonableness of any mitigating actions the firm proposes to mitigate the impact of the stress, linking the projected capital impacts to the firm’s planned responses. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]

question: If the PRA is reviewing a firm’s ICAAP stress testing in the SREP (and major UK firms also face the Bank’s annual stress test (AST)), what does the review look at in the firm’s stress results and plans to deal with the stress?
gold_answer: The PRA’s review of a firm’s ICAAP stress testing is performed as part of the SREP, and for major UK firms this SREP assessment is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). [#SRC:7a56cad9ade1c41e] In carrying out that assessment, the PRA looks at whether the firm’s projected stress results are credible and reasonable, and whether the assumptions used to build the stress projections are themselves credible and reasonable. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] The review focuses on the parts of the stress scenario that harm the firm’s capital position, meaning the areas where the scenario reduces capital resources and increases capital requirements. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] It also considers the nature and severity of the scenario that the stress results are based on, as part of understanding why the projections look the way they do. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] In addition, the PRA assesses whether the mitigating actions the firm proposes to mitigate the impact of the stress are reasonable, tying the firm’s response plans to the projected capital effects identified in the stress results. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]

question: How should a firm structure responsibility for compliance reporting so that the written reports provided to senior management on the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts are produced with the required frequency and content, and who must be appointed to be responsible for that reporting?
gold_answer: A firm should allocate clear ownership of compliance reporting to a designated compliance officer and use that role to support the firm’s obligation to deliver written compliance-related reports to senior management at the required cadence and with the required content. The compliance officer must be appointed by the management body, and that individual must be responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required in relation to the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] In parallel, the firm must ensure that its senior management receive written reports on a frequent basis and, in any event, at least annually, covering the matters addressed by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] Those written reports must also state whether appropriate remedial measures have been taken where deficiencies have been identified, so the reporting process overseen by the compliance officer should be capable of capturing deficiencies and tracking remediation status for inclusion in the reports to senior management. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] This linkage—management-body appointment and responsibility for compliance reporting, combined with the senior-management written reporting frequency and remediation-status content—provides a coherent structure for meeting both requirements. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3]

question: Who has to appoint the compliance officer, and how does that role connect to the rule that senior management must get written reports (at least once a year) that say whether fixes were made when problems were found?
gold_answer: The management body must appoint a compliance officer, and that compliance officer must be responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required for the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] Separately, the firm must make sure its senior management receive written reports frequently and at least annually on the matters covered by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] To connect these requirements in practice, the compliance officer’s responsibility for compliance reporting should be used to drive the preparation and delivery of those written reports to senior management on the required schedule. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] The written reports to senior management must also indicate whether appropriate remedial measures were taken when deficiencies occurred, so the reporting overseen by the compliance officer needs to include both identification of deficiencies and an update on whether remediation has been completed. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] In short, appointment by the management body establishes who owns compliance reporting, and the senior-management reporting rule sets the minimum frequency and the requirement to report on remediation status. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3]

question: In solvent exit planning, what must a firm do regarding deposits and timing/resources, and how does this interact with the position that a solvent exit may not involve liquidation—particularly where the firm is a building society that will cease to meet the principal purpose test and may need dissolution steps under the Building Societies Act 1986?
gold_answer: A firm’s solvent exit planning should be structured to ensure it can stop its PRA-regulated deposit-taking in an orderly way while remaining solvent, and it should treat the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits as a core deliverable of that process. [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] In practice, the firm should build in sufficient time and resources so it can meet liabilities as they fall due while it transfers and/or repays all deposits, and it should plan for the solvent exit to conclude with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission or the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (i.e., removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] At the same time, the firm should not assume that completing a solvent exit necessarily means liquidation, because whether liquidation occurs depends on the circumstances. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654] Where the firm is a building society, it should explicitly link its deposit transfer/repayment plan to the consequence that doing so will cause it to cease meeting the principal purpose test, and it should therefore also take into account any steps necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]

question: If a firm is planning a solvent exit, what does it need to do about paying back or transferring deposits and making sure it has enough time and resources, and what extra thing should it consider if it is a building society (given that a solvent exit might not end in liquidation)?
gold_answer: In a solvent exit, the firm is expected to stop its PRA-regulated activities while staying solvent, and it should plan to transfer and/or repay all deposits as part of that exit. [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] The planning should include enough time and resources to allow the firm to meet its liabilities when they fall due while it carries out the deposit transfers and/or repayments, and the firm should anticipate that the solvent exit ends when deposit-taking is removed from its Part 4A permission or when its Part 4A permission is cancelled (removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] Separately, the firm should recognize that a solvent exit does not automatically mean the firm will be liquidated, because that outcome depends on the circumstances. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654] If the firm is a building society, it should connect its deposit transfer/repayment plan to the fact that completing that step will mean it no longer meets the principal purpose test, and it should also consider what steps are needed for dissolution under the Building Societies Act 1986. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]

question: For a firm that is a party to a transfer event and is making the updates described under 6.1(1) and (2), how should it ensure adherence to Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 (including any waiver/modification position), while also meeting the constraint on the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed after those updates?
gold_answer: A firm that is a party to a transfer event and is carrying out the updates under 6.1(1) and (2) must manage those updates so they do not increase the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by the firms involved in the transfer event. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] At the same time, the firm must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is followed unless the firm has been granted a waiver or modification under 3.3 of the SoP titled ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] In practice, the PRA indicates it expects compliance with 6.2 can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’, which provides a mechanism the firm can use when implementing the 6.1(1) and (2) updates while keeping the aggregate TMTP from increasing across the parties to the transfer event. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] The firm should therefore (i) confirm whether it is operating under the default requirement to adhere to 6.2 or under an applicable waiver/modification, and (ii) apply an adjustment to ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ in a way that supports adherence to 6.2 while ensuring the 6.1(1) and (2) updates do not cause any increase in the aggregate TMTP claimed by the transfer-event parties. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]

question: If firms involved in a transfer event are doing the 6.1(1) and (2) updates, what do they need to do so the total TMTP claimed doesn’t go up, and how can they do that while still following Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 (unless they have a waiver/modification)?
gold_answer: When firms that are parties to a transfer event make the updates under 6.1(1) and (2), those updates must be handled so they do not lead to any increase in the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by the firms involved. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] Separately, firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is complied with, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification under 3.3 of the SoP ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] The PRA’s stated expectation is that adherence to 6.2 can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’, which gives firms a concrete way to implement the 6.1(1) and (2) updates while controlling the overall TMTP outcome across the transfer-event parties. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] In operational terms, the firms should (i) check whether they are relying on the default 6.2 requirement or an approved waiver/modification, and (ii) use an adjustment to ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ as the means to keep the aggregate TMTP from increasing while still meeting the 6.2 adherence expectation. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]

question: When a firm is preparing the information it reports annually (including the assessments referred to in 3.2), how should it determine what must be submitted to the PRA, and what additional analysis is required if setting the matching adjustment or volatility adjustment to zero would cause non-compliance with the SCR?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that its annual reporting package to the PRA includes the specific assessments referred to in 3.2, because those assessments are required to be submitted as part of the information reported annually. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] In determining the overall scope of what it submits, the firm must provide the PRA with information that is necessary for the purposes of the PRA’s supervision of the firm, so the annual submission should be framed to meet that supervisory-necessity standard in addition to including the mandated assessments. [#TGT:bf73213345d9be15] If a stress in which the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment is reduced to zero would lead to non-compliance with the SCR, the firm must also include an analysis of the measures it could apply in that scenario. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] That analysis must address how the firm could re-establish eligible own funds covering the SCR or, alternatively, how it could reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR, so that the PRA receives the information needed to supervise the firm’s resilience under that condition. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389][#TGT:bf73213345d9be15]

question: For the yearly information a firm sends to the PRA, what has to be included, and what extra write-up is needed if dropping the matching adjustment or volatility adjustment to zero would make the firm fail the SCR?
gold_answer: In its annual submission, a firm must include the assessments referred to in 3.2, because those assessments are required to be provided as part of the information reported annually. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] Beyond those named items, the firm must submit to the PRA the information that is necessary for the purposes of the PRA’s supervision of the firm, which sets the overall test for what else needs to be included in the yearly package. [#TGT:bf73213345d9be15] If the firm identifies that reducing the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR, the firm must add an analysis describing what measures it could apply in that situation. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] That analysis must cover either steps to re-establish the level of eligible own funds covering the SCR or steps to reduce the firm’s risk profile so that compliance with the SCR is restored, giving the PRA the supervisory information it needs about how the firm would respond to that specific stress. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389][#TGT:bf73213345d9be15]

question: When meeting the expectations in this Chapter on planning for a solvent exit, how should a firm use scenarios, and which specific recovery-planning sources are identified as relevant for developing or adapting those scenarios?
gold_answer: A firm should approach the Chapter’s expectations by considering realistic circumstances that could plausibly result in the firm needing to carry out a solvent exit, and it should use scenario work to inform that assessment. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] In doing so, the firm is permitted to draw on and tailor scenarios that were developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, rather than starting from scratch, provided those scenarios are used to help identify circumstances that could trigger the need for a solvent exit. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The recovery-planning materials explicitly identified as relevant to those recovery planning expectations are Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and the ‘(a) Design’ element within ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17. [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a] Accordingly, to align solvent-exit planning with the referenced recovery-planning framework, the firm should ensure its solvent-exit scenario thinking is informed by (and, where appropriate, adapted from) scenario design and scenario testing concepts drawn from those two sources. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]

question: If a firm is trying to meet the Chapter’s expectations and wants to plan for situations where it might need a solvent exit, what kind of scenarios should it think about, and which two named recovery-planning references can it use to build or adapt those scenarios?
gold_answer: To meet the Chapter’s expectations, the firm should think through plausible situations that could realistically lead to the firm needing to execute a solvent exit, using those circumstances as the basis for its planning. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The firm is allowed to use scenario work it already has from recovery planning, and it may adapt those recovery-planning scenarios so they help the firm understand when a solvent exit might become necessary. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The recovery-planning sources specifically pointed to for those recovery planning expectations are (1) Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and (2) the ‘(a) Design’ component under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ in SS9/17. [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a] Practically, that means the firm’s solvent-exit scenario thinking should be built around plausible solvent-exit-triggering circumstances, while being informed by the scenario design and scenario testing material referenced in those two recovery-planning documents. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]

question: When authorities request Part A information in Phase 1, how should a firm explain the purpose of that request in terms of both (i) what Part A covers and (ii) how the requested information is used for resolution planning, including the specific resolution tool and compliance monitoring context?
gold_answer: A firm should describe Part A of Phase 1 as an information request focused on foundational firm characteristics, and it should connect that scope to how authorities use the information for resolution planning and related monitoring. Part A in Phase 1 is framed as seeking information on group structure, significant legal entities, and the firm’s business model, and the stated purpose is to help authorities determine the most suitable resolution strategy for the individual firm. [#SRC:e33015cabfcd50f4] In addition, the firm should explain that the broader set of information requests is used to support development of a resolution plan specifically premised on using the bail-in tool, and that the same information is also requested to monitor the firm’s compliance with MREL and its capacity to meet those requirements going forward. [#TGT:eec6fcc945ab4321] Taken together, the firm’s explanation should link the Part A content (structure, key entities, and business model) to the authorities’ resolution-planning objective, while also situating the request within the bail-in-based resolution plan development and the ongoing MREL compliance and forward-looking capability monitoring described for the information requests. [#SRC:e33015cabfcd50f4] [#TGT:eec6fcc945ab4321]

question: When directors of a society are contemplating a transfer and the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, how should the directors align their internal readiness work (including consultation with external auditors or other advisers) with the society’s obligation to apply to the PRA for confirmation in the manner the PRA may direct, and what PRA decision points are implicated at approval of the Transfer Statement and at confirmation?
gold_answer: The directors should treat systems readiness as a prerequisite that supports the society’s ability to make a proper application for PRA confirmation once the Transfer Resolutions have been passed, and they should plan for PRA scrutiny both at Transfer Statement approval and at the later confirmation stage. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] Before the society applies, the directors must satisfy themselves—working with external auditors or other advisers—that the society’s systems can produce the relevant information, because the PRA will require an assurance on that capability when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] After the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the manner the PRA may direct, and the transfer cannot take effect until the PRA has confirmed it. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] In preparing for confirmation, the directors should also anticipate that one criterion the PRA considers at confirmation is whether a relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled, which makes early assurance work and procedural compliance directly relevant to the confirmation outcome. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]

question: If a society has already passed the Transfer Resolutions, what must it do before the transfer can take effect, and what should the directors do (with external auditors or other advisers) to make sure the society can meet the PRA’s expectations when applying for approval of the Transfer Statement and later seeking confirmation?
gold_answer: Once the Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the way the PRA directs, and the transfer cannot take effect unless and until the PRA confirms it. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] To support that process, the directors should first check—together with the society’s external auditors or other advisers—that the society’s systems can produce the required information, because the PRA will ask for an assurance about that systems capability when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] The directors should also plan for the confirmation stage as a separate PRA decision point, because the PRA considers (among its confirmation criteria) whether any relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not met, which means gaps in process or information readiness can matter at confirmation even if the society is already moving through the application steps. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] Practically, this means sequencing internal assurance work so it is available for the Transfer Statement approval application while also ensuring the overall transfer process is compliant before the PRA considers confirmation and any representations. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]

question: When a firm selects rates of interest for calculating the present value of future payments, how must it apply the cap on the assumed yield for an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business (including the specified reduction and the fact it is applied before any tax adjustment), and how does that cap interact with the requirement that rates be based on a prudent assessment of yields on existing and (as appropriate) future investments?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that the interest rates it uses to discount future payments do not exceed rates derived from a prudent assessment of relevant asset yields, and that any assumed yield used for an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business is additionally constrained by a specific quantitative cap.
