[#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The PRA also explains it chose this wording to avoid confusion with other similar-sounding concepts used elsewhere in financial regulation (for example, “critical function” or “critical service” in an OCIR context). [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] To decide whether a particular outsourcing or third party arrangement is material, you should generally apply the performance-failure test: treat the arrangement as material where a defect or failure in how it is performed could materially impair the firm (as described in the PRA Rulebook definition and, where applicable, the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria). [#TGT:52624254f79512d2] When applying criteria to identify material arrangements, you should use an approach that is substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria for identifying “critical or important outsourcing arrangements,” while recognising the PRA notes there are a few justified exceptions, including ones tied to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] Put together, you map the terminology across, then use the defect/failure material-impairment test with the aligned criteria set (adjusted only for the PRA’s stated exceptions). [#TGT:52624254f79512d2]

question: When a firm is meeting its obligation to identify and document the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information for each important business service, how may it use its end-to-end mapping under Chapter 4 of the Operational Resilience – CRR Firms and Operational Resilience – Solvency II Parts of the PRA Rulebook to ensure intragroup and other dependencies are captured in that documentation?
gold_answer: A firm can satisfy the identification-and-documentation obligation for each important business service by using its existing end-to-end mapping work as the vehicle to record what is needed to deliver the service and how dependencies support delivery. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] Specifically, the firm may leverage its end-to-end mapping of important business services performed under Chapter 4 of the Operational Resilience – CRR Firms and Operational Resilience – Solvency II Parts of the PRA Rulebook to document and map intragroup and other dependencies, and then align that dependency mapping with the required inventory of necessary inputs for each service. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] In practice, this means the firm should ensure that, for each important business service, the documentation covers: (i) the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information required to deliver the service; and (ii) the intragroup and other dependencies identified through the Chapter 4 end-to-end mapping that relate to those necessary elements. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] Using the Chapter 4 mapping in this way helps the firm integrate dependency mapping into the same documentation set used to evidence the required identification of delivery-critical resources for each important business service. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf]

question: If a firm has already done end-to-end mapping of its important business services under Chapter 4, how can it use that work to help write down what it needs (people, processes, technology, facilities and information) to deliver each important business service, including intragroup and other dependencies?
gold_answer: The firm can use its Chapter 4 end-to-end mapping as a practical foundation for the documentation it must produce for each important business service. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] The required documentation must identify the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information needed to deliver each important business service, so the firm should structure its write-up to capture those items for every service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] It may then extend or align that same mapping output to document and map intragroup and other dependencies, so that dependencies are recorded alongside (and connected to) the people, processes, technology, facilities and information that enable delivery. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] Put another way, the firm should treat the end-to-end mapping under Chapter 4 as the mechanism to connect “what is necessary to deliver the service” with “which intragroup and other dependencies support those necessary elements,” ensuring both are documented for each important business service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd]

question: In stress conditions, how should a firm approach the Matching Adjustment (MA) and fundamental spread (FS) used for technical provisions (TPs), and in what circumstances may it increase the fundamental spread beyond the amount calculated under rules 4.10 to 4.16 (including any additions referenced in 4.16 and 4.17)?
gold_answer: For TP purposes, the firm should treat the MA and FS as being calculated under Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook, and the PRA’s expectation is that the MA calculation method itself should not be altered merely because conditions are stressed. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] However, stress conditions require the firm to reassess whether the assumptions used in calculating the MA and FS for the TP calculation remain appropriate, including any additions to the FS (whether additions linked to assets with HP cash flows under Matching Adjustment 4.16 or additions made for other reasons under Matching Adjustment 4.17). [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] In addition, the firm has discretion to increase the fundamental spread beyond the amount calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 when that increase is necessary so that the fundamental spread covers all risks that the firm retains. [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1] Read together, this means the firm should keep the MA calculation method stable while using stress-driven review of assumptions (including FS add-ons) and, where needed, applying an increase to the fundamental spread to ensure comprehensive coverage of retained risks within the 4.10–4.16 framework. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1]

question: If markets are stressed, do firms change the MA calculation method for TPs, and when can they add more to the fundamental spread than the amount worked out under 4.10–4.16 (including the kinds of add-ons mentioned in 4.16 and 4.17)?
gold_answer: When calculating TPs, the MA and FS are determined using the approach set out in Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook, and the PRA view is that the MA calculation method should stay the same even in stress conditions. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Even so, firms should actively consider whether the assumptions feeding into the MA and FS used for the TP calculation are still suitable under stress, including any extra amounts added to the FS (for example, additions connected to assets with HP cash flows under Matching Adjustment 4.16, or additions made for other reasons under Matching Adjustment 4.17). [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Separately, a firm is allowed to increase the fundamental spread above the level calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 if that increase is needed to make sure the fundamental spread covers all risks the firm keeps. [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1] Putting these points together: the method stays stable, but the firm should revisit assumptions and can raise the fundamental spread where necessary so retained risks are fully covered. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1]

question: If a firm is working out the MA (including cash flow matching) and also calculating amounts recoverable from reinsurance contracts and UK ISPVs, what does it need to do to keep the reinsurance risk adjustment consistent, and does it have to map the reinsurance to an FS?
gold_answer: The firm should apply a risk adjustment to reinsurance cash flows for MA purposes using the basis in Technical Provisions 11.1, and it should keep that adjustment consistent by using the same adjustment when calculating the value of the reinsurance recoverable. [#SRC:7ebc4345de167c98] At the same time, the firm must calculate amounts recoverable from reinsurance contracts and UK ISPVs in line with the specified provisions (2 to 10). [#TGT:74361ab0c9c7163d] Putting these together, the firm should not treat the MA calculation as a separate exercise with a different reinsurance adjustment: the MA risk adjustment and the reinsurance recoverable valuation adjustment are intended to be aligned while the recoverable amount itself is calculated under the required recoverables framework. [#SRC:7ebc4345de167c98] [#TGT:74361ab0c9c7163d] On mapping, the PRA states it does not expect firms to map the reinsurance to an FS, even though the firm still needs to perform the recoverables calculation for reinsurance contracts and UK ISPVs under the applicable provisions. [#SRC:7ebc4345de167c98] [#TGT:74361ab0c9c7163d]

question: If a counterparty is under liquidity stress and might “recall sleeper collateral,” what does “sleeper collateral” mean here, and why could that recall be a problem for the insurer?
gold_answer: Here, “sleeper collateral” means collateral value that an insurer is already contractually required to post to a counterparty, but has not posted yet because the counterparty has not called for it. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] A recall of sleeper collateral is flagged as one of the ways stressed counterparties or other market participants can create liquidity pressure that could adversely affect the insurer. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] Putting those two points together, the recall matters because it can turn an unposted, call-dependent obligation into an immediate liquidity need for the insurer, even though nothing had been posted before the call. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] The same stress scenario also includes other potentially harmful actions—like selling similar assets that the insurer may rely on for liquidity (which can move market prices), not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes—so a sleeper-collateral recall should be viewed as part of a broader set of stress-driven behaviors that can worsen the insurer’s liquidity situation. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] In short, the insurer should treat sleeper collateral as a contingent obligation that can be activated by a counterparty’s recall during liquidity stress. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]

question: Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies so that specified requirements must be applied at the level of the group, how should a firm treat its responsibility for compliance if it outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity—particularly in relation to the group-level application of the listed Conditions Governing Business, Fitness and Propriety, Allocation of Responsibilities, and Key Function Holder – Notifications requirements?
gold_answer: A firm should treat outsourcing as not reducing or transferring its compliance responsibility, even where the relevant requirements are being applied at the level of the group because 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] In that situation, the firm must ensure that the specified requirements continue to be met at group level “with any necessary changes,” including the identified Conditions Governing Business modules (such as 1A, 2.2–2.6, 2A.1–2A.6, 3, 3A, 4, 4A, 5, 6, 7, and 11A–11F), the listed Fitness and Propriety provisions, Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (as applied in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] If the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it nevertheless remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other applicable legal and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Accordingly, outsourcing arrangements must be managed so that the firm can still demonstrate compliance with those group-applied requirements, because the accountability for meeting the obligations stays with the firm rather than the outsource provider. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245]

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) means certain rules have to be applied at the group level, what happens to a firm’s responsibility when it outsources a function or insurance/reinsurance activity—does outsourcing change who is accountable for meeting the group-level Conditions Governing Business, Fitness and Propriety, Allocation of Responsibilities, and Key Function Holder – Notifications requirements?
gold_answer: Outsourcing does not change who is accountable: the firm remains responsible for meeting its obligations, even when the relevant requirements are being applied at the level of the group. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the specified requirements must be applied at group level with any necessary adjustments, and this includes a defined set of Conditions Governing Business modules, certain Fitness and Propriety provisions, Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (applied in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] If the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it still remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other applicable provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Practically, this means the firm must structure and oversee outsourcing so that it can continue to comply with those group-level requirements (for example, the relevant Conditions Governing Business and the notification-related requirements), because responsibility for compliance stays with the firm rather than moving to the outsource provider. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]

question: If an outsourcing or third party arrangement uses an ICT service (like cloud), does that automatically make it “material outsourcing,” and what steps should the firm follow to decide—especially given the PRA says “material outsourcing” covers what some rules call “critical or important outsourcing”?
gold_answer: No—using an ICT product or service (such as cloud) does not automatically make an outsourcing arrangement material. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] The firm should still decide materiality by looking at all applicable criteria in Table 5, considering each criterion on its own and also how the criteria work together, for arrangements that are not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] In doing so, the firm should apply the PRA’s terminology: the PRA uses “material outsourcing” for clarity and indicates that, for practical purposes, a “material outsourcing” arrangement includes what retained EU legislation or PRA rules describe as a “critical or important outsourcing” arrangement. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The firm can also take comfort that the criteria it uses to identify “material outsourcing” are described as substantively aligned with the criteria for identifying “critical or important outsourcing arrangements” under the EBA Outsourcing GL, while noting there are some justified exceptions, including ones tied to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The decision should therefore come from applying the Table 5 criteria within this PRA framing, not from ICT presence alone. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]

question: What does it mean for a firm to “prepare for resolution” under Fundamental Rule 8, and how does that connect to the PRA and the Bank as resolution authority talking to the home state supervisor and/or home resolution authority and then asking the firm for more information?
gold_answer: Preparing for resolution under Fundamental Rule 8 means the firm must get itself ready so that, if resolution is needed, it can be handled in an orderly way and with as little disruption as possible to critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] The resolution planning information the firm provides should therefore describe preparations that support that outcome, because the purpose of the preparation is to enable an orderly resolution with minimal disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] The PRA and the Bank as resolution authority play an active role in reviewing and testing whether the firm’s information is sufficient: they will discuss the firm’s resolution preparations with one or both of the home state supervisor and the home resolution authority. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] After those discussions, they will consider whether they need any additional information from the firm. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] So, the firm should be ready not only to provide initial resolution planning information, but also to respond if the PRA and the Bank as resolution authority decide—based on engagement with the relevant home authorities—that more information is required to assess the firm’s readiness for orderly resolution and continuity of critical services. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]

question: If a firm calculates its SCR using an internal model, what does the SCR measure need to match (confidence level and time period), and how will the PRA review the model differently when the firm’s risks are homogeneous versus only mostly homogeneous?
gold_answer: For an internal-model SCR, the model’s calibration needs to support an SCR that matches the required risk measure: the SCR must equal the value-at-risk of the firm’s basic own funds at a 99.5% confidence level over a one-year period. [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf] [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] This linkage matters because the internal model is required to be calibrated to the specified calibration standard, and the SCR definition fixes the confidence level and horizon the calibration must ultimately deliver. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf] The PRA’s review approach then depends on how similar the firm’s risks are to each other. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] If the risks are homogeneous, the PRA can use a quantitative assessment of how each individual risk is calibrated and how dependency structures are calibrated as an efficient way to spot potential problem areas suggesting the model is not calibrated adequately to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] If the risks are largely (but not totally) homogeneous, the PRA will adjust (tailor) its quantitative assessment to reflect the firm’s specific risk profile, while still using that work to judge whether calibration is adequate for producing an SCR consistent with the 99.5% one-year value-at-risk requirement. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf]

question: When allocating responsibilities within a firm’s senior management arrangements, how should the firm treat a person who performs an FCA designated senior management function (noting the “subject to 3.6(1)” qualifier) in light of the prohibition on allocating a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the prohibition as applying specifically to individuals who perform an “FCA other overall responsibility senior management function,” and it must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to such a person. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] Separately, the population of individuals who may be relevant to the firm’s senior management arrangements includes those who perform a PRA senior management function and those who perform an FCA designated senior management function, with the latter category expressly framed as being “subject to 3.6(1).” [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] In practice, this means the firm should first identify whether the individual in question is within the senior management function categories described (PRA senior management function or FCA designated senior management function, as qualified). [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] If the individual also performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the firm is prohibited from allocating any prescribed responsibility to that individual, regardless of their status as a PRA senior management function holder or FCA designated senior management function holder. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] The “subject to 3.6(1)” wording signals that the FCA designated senior management function category is not unconditional, so the firm should apply that qualifier when determining whether the person is treated as performing that function for these purposes. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903]

question: If someone is in scope because they perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA designated senior management function (with the “subject to 3.6(1)” note), can the firm give them a prescribed responsibility if they also perform an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: No. If the person performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the firm is not allowed to allocate a prescribed responsibility to them. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] The set of people you may be looking at for this decision includes those who perform a PRA senior management function and those who perform an FCA designated senior management function, and the FCA designated category is explicitly stated to operate with a “subject to 3.6(1)” qualifier. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] So the firm should (1) confirm the person is being considered in the relevant senior management function population (PRA senior management function or FCA designated senior management function, applying the qualifier), and then (2) check whether they perform an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] If they do perform that FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the prohibition applies and the prescribed responsibility must not be allocated to them, even if they also fall within the PRA or FCA designated senior management function categories. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4]

question: For a TWD firm forecasting the impact of a TWD scenario from the reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, what specific categories of information and analytical capabilities must be in place so that the firm can both project impacts on capital requirements/resources/liquidity and perform the required financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, including portfolio segmentation for alternative packaging of trades for novation?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should ensure it has both (i) the analytical infrastructure to forecast the TWD scenario’s effects on key prudential metrics over time and (ii) the underlying risk and trade data needed to run the required projections and sensitivity work, including portfolio segmentation that supports wind-down execution options. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] Specifically, the firm should have methodologies, models, and frameworks that enable it to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, and to do so by making projections from the reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] To make those forecasts operational and support the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, the firm’s information set should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate those projections and sensitivities. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] The data should also be sufficient to segment the firm’s trading portfolios in multiple ways, including enabling alternative packaging of trades for novation, so that the projections can reflect different wind-down execution approaches. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] Together, these elements link the time-bounded forecasting requirement (from reference date through wind-down) with the concrete data and segmentation capabilities needed to compute and stress the projected impacts. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]

question: If a TWD firm needs to project the TWD scenario’s effects from the reference date through the wind-down period, what does it need to have (tools and data) so it can forecast impacts on capital and liquidity and also run the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, including splitting trading portfolios in different ways like packaging trades for novation?
gold_answer: To meet the projection task across the wind-down timeline, a TWD firm needs both forecasting capability and the supporting dataset that makes those forecasts calculable and testable. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] On capability, the firm should have the methodologies, models, and frameworks required to forecast how the TWD scenario affects capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, and it should apply those projections starting at the reference date of the TWD option and continuing through the wind-down period. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] On inputs, the firm should include all risk and trade data needed to calculate the financial impact projections and the sensitivity analysis referenced for the TWD work. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] That same information should also support segmenting the firm’s trading portfolios in multiple ways, so the firm can reflect different portfolio breakdowns when projecting impacts. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] An explicit example of the required segmentation support is being able to represent alternative packaging of trades for novation, which can change how exposures and impacts are grouped in the projections. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] In combination, the tools define what must be forecast over the wind-down period, while the data and segmentation enable the firm to compute and stress those forecasts. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]

question: Where a CRR firm is a member of a group, how does the Part’s general scope interact with the special treatment of an Article 109 undertaking, and what specific compliance obligation is imposed on an Article 109 undertaking in relation to the types of groups it belongs to?
gold_answer: For a CRR firm that is a member of a group, the Part generally applies, but it does so with an express carve-out that preserves the application of provision 2.3 specifically for an Article 109 undertaking. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] In other words, the scope statement both brings group-member CRR firms within the Part and simultaneously signals that Article 109 undertakings are treated differently by identifying 2.3 as the relevant hook for them. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] Separately and more concretely, an Article 109 undertaking has a defined compliance duty: it must comply with 2.1(2) not only for its own group, but also for any UK consolidation group or non-UK sub-group of which it is a member. [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8] This means that, when the entity is an Article 109 undertaking, the compliance analysis must connect the Part’s scope carve-out for Article 109 undertakings with the specific requirement to apply 2.1(2) across each relevant group context (UK consolidation group, non-UK sub-group, and its group). [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8]

question: If a CRR firm is in a group, does this Part apply, and what extra rule applies when the firm is an Article 109 undertaking—especially about which groups it has to follow 2.1(2) for?
gold_answer: If a CRR firm is a member of a group, this Part applies to it as the default position. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] However, the scope text also makes clear there is a specific exception-style treatment for an Article 109 undertaking, because it states that 2.3 applies to an Article 109 undertaking even within that general scope framework. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] For an Article 109 undertaking, the concrete compliance requirement described is that it must comply with 2.1(2) in relation to multiple group settings: any UK consolidation group of which it is a member, any non-UK sub-group of which it is a member, and also its group. [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8] Putting these together, when the entity is an Article 109 undertaking you should not stop at the general statement that the Part applies to group-member CRR firms; you must also recognize the special reference to 2.3 and ensure 2.1(2) is applied across each of the specified group categories tied to the undertaking’s memberships. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8]

question: In the PRA’s capital framework, how should a firm position the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) relative to the total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and what specific buffer components must be included when determining the combined buffer amount?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) as an additional capital amount held on top of both its total capital requirement (TCR) and its combined buffer, and it should understand that these three elements together form the PRA’s capital framework. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] The PRA buffer is described as serving to absorb losses that could arise under a severe stress scenario, while being set so as to avoid duplicating what is already covered by the combined buffers. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] To determine the combined buffer that sits alongside the PRA buffer and the TCR in that framework, the firm must include the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), and the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] In addition, for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies, the combined buffer also includes the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] Accordingly, the combined buffer amount used in the capital stack must be built from those specified components, and the PRA buffer then sits in addition to that combined buffer and the TCR. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]

question: When you’re working out how much capital a firm should hold in the PRA’s capital stack, what is the PRA buffer meant to do and what exact items make up the combined buffer (including any extra item that applies only to ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies)?
gold_answer: In the PRA’s capital stack, the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an extra amount of capital the firm should maintain on top of its total capital requirement (TCR) and on top of the combined buffer. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] Its purpose is to absorb losses that could occur under a severe stress scenario, and it is designed to avoid overlapping with (ie duplicating) the combined buffers. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] The combined buffer that sits alongside the PRA buffer and the TCR is made up of specific named components: the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), and the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] There is also an additional component that applies only for certain firms: for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies, the combined buffer includes the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] Putting these together, the firm identifies the combined buffer from those components and then adds the PRA buffer above it, alongside meeting the TCR, to reflect the PRA’s overall capital framework. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]

question: If you’re listing steps to reduce the risks, what do you need to say about changing “standardised” and “non-standardised” documentation, and what exactly counts as each type?
gold_answer: When you identify the steps needed to reduce the risks, you must include any changes needed to documentation so that the documentation is better aligned with the preferred resolution strategy, and you must cover both standardised and non-standardised documentation in that work. [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5] To do that correctly, you should apply the specific meanings of the two categories: standardised documentation means ISDA agreements, and non-standardised documentation means bilateral or bespoke agreements. [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad] As a result, your list of risk-reducing measures should consider whether ISDA agreements need changes and whether any bilateral or bespoke agreements need changes, because both fall within the documentation types that must be reviewed for alignment with the preferred resolution strategy. [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5] Using these definitions helps ensure you are not treating “standardised” and “non-standardised” as vague labels, but as concrete agreement types that must be assessed for required changes. [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad]

question: For a firm that is a parent entity of an international group, what does the PRA expect the firm to show in its group recovery plan regarding (i) coverage of entities in other jurisdictions and (ii) the way dependencies and mutual exclusivity between recovery options are identified and explained?
gold_answer: A firm that is a parent entity of an international group should produce a group recovery plan that both (1) evidences coverage of group entities located in other jurisdictions and (2) provides a clear, structured explanation of how recovery options depend on one another, including where options cannot be used together. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] In practice, the plan should demonstrate how different entities in other jurisdictions are addressed within the group recovery plan, rather than leaving their treatment implicit. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] Alongside that jurisdictional coverage, the PRA expects the firm to detail and explain dependencies between recovery options and to clearly flag any recovery options that are mutually exclusive. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] The dependency analysis should be framed to help the firm understand dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, so that the interaction of recovery actions is transparent in a cross-border group context. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] The firm should therefore link its explanation of recovery-option dependencies and mutual exclusivity to the way it has covered different entities across jurisdictions, so the plan shows how those inter-entity dependencies affect which recovery options can be executed and in what combinations. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]

question: If a general insurer in run-off is working on a Part 26 scheme of arrangement, what two PRA materials does it need to use together, and how can you confirm you have the right SS3/14 (name, date, and link info)?
gold_answer: For a general insurer in run-off preparing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, the materials that need to be used together are: (1) the relevant PRA Rulebook provisions, including the Risk Management chapter in the Conditions Governing Business Part (which contains the requirement to perform an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA)), and (2) the PRA supervisory statement SS3/14 on the PRA’s approach to such schemes, because the supervisory statement described is intended to complement SS3/14 and the two are meant to be read together for general insurers in run-off. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] To confirm you have the correct SS3/14, match it to the specific identification details provided: it is PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14 titled “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006,” dated April 2014, and it is associated with the listed Bank of England web address. [#TGT:8d6a107327860924] Using both sources together helps ensure the scheme work is aligned with the PRA’s scheme-focused supervisory approach while also maintaining the insurer’s ongoing Rulebook compliance expectations, including ORSA. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197]

question: When a critical third party appoints a skilled person, what specific written contract terms must the critical third party include to ensure the regulators can enforce certain provisions, including how arbitration (if included) and later variation or rescission are handled?
gold_answer: When a critical third party appoints a skilled person, the critical third party must set the required protections in the contract with that skilled person. [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2] The contract must be in writing and must expressly grant the regulators a right to enforce the provisions that are included in the contract under 12.2, 12.3, and 12.4(2)(b) to (d). [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] It must also expressly restrict the skilled person’s ability, in enforcement proceedings brought by the regulators, to rely on any defence, set-off, or counterclaim that is not relevant to those enforceable provisions. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] If the contract contains an arbitration agreement, it must expressly state that the regulators, when exercising their enforcement right, are not to be treated as a party to or bound by that arbitration agreement. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] Finally, the contract must expressly provide that the provisions included under 12.2, 12.3, and 12.4(2) are irrevocable and cannot be varied or rescinded without the regulators’ consent. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]

question: If a critical third party hires a skilled person, what has to be written into their contract so regulators can enforce the key provisions, and what happens if the contract also has arbitration?
gold_answer: For an appointment of a skilled person by a critical third party, the required safeguards must be built into the contract between the critical third party and the skilled person. [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2] The contract must be in writing and must clearly say that the regulators have a right to enforce the provisions that are included under 12.2, 12.3, and 12.4(2)(b) to (d). [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] It must also state that, if the regulators bring proceedings to enforce those provisions, the skilled person cannot use unrelated defences, set-off, or counterclaims against the regulators in that enforcement action. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] If the contract includes an arbitration agreement, it must make clear that the regulators are not treated as a party to, and are not bound by, that arbitration agreement when they exercise their enforcement right. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] In addition, the contract must say the relevant provisions are irrevocable and cannot be changed or cancelled unless the regulators consent. [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]

question: For a TWD firm projecting exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, how should it determine what qualifies as an “exit cost” for positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the TWD scenario’s actions, arrangements and measures?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should treat “exit costs” as a specific, quantifiable component of the broader set of items it is expected to project from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] In determining what qualifies as an exit cost, the firm should calculate, for each position that is intended to be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures of the TWD scenario, the difference between (i) the expected exit value under that TWD scenario and (ii) the accounting book value of that position. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] This definition links the firm’s projection obligation to a concrete measurement method: the firm’s exit-cost projection should be built by identifying the relevant positions covered by the TWD scenario’s planned actions and then measuring the “gap” between expected exit value and book value for those positions. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] The resulting exit-cost figures should be capable of being projected from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period alongside the firm’s other projected elements (operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs). [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]

question: When a TWD firm is working out its projected exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, what numbers does it compare to calculate the exit cost for positions it plans to novate, terminate, or liquidate under the TWD scenario?
gold_answer: To project exit costs as part of its wind-down planning, a TWD firm should calculate exit costs using the specific comparison set out for the TWD scenario and then ensure those amounts can be projected from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] For any positions that the firm expects to novate, terminate, or liquidate under the actions, arrangements and measures of the TWD scenario, the exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under that TWD scenario and the accounting book value of those positions. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] Practically, this means the firm first identifies which positions fall within the planned TWD actions (novation, termination, or liquidation) and then computes the difference between the scenario-based expected exit value and the book value for each such position. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] Those calculated gaps are the exit-cost amounts the firm should be able to project over time from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, alongside its projections for operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]

question: How should a TWD firm document and operationalise its TWD option so that it can be executed in real-life stress, including how the wind-down period is defined and what must be quantified in the recovery plan, and how this documentation links to the firm’s TWD capabilities used for its recovery plan and BRP?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should both (i) set out the TWD option in its recovery plan in a way that supports straightforward execution under stress and (ii) maintain capabilities that allow it to develop and execute that option across real-life circumstances, using those capabilities to support both the recovery plan and the BRP. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8] The recovery plan should explain the TWD option, and where relevant include the playbook, so the option can be implemented readily in a stress scenario. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] In addition, the recovery plan should quantify wind-down costs and describe impacts on projected capital and liquidity resources over the full wind-down period, measured from execution of the TWD option until trading activities are wound down. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] The wind-down period should be broken into an active wind-down period (from execution until the firm has exited all positions it can exit without undue costs) and a passive wind-down period (the remainder, during which exposures of remaining rump positions are hedged where possible until expiry). [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] To make that plan executable beyond paper design, the firm should have TWD capabilities that enable development and execution of the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities when developing and executing its recovery plan and BRP. [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8]

question: In an RFTS application, how should the court’s timetable set at a Directions hearing be framed in relation to the applicant’s role (as transferor, transferee, or both) in submitting the application, particularly for public notification and handling written submissions from persons claiming adverse effect?
gold_answer: For an RFTS application, the court uses a Directions hearing to establish a timetable that governs what the applicant must do to (i) notify the public about the RFTS application and (ii) receive written submissions from persons who say they would be adversely affected by the scheme. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] In framing and applying that timetable, the relevant “applicant” is the party (or parties) submitting the RFTS application to the court to bring about the transfer—typically the transferor, the transferee, or both acting as applicant(s). [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] Practically, this means the timetable set at the Directions hearing should be read as binding on whichever of those entities is acting as the applicant in the particular case, because that is the actor responsible for progressing the court application. [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] The timetable’s scope specifically covers the steps and sequencing for public notification and for receiving written submissions from potentially adversely affected persons, so the applicant must be prepared to carry out those two functions in accordance with the court’s schedule. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] The process described is triggered by the Directions hearing itself, which is the point at which the court sets out the timetable for these applicant actions. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]

question: Who counts as the “applicant” in an RFTS application, and what does the court set the applicant to do at the Directions hearing about telling the public and collecting written comments from people who say the scheme would harm them?
gold_answer: In an RFTS application, the “applicant” is usually the transferor, the transferee, or both, and it is the party (or parties) that submits the RFTS application to the court to make the transfer happen. [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] At a Directions hearing, the court then sets a timetable that tells the applicant when and how to notify the public about the RFTS application and how to receive written submissions from persons who allege they would be adversely affected by the scheme. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] Because the timetable is set specifically “for the applicant,” it applies to whichever entity is acting as the applicant in that case (transferor, transferee, or both). [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] The two concrete tasks covered by the timetable are (1) public notification of the RFTS application and (2) receiving written submissions from people claiming adverse impact, so the applicant should plan to execute both steps in line with the court’s schedule. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] This linkage matters because the court’s timetable is about managing the applicant’s procedural steps, and the identity of the applicant depends on who is submitting the RFTS application to the court. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]

question: How should a TWD firm design and use sensitivity analysis for key assumptions in its TWD scenario so that senior management can understand the plausible range of impacts on capital and liquidity projections, given the expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should build sensitivity analysis into its TWD capabilities so it can quantify how alternative key assumptions (relative to those used in the TWD scenario) would change projected outcomes, and it should present results in a way that helps senior management understand plausible ranges of impact on capital and liquidity after executing the TWD option. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] This sensitivity analysis should be capable of setting upper and lower bounds for the firm’s key assumptions, so the analysis does not just provide a single-point estimate but instead frames a range of plausible impacts for decision-makers. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The analysis capability should also be able to assess at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are included in the TWD scenario (and may include other factors as well), ensuring the sensitivity work is anchored to the scenario’s core drivers. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] In designing this capability, the firm should do so in a manner consistent with the expectation that its overall TWD capabilities are constructed on the basis of a full wind-down of its trading activities, so that the sensitivity ranges and bounds are evaluated within that full wind-down context rather than a partial trading continuation. [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]

question: When a TWD firm runs sensitivity analysis on its TWD scenario assumptions, what does it need to show senior management about capital and liquidity impacts, and how should that work fit with the idea that TWD capabilities are based on fully winding down trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to run sensitivity analysis that measures how changing key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) would affect outcomes, and it should use that analysis to help senior management see the plausible range of impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] Concretely, the firm’s sensitivity analysis capability should be able to set upper and lower bounds for the firm’s key assumptions, so management can understand not only a central view but also the range of plausible results. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The capability should also include the ability to analyse at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are part of the TWD scenario (and potentially other factors), so the sensitivity work covers the scenario’s core elements. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] This sensitivity analysis should be developed and applied within the broader expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities, meaning the ranges and bounds should be assessed in a full trading wind-down setting. [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]

question: In an application for authorisation as a third-country branch, how should a firm explain the PRA’s decision framework in a way that links the PRA’s statutory-objectives anchor and its assessments of supervisory equivalence and supervisability to the fact that third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA Rulebook provisions relevant to third-country branches?
gold_answer: A firm should describe the PRA’s authorisation decision framework as one that is rooted in the PRA’s statutory objectives and operationalised through specific assessments the PRA undertakes when reviewing third-country branch applications, while also recognising the ongoing rule framework that applies once operating in the UK. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] In particular, the firm should explain that, when the PRA considers an application for authorisation as a third-country branch, its approach includes assessing regulatory and supervisory equivalence (described as ‘supervisory equivalence’) and ‘supervisability’, meaning the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer operating in the UK through a branch. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] The firm should then link that application-stage assessment to the operating-stage compliance context by noting that third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, as set out in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] Framing the explanation this way connects (i) the statutory-objectives anchor, (ii) the PRA’s need to be satisfied on supervisory equivalence and supervisability in its assessment, and (iii) the applicable rule set that governs third-country branch undertakings once they operate in the UK. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]

question: If a firm is applying to be authorised as a third-country branch, what are the key things the PRA looks at (including what “supervisability” means), and how does that connect to the rules the branch must follow once it operates in the UK?
gold_answer: For a third-country branch application, the PRA’s review should be understood as having two connected parts: what the PRA assesses at authorisation, and what rules apply once the branch is operating in the UK. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] On the authorisation side, the PRA’s approach is anchored in its statutory objectives and includes an assessment of regulatory and supervisory equivalence (called ‘supervisory equivalence’) and ‘supervisability’. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] “Supervisability” is specifically the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer that seeks to operate in the UK through a branch, so the firm should address how the PRA would be able to supervise the proposed UK branch model. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] This assessment links to the operating requirements because third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, and those rules are set out in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] Putting these together, the firm should show how its proposed branch can be effectively supervised under the PRA’s statutory-objectives-based approach, and how it will operate within the PRA Rulebook framework that applies to third-country branches in the UK. [#TGT:611c096a35f50289] [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]

question: When applying the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ in the UK context, how does this SS describe the PRA’s approach to those Guidelines, and where does the PRA indicate the EBA Outsourcing GL can be accessed on its website (including the specific link)?
gold_answer: The SS explains that it is intended to clarify how the PRA expects banks to apply the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ (EBA Outsourcing GL) within the context of the PRA’s own requirements and expectations. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] It also indicates that the SS goes beyond mere clarification in some areas by expanding on expectations found in the EBA Outsourcing GL, specifically pointing to Chapter 7 on data security and Chapter 10 on business continuity and exit plans as examples of where additional PRA expectations are set out. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] In terms of access, the PRA states that its website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period, and it identifies that the EBA Outsourcing GL are available there. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] The PRA provides a direct URL for the EBA Outsourcing GL: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] Taken together, this means banks should use the SS to understand the PRA’s expectations (including the SS’s expansions on Chapters 7 and 10) while obtaining the underlying EBA Outsourcing GL from the PRA-hosted link referenced above. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9][#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0]

question: If a bank wants to follow the EBA Outsourcing GL in the UK, what does this SS say it adds (name the chapters it expands on), and where on the PRA website can the bank find the EBA Outsourcing GL (give the exact link)?
gold_answer: For UK use of the EBA Outsourcing GL, the SS says it serves to clarify how the PRA expects banks to approach the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ in light of the PRA’s own requirements and expectations. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] The SS also states that it expands on the expectations in the EBA Outsourcing GL in certain parts, and it gives concrete examples by naming Chapter 7 (data security) and Chapter 10 (business continuity and exit plans). [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] Separately, the PRA explains that its website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period, and it indicates that the EBA Outsourcing GL are available there. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] The PRA provides the specific web address where the EBA Outsourcing GL can be accessed: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] In practice, a bank would use the PRA-hosted EBA Outsourcing GL as the base document and then use the SS to understand the PRA’s clarifications and the additional detail it provides for Chapters 7 and 10. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9][#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0]

question: If a derivative has several material risk drivers, and one of them is a climatic conditions variable, when do you map it only once and when do you map it to more than one risk category?
gold_answer: You map the transaction to the commodity risk category when the climatic conditions variable is the primary risk driver (or the most material risk driver within a given risk category for the relevant transactions). [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] At the same time, because the transaction is a derivative with more than one material risk driver, you must map it to more than one risk category unless all of its material risk drivers fall within a single risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, you map the transaction only once to that category, and you do so using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis for the mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers belong to different risk categories, you map the transaction once to each risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and for each category you use the most material risk driver in that category as the basis. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In that multi-category case, the climatic conditions variable still drives a commodity mapping (because it is a climatic conditions variable and is primary/most material as described), while the other material drivers trigger mapping to their respective categories under the derivative multi-driver rule. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]

question: When solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect and a solvent exit execution plan is therefore needed, how should a firm distinguish between what it must already have prepared as part of BAU and what it must produce and then manage/monitor during execution, given that the Chapter applies specifically when the execution plan is needed and throughout execution?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s expectations as split between (i) BAU preparation for an orderly solvent exit and (ii) the point at which a solvent exit execution plan is needed and the firm is executing the exit, with the latter being the focus of the Chapter described in the TARGET. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f] In BAU, the firm is expected to prepare for an orderly solvent exit and to produce a solvent exit analysis that meets the expectations set out for preparation. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] When solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the firm is expected to produce a solvent exit execution plan, and then manage and monitor the execution of the solvent exit. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] The Chapter in the TARGET should be read as applying specifically in that latter phase—i.e., when the execution plan is needed and during the firm’s execution—so the firm should ensure it has transitioned from BAU preparation (analysis) to execution-focused deliverables and oversight (execution plan plus management/monitoring) at the point the execution plan is required. [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f] [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]

question: If a firm is moving from normal business to actually carrying out a solvent exit, what documents should it have (analysis vs execution plan), and when does the Chapter’s guidance apply (only once the execution plan is needed and during the exit)?
gold_answer: The firm should separate what it does in normal business (BAU) from what it does once it needs an execution plan and is carrying out the solvent exit, because the Chapter described in the TARGET applies in that execution-plan-needed and execution period. [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f] [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] In BAU, the PRA expects the firm to prepare for an orderly solvent exit and to produce a solvent exit analysis that meets the expectations for preparation. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] Once solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the PRA expects the firm to produce a solvent exit execution plan. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] After that, the firm is expected to manage and monitor the execution of the solvent exit, which aligns with the TARGET’s statement that the Chapter covers expectations when the execution plan is needed and during execution. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f] Practically, this means the analysis is the BAU preparation output, while the execution plan (and the related management and monitoring) is the output and activity set that becomes relevant when the firm has reached the stage where an execution plan is needed and it is executing the solvent exit. [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3] [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f]

question: Where a third country branch outsources activities to a service provider that is in the same group, how should the branch approach (i) assessing group-based control or influence over the service provider for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and (ii) responding to a PRA (or other relevant competent authority) request for information needed to supervise compliance of the outsourced activities with the regulatory system?
gold_answer: A third country branch that outsources activities to a service provider in the same group may factor its degree of control over, or ability to influence, that service provider when applying the requirements referenced in 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, but it must still be able to provide supervisory authorities with the information they need about the outsourced activities. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Specifically, the branch’s group relationship is relevant only to the extent it demonstrates how the branch controls the service provider or can influence the provider’s actions for those identified purposes. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Separately, when the PRA or any other relevant competent authority asks, the branch should make available all information necessary for those authorities to supervise whether the outsourced activities are being performed in compliance with the requirements of the regulatory system. [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1] In practice, this means the branch should be prepared to explain both (i) how its control/influence within the group affects the service provider’s conduct in relation to 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and (ii) to furnish the underlying information about the outsourced activities that enables supervisory review of compliance performance. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]

question: When describing the PRA’s planned transparency reporting on the MA framework, how should a compliance team link the purpose and timing of the first report to the specific HMT Solvency II Review reference identified in the ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’?
gold_answer: A compliance team should describe the PRA’s MA framework reporting as a transparency measure that is explicitly tied to implementing the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review, and should identify that the relevant HMT review is the one referenced as paragraph 1.17 in the ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3] The description should also state that the PRA intends to publish these reports regularly alongside the PRA Annual Report and that the reports will cover application review timelines and decision rates. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] For timing, it should specify that the first such report is planned for publication in 2025, and that this timing is part of the PRA’s stated plan for regular reporting connected to the Solvency II Review outcome. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] To make the cross-reference clear and auditable, the compliance team should point to the ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ consultation response as the location where the cited Solvency II Review reference appears (paragraph 1.17), aligning that citation with the PRA’s statement that it is implementing the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review. [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3] [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]

question: If someone asks why the PRA will publish reports on the MA framework and what they will include, what should you say, and how do you point them to the exact Solvency II Review reference mentioned in the consultation response?
gold_answer: You should explain that the PRA plans to publish regular reports on the MA framework to improve transparency and to put into effect the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] You should also say what the reports will cover and when they start: they will be published alongside the PRA Annual Report, they will include application review timelines and decision rates, and the first report is planned for 2025. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] To point to the exact Solvency II Review reference, you should direct the reader to paragraph 1.17 of the document titled ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ (available at the government consultation link), because that is the specific place identified for the Solvency II Review reference. [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3] Bringing both points together, the PRA’s stated reporting package (regular MA framework reports with those metrics, starting in 2025) should be presented as the transparency mechanism that supports implementing the outcome of the HMT Solvency II Review that is cross-referenced via paragraph 1.17 in the consultation response. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3]

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how do you determine whether the firm must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, or whether 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 are disapplied due to the group parent’s head office being in a designated overseas jurisdiction under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations (and regulation 14(3) applying)?
gold_answer: For a firm in a group covered by 2.1(3), you must first assess whether the group-level operational resilience obligation applies, and then check whether the specific disapplication condition for 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 is met. The firm is generally required to ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of its group comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (noting the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3), and that 2.1(3) is referenced as being subject to 22.5). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] Separately, where the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] In practice, this means you must confirm both the group coverage status (2.1(3)) and the overseas-jurisdiction/regulation-14(3) condition to conclude whether 22.2–22.4 are switched off, while still addressing the group-level compliance duty described for groups within scope of 2.1(3) (as framed in the operational resilience provision). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]

question: If a firm is in a 2.1(3) group, when does it have to make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems meet Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, and when are 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 switched off because the parent’s head office is in a designated overseas jurisdiction under the IRPR regulations?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), it is within the scope of a rule that requires the firm to ensure the group’s strategies, processes and systems comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (with the stated carve-out for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3), and with 2.1(3) described as being subject to 22.5). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] However, for a 2.1(3) group there is also a separate condition that can turn off the application of 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4: those provisions do not apply if the group parent undertaking’s head office is in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] So you need two checks: (1) confirm the firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3) to identify the group-level operational resilience compliance duty, and (2) confirm the overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to decide whether 22.2–22.4 are disapplied for that firm. [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]

question: Where the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that a home resolution authority’s regime will achieve outcomes aligned with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives, how does that affect the PRA’s willingness to host a branch from that jurisdiction, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances fit into the resulting supervisory or structural expectations for an existing branch?
gold_answer: If the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver outcomes consistent with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA’s stated position is that it is likely not prepared to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] For an international bank already operating through an existing branch, the PRA indicates that the firm may be required to establish a UK subsidiary where such assurance is lacking. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] In that same insufficient-assurance scenario, the PRA further signals that supervision may need to move toward a more standalone basis, aligned with an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This supervisory emphasis on standalone outcomes links to the Bank’s stated capability: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] Taken together, the PRA’s reluctance to host (or its push toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch) is framed around ensuring resolvability aligned with UK objectives, while the Bank’s branch resolution powers provide a mechanism that can operate on a standalone basis where circumstances warrant. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]

question: If the PRA does not feel confident about the home country’s resolution setup for a bank branch, what might the PRA require for a bank that already has a UK branch, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve a branch on its own in some cases connect to that?
gold_answer: When the PRA cannot get enough comfort that the home resolution authority’s regime will produce outcomes that meet the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA says it is likely unwilling to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] If the bank is already in the UK through an existing branch, the PRA indicates it may require the firm to set up a UK subsidiary instead. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] The PRA also explains that, where assurance over home state resolution arrangements is insufficient, the firm may need to be supervised more on a standalone basis in a way that matches an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This focus on being able to deal with the branch or UK operations separately connects to the Bank’s stated powers: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including resolving branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] So, the PRA’s potential move toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch aligns with the idea that the Bank can, where circumstances apply, take branch-level resolution action on a standalone basis. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]

question: For an insurer that is within scope because it is a large non-directive insurer or a Swiss general insurer, what governance and prudential risk management framework elements must it have in place, including how risk information is escalated to management or the board?
gold_answer: If an insurer falls within the scope of the Chapter because it is a large non-directive insurer or a Swiss general insurer, it must implement the governance and prudential risk management elements described for insurers. [#TGT:5d1441b4dce1a2f4] In particular, the insurer must establish an effective system of governance together with prudential risk management systems. [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53] As part of that framework, the insurer must define its risk appetite or tolerance for risk so that the organisation has an articulated level of risk it is willing to accept. [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53] The insurer must also operate a process that identifies, measures, and monitors risk, ensuring risks are not only recognised but also assessed and tracked over time. [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53] Finally, the insurer must maintain appropriate systems for communicating risk-related information to management or the board, so that oversight bodies receive the information needed for governance and decision-making. [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53] These expectations apply to the in-scope insurer types identified for this Chapter, and the required communication channel explicitly includes management or the board. [#TGT:5d1441b4dce1a2f4]

question: For a PRA-regulated firm that is not a third-country branch and has smaller and less complex trading activities, but anticipates it is going to become a TWD firm as its business changes or grows, what must it be prepared to demonstrate to the PRA about its recovery plan, and how does that relate to its ongoing obligation under Rule 2.11 in the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm in this position should be prepared to show the PRA that its recovery plan satisfies the applicable requirements and criteria, while also maintaining the ability to execute the plan effectively in a stress. Specifically, if the firm anticipates it is going to become a TWD firm as its business changes or grows, it needs to anticipate meeting the stated expectations, even though those expectations do not apply to third-country branches and other firms with smaller and less complex trading activities. [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f] In parallel, the firm must be able to demonstrate to the PRA that its recovery plan meets the requirements set out in the relevant Chapter and the specified criteria. [#TGT:502e9f6c49e6d128] This demonstration obligation sits alongside the firm’s continuing status under Rule 2.11 in the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook, under which such other firms remain required to be able to implement their recovery plans quickly and easily in a stress. [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f] Taken together, the firm should plan for both (i) evidencing compliance of the recovery plan against the Chapter’s requirements/criteria to the PRA and (ii) ensuring operational readiness to implement the plan rapidly under stress, particularly as it approaches TWD firm status. [#TGT:502e9f6c49e6d128] [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f]

question: If a PRA-regulated firm has smaller and less complex trading activities but expects it may become a TWD firm as it grows, what does it need to be ready to show the PRA about its recovery plan, and what does Rule 2.11 still require it to be able to do in a stress?
gold_answer: The firm should be ready to do two related things: demonstrate the recovery plan’s compliance to the PRA, and ensure it can carry out the plan effectively during stress. If the firm starts to anticipate that it is going to become a TWD firm as its business changes or grows, it would need to anticipate meeting the expectations described, even though those expectations do not apply to third-country branches and other firms with smaller and less complex trading activities. [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f] At the same time, the firm must demonstrate to the PRA that the recovery plan meets the requirements set out in the relevant Chapter and the listed criteria. [#TGT:502e9f6c49e6d128] Separately from that demonstration, these other firms continue to be subject to Rule 2.11 in the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook, which requires them to be able to implement their recovery plans quickly and easily in a stress. [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f] In practice, the firm should treat the PRA-facing demonstration of meeting Chapter requirements/criteria as complementary to (not a substitute for) maintaining the operational capability to execute the recovery plan rapidly under stress, especially as it moves toward TWD firm status. [#TGT:502e9f6c49e6d128] [#SRC:5d5f89c35620dc3f]

question: What does it mean in practice for a firm to keep enough liquid assets to pay liabilities when they are due, and how do “liquidity buffer,” monitoring, and possible sale haircuts fit into showing the assets are sufficient?
gold_answer: In practice, the firm must keep liquid assets at a level that is enough to pay its liabilities as they become due, so the focus is on having cash-like resources available when payments need to be made. [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855] The firm should meet this by maintaining an adequate stock of liquid assets—called a “liquidity buffer”—that is sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and it is expected that this buffer remains adequate in both normal (benign) and stressed conditions. [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0] To judge whether the liquid assets are truly “sufficient,” the firm should consider its total liquidity needs, including what an appropriate liquidity buffer should be, and it should consider the level of liquid assets and how those liquid assets are monitored. [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0] The firm should also take into account that if it needs to sell assets to raise liquidity, haircuts might be applied, which can reduce the amount of usable liquidity available to meet liabilities when due. [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0] Put together, the rule is met by holding and monitoring a liquidity buffer that can cover liabilities as they become due, including under stress and after considering potential haircuts on sale. [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855] [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0]

question: Where a firm plans to issue a notified instrument that includes new or complex features (including instruments marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’), what engagement with the PRA is expected and who within the firm is expected to be accountable for the quality of the notification (including where signing/submission is delegated)?
gold_answer: The firm should plan for earlier and potentially longer PRA engagement when the notified instrument has new or complex features, including where the instrument is marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’, because the PRA is likely to need more time to review such cases. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] In that context, the PRA expects the firm to contact its usual supervisory contact as early as possible—such as once the relevant terms and conditions (including any side agreements) have been drafted—and to provide a clear explanation of how the proposed features meet the letter and objective of PRA rules and supervisory expectations. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] Separately, the PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to take responsibility for the overall quality of the firm’s capital structure, including being accountable for the quality of notifications to the PRA under Definition of Capital Part Rule 7A to 7D, even if the act of signing and submitting a notification form is delegated. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] Taken together, this means the firm should combine early supervisory engagement on the substance of new/complex features with clear internal accountability at SMF level for the quality of the notification package that supports that engagement.
