[#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868]

question: When the PRA applies its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state requirements, what does the PRA expect regarding (i) meeting MREL alongside CET1 held for risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers, and (ii) avoiding any double counting of CET1 across those expectations?
gold_answer: Where the PRA is applying its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) in relation to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, firms are expected to satisfy MREL while also maintaining CET1 at a level that reflects their risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe] [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] In doing so, the PRA’s expectation is that firms should not count the same CET1 twice—once toward meeting MREL and again toward the CET1 amount that reflects the risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] Although CET1 can be used to meet MREL, firms are not required to meet MREL using CET1, which reinforces the expectation that CET1 held to reflect buffers should not be automatically treated as simultaneously fulfilling MREL. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The scope of these expectations is framed by the PRA’s application of the Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 policies to the Bank-set MREL across both interim and end-state requirements, meaning the same non-double-counting approach should be observed in that policy context. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]

question: If the PRA is applying its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to the MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL, what does the PRA expect a firm to do with CET1 when it is meeting MREL and also holding CET1 for risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers?
gold_answer: In the context where the PRA applies its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, a firm is expected to meet MREL and also maintain CET1 in an amount that reflects its risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe] [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The PRA also expects the firm not to use the same CET1 amount to satisfy both objectives at the same time; in other words, CET1 should not be double counted toward MREL and toward the CET1 amount reflecting the buffers. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The PRA’s position also makes clear that, while a firm can meet MREL with CET1, it is not required to meet MREL with CET1, which supports the idea that CET1 held for buffer reflection should not be assumed to be the same CET1 used for MREL. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] These expectations apply within the policy setting described—namely, the PRA’s application of the Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 policies to Bank-set MREL for both interim and end-state requirements. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]

question: Where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution (so that it is exempt from putting Merger Resolutions and sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members), what timetable-management steps should the societies still follow from the point their boards resolve to seek a merger, and what member notifications must be included in the Merger Document?
gold_answer: Even where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution—removing the need to put Merger Resolutions to members and to send a Schedule 16 Statement to its members—the merger should still be managed against a structured timetable and member-notification sequence. [#SRC:98fdd2a7fe5b0420] As a practical planning baseline, the end-to-end path from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, a general meeting, and a confirmation hearing to the effective date is generally not expected to take less than six months, so the societies should plan on that scale when setting milestones. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] The societies should meet with the PRA’s staff as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger and agree a provisional timetable, which can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] Regardless of the board-resolution consent scenario described, members must be notified (via the Merger Document) of both the provisionally set date for the confirmation hearing and the proposed completion date of the merger. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]

question: If the PRA lets a transferee society do the merger by board resolution (so it doesn’t have to put Merger Resolutions to members or send them a Schedule 16 Statement), what should the societies do early on with the PRA about the timetable, and what dates do members still have to be told in the Merger Document?
gold_answer: If the PRA has consented to the transferee society proceeding by board resolution, the transferee society is treated as exempt from the requirement to put Merger Resolutions to its members and from sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members. [#SRC:98fdd2a7fe5b0420] Even in that scenario, the societies should run the merger using an agreed timetable and should engage the PRA early: as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger, the societies should meet with the PRA’s staff and agree a provisional timetable. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] That provisional timetable can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, which provides a point at which the schedule is settled for orderly execution. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] For planning expectations, the overall process from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, general meeting, confirmation hearing, and then to the effective date is generally unlikely to be completed in under six months. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] Members must still be notified in the Merger Document of the date provisionally set for the confirmation hearing and the proposed date of completion of the merger. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]

question: If an insurer wants to put an asset in its liquidity buffer, what does “unencumbered” mean, and how does that fit with the PRA’s expectation that the asset should be easy to sell and value (including in stressed markets)?
gold_answer: For an asset to be suitable for the liquidity buffer, it needs to meet the PRA’s expectation that buffer assets are unencumbered, high credit quality, readily marketable, and reliable sources of liquidity in stressed market conditions. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9] “Unencumbered” specifically means the asset is free of material legal, regulatory, contractual, or other restrictions that would limit the insurer’s ability to liquidate, sell, transfer, or assign it. [#TGT:bb68fdf1ed7da148] Putting these together, the insurer should check both market features and restriction-free ownership/control. On the market side, the asset should be easy to value with a high degree of certainty and should be either listed on recognised exchanges or tradable on large, deep and active cash or repurchase markets with many participants and observable prices. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9] On the restriction side, even if an asset looks liquid in the market, it would not be “unencumbered” if a material legal, regulatory, contractual, or similar limitation could prevent or materially hinder the insurer from selling or transferring it when needed. [#TGT:bb68fdf1ed7da148] Because assets can differ in how quickly they can be realised in stress, the insurer can use these checks to support whether an asset is more consistent with primary or secondary liquidity within the buffer. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9]

question: For a subsidiary assessing its Senior Management Functions (SMFs) and maintaining governance documentation, how should it treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) in light of the fact that Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and what related documentation and allocation expectations apply?
gold_answer: A subsidiary should treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) as the Statements of Responsibilities required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and it should keep those SoR current as part of its broader senior management governance arrangements. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e] In practice, the subsidiary is expected to ensure it has an appropriate number of SMFs that reflects its size, complexity, and governance structure, and to do so consistently with the principles in SS28/15 on strengthening individual accountability in banking. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Alongside calibrating SMFs, the subsidiary should ensure that both its Management Responsibilities Maps and its SoR are up to date. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] It should also allocate responsibilities in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, using the up-to-date SoR and Management Responsibilities Maps as the key governance artefacts supporting that allocation. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Because the SoR are specifically the FSMA section 60(2A) Statements of Responsibilities, the subsidiary’s obligation to keep SoR current should be understood as maintaining those section 60(2A) documents in an up-to-date state within its accountability framework. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]

question: When a subsidiary is checking it has the right number of SMFs for its size and updating its governance paperwork, what exactly counts as a Statement of Responsibilities (SoR), and what else must it keep up to date and aligned with the PRA Rulebook/SS28/15?
gold_answer: A Statement of Responsibilities (SoR) is the type of Statement of Responsibilities required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, so the subsidiary should treat its SoR as those section 60(2A) documents. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e] The subsidiary should also make sure it has an appropriate number of SMFs based on its size, complexity, and governance structure, following the principles in SS28/15 on strengthening individual accountability in banking. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] As part of that accountability setup, the subsidiary should keep two key governance documents current: its Management Responsibilities Maps and its SoR. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] It should then ensure responsibilities are allocated in line with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, using the up-to-date Management Responsibilities Maps and the (FSMA section 60(2A)) SoR to support that allocation. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Keeping the SoR “up to date” therefore means keeping the section 60(2A) Statements of Responsibilities current within the subsidiary’s governance and accountability arrangements. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]

question: When documenting changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts—particularly where the change involves integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society—how should PIBS 26 be characterised based on the definition provided?
gold_answer: PIBS 26 should be treated as a specific instrument whose nature is defined as “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and it is further characterised as a type of deferred share; that characterisation should be used when describing or assessing changes to the terms and conditions that apply to PIBS 26 within the broader set of products listed. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The relevant change scenario includes any amendments to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and it expressly encompasses changes arising from integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] Accordingly, when the integration of product lines results in revised terms for PIBS 26, the documentation should reflect that the affected product is a permanent interest-bearing share (i.e., a deferred share type), rather than treating it as an undefined or generic account product. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] This ensures the change description aligns the product-specific definition of PIBS 26 with the scope of term-and-condition changes contemplated for integration between the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]

question: If the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society integrate their product lines and this leads to changes in the terms for PIBS 26, what is PIBS 26 and how should that affect how you describe the change?
gold_answer: You should describe the change to PIBS 26 as a change to “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and note that this product is a type of deferred share, because that is the definition given for PIBS 26. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The change you are describing falls within the stated scope of “any changes to the terms and conditions” for CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and that scope explicitly includes changes connected to integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] So, when integration causes PIBS 26 terms to be updated, the write-up should not treat PIBS 26 as just another account label; it should reflect that the affected item is a permanent interest-bearing share (a deferred share type) whose terms and conditions are being amended as part of the integration. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] This links the product definition to the integration-driven term changes that the text identifies as in scope. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]

question: When documenting the purpose and use of a model, what must be described about the model’s operating boundaries and how should the firm treat use of the model outside those boundaries, including in stressed macroeconomic conditions?
gold_answer: A firm’s documentation of a model’s purpose and use should include a clear statement of the model operating boundaries under which the model’s performance is expected to be acceptable, alongside the relevant product or portfolio and a comparison of intended versus actual use. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] In this context, “operating boundaries” should be expressed as the sample data range used to assess model performance, and in multivariate settings this range includes the empirical variance-covariance relationships reflected in the sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] The documentation should also make explicit that applying the model by extrapolating beyond those operating boundaries is assumed to increase model risk, and this linkage should be highlighted where the extrapolation involves conditions such as macroeconomic indices during shock or stressed economic environments. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] Practically, the firm should connect the boundary description to the intended-versus-actual use comparison by identifying whether actual use stays within the sample data range (and associated multivariate relationships) that underpins the performance assessment, or whether it extends beyond it. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] Where actual use extends beyond the defined operating boundaries, the firm should treat that use as involving increased model risk and reflect that in the model’s documented use case and boundary conditions. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]

question: In a model write-up, what do you need to say about the model’s “operating boundaries,” and what does it mean for model risk if the model is used outside that range (for example, in a stressed economy)?
gold_answer: In the model write-up, you need to describe the model’s purpose and use, including what product or portfolio it relates to, how the model is meant to be used versus how it is actually used, and the model operating boundaries within which performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] Here, “operating boundaries” should be set out as the sample data range used to measure model performance, and if the model is multivariate that range also covers the empirical variance-covariance relationships present in the sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] You should then link this boundary definition to the intended/actual use comparison by stating whether actual use stays inside the sample data range used for performance assessment or whether it goes beyond it. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] If the model is used by extrapolating beyond its operating boundaries, that use should be treated as involving increased model risk, including where the extrapolation relates to macroeconomic indices under shock or stressed economic conditions. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] This makes the boundary description actionable: it is not just a label, but a condition for when performance expectations apply and when risk is assumed to rise. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f]

question: Where the PRA has deferred (in whole or in part) a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy because payment would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, when must the deferred amount be paid, and what is the maximum duration of any single deferral (including whether it can be renewed)?
gold_answer: A deferred contribution must be paid once making the payment no longer threatens the firm’s liquidity and solvency, and any PRA-granted deferral of a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy cannot run for more than six months at a time, though it may be renewed if the firm asks. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The trigger for payment is the point at which paying the deferred amount ceases to jeopardise the liquidity and solvency of the firm, meaning the deferral is not a permanent waiver but a timing adjustment tied to the firm’s financial condition. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA’s ability to defer applies where it considers that the contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and it may defer the obligation in whole or in part for a class A2 member in relation to a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Even if the liquidity/solvency concern persists, the PRA cannot grant a single deferral for longer than six months; however, the firm can request renewal, allowing the deferral to be extended through successive periods if renewed. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Accordingly, compliance planning should align both the condition-based payment point and the six-month cap with potential renewal requests. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]

question: If the PRA puts off a class A2 member’s recapitalisation payment levy share because paying now would harm the firm’s liquidity or solvency, how long can that delay last, can it be extended, and when does the firm have to pay the deferred amount?
gold_answer: The deferred amount has to be paid when paying it no longer puts the firm’s liquidity and solvency at risk, and the PRA’s deferral cannot last more than six months at a time, although it can be renewed if the firm requests it. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] In other words, the payment timing is linked to the firm’s financial condition: once the payment would not jeopardise liquidity and solvency, the contribution becomes due. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA can defer the obligation (fully or partly) only where it considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and this applies to a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The six-month limit is a hard cap on any single deferral period, but the firm can ask for a renewal, which allows the deferral to continue beyond six months through renewed periods. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] So the firm should track both (i) whether the liquidity/solvency risk has ended (which triggers payment) and (ii) the end date of the current six-month deferral period (which may require a renewal request). [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]

question: If an auditor, during their work on a firm that applies the matching adjustment, becomes aware the firm may not be compliant with MA requirements and the firm is no longer able to comply with the matching adjustment eligibility conditions, what immediate action is the firm required to take and what does the PRA expect the auditor to do first?
gold_answer: In this situation, the firm has an immediate obligation triggered by being no longer able to comply with the matching adjustment eligibility conditions, and the auditor has an expected first step of raising the issue with the firm. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] Specifically, where the firm that applies the matching adjustment is no longer able to comply with the matching adjustment eligibility conditions, it must act immediately (i.e., without delay) in response to that loss of ability to comply. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] Separately, if through the course of their work an auditor becomes aware that the firm may not be compliant with MA requirements (even if those requirements are outside the scope of the auditor’s opinion on the relevant elements of the SFCR), the PRA would expect the auditor to inform the firm in the first instance. [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba] In addition, auditors may choose to remind the firm of the requirement in Matching Adjustment 13.4 that, if it is not able to comply with the specified conditions, it must inform the PRA and take the necessary measures to restore compliance as soon as possible. [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba] Taken together, the firm’s immediate response obligation upon losing eligibility aligns with the auditor’s expected prompt escalation to the firm and optional reminder about notifying the PRA and restoring compliance. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba]

question: If a firm using the matching adjustment can’t meet the eligibility conditions anymore, what does it have to do right away, and what is the first thing the PRA expects an auditor to do if they spot possible MA non-compliance during their work?
gold_answer: When a firm that applies the matching adjustment is no longer able to comply with the matching adjustment eligibility conditions, it has an immediate duty to act at once in response to that inability to comply. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] This “immediately” trigger is tied to the firm’s status of no longer being able to meet the eligibility conditions for applying the matching adjustment. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] From the auditor’s side, if through the course of their work an auditor becomes aware that the firm may not be compliant with MA requirements, the PRA would expect the auditor to tell the firm first (before anything else). [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba] This expectation applies even where the MA requirements at issue are not within the scope of the auditor’s opinion on the relevant elements of the SFCR. [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba] The auditor may also choose to remind the firm about the Matching Adjustment 13.4 requirement to inform the PRA if it is not able to comply with the specified conditions and to take necessary measures to restore compliance as soon as possible. [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba] Together, the firm’s immediate action requirement and the auditor’s expected first notification to the firm are complementary responses to the same loss of compliance. [#TGT:3b0e448a0759ec38] [#SRC:01de25e6ccaf1aba]

question: When a society chooses to send a Transfer Summary rather than the full Transfer Statement to members, how must that summary be distributed in relation to the notice of the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered, and what continuing role does the PRA have during the transfer process in connection with the Transfer Statement?
gold_answer: If a society opts to use a Transfer Summary in place of the full Transfer Statement, it must treat the summary as a substitute document that is sent to members, rather than sending the Transfer Statement itself. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] In that case, the summary must be sent to every member who is entitled to receive the meeting notice, and it must be provided in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] Alongside this member-communication choice, the PRA’s role remains tied to the Transfer Statement and the transfer process: the chapter describes the PRA as approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members and participating in the confirmation procedure. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The same chapter also describes the PRA as continuing its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process, meaning the PRA’s involvement is not limited to a single approval step even where a Transfer Summary is used for member distribution. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The practical compliance outcome is that the society must align the timing and recipient scope of the Transfer Summary with the meeting notice for the Transfer Resolutions, while recognizing that the PRA’s approval and confirmation-procedure role is framed around the Transfer Statement and is accompanied by ongoing prudential supervision throughout the transfer process. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]

question: If a society sends a Transfer Summary instead of the full Transfer Statement, who must get it and when must it be sent, and what does the text say the PRA is doing during the transfer process?
gold_answer: When a society uses a Transfer Summary as a replacement for the Transfer Statement, the summary is the document the society may send to its members instead of sending the full Transfer Statement. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The summary must go to every member who is entitled to receive the notice of the meeting, and it must be sent in or with that meeting notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] Separately from how the society communicates with members, the PRA is described as having a role in approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The PRA is also described as continuing its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process, so its involvement runs through the transfer process rather than being limited to a single point in time. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] Putting these points together, the society’s choice to send a summary affects what is included with the meeting notice and who receives it, while the PRA’s described responsibilities still focus on approval of the Transfer Statement and participation in confirmation, alongside ongoing supervision during the transfer process. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]

question: For an asset that has both economic cash flow variability risks and event risk exposures, what standard approach should a firm apply, and what cash-flow/yield assumption and FS addition elements must be reflected when the dominant risk is economic?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the standard approach that corresponds to the dominant risk when an asset has both economic and event risk exposures; if economic risk is dominant, the economic-risk standard approach is the relevant one. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] Under that economic-risk standard approach, the PRA expects the assumed cash-flow pattern to be based on the investor receiving at least the minimum yield outcome (ie a “yield to worst” assumption). [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] If the asset’s features or contractual terms make a different method more appropriate, the firm may use an alternative on a case-by-case basis, but only if the method still assumes the issuer behaves in an economically rational manner. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] In addition, the FS addition within this approach should incorporate an appropriate de minimis allowance for reinvestment risk and rebalancing costs. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] This linkage matters because the dominant-risk selection determines which standard approach framework applies, while the economic-risk framework specifies the yield-to-worst cash-flow assumption and the required de minimis allowance in the FS addition. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855][#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]

question: When a firm has pooled asset exposures whose underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but show sufficient evidence of predictability, how may the firm treat event risks in the FS addition, and what economic-risk standard approach assumptions must still be used for cash flows and issuer behaviour?
gold_answer: For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks and there is sufficient evidence of predictability, the firm may propose applying the standard approach to the FS addition specifically for event risks. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] Even in that context, the economic-risk standard approach expectations for modelling cash flows remain relevant to the economic-risk component: the assumed cash-flow pattern should reflect a minimum investor yield outcome (ie “yield to worst”). [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] If the pooled assets’ features or contractual terms make another method more appropriate, the PRA indicates it can be considered case-by-case, but the alternative must preserve the assumption that the issuer will act in an economically rational manner. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] Separately, the FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for reinvestment risk and rebalancing costs. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] Taken together, the firm’s ability to propose a standard approach for event-risk FS addition in predictable pooled exposures does not remove the need to apply the economic-risk standard approach’s yield and issuer-behaviour assumptions for the economic-risk side of the exposure. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855][#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]

question: For a ring-fenced body that is considering an intragroup outsourcing arrangement that would involve entering into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, how should it align (i) the arm’s length requirement for that transaction and (ii) the PRA’s expectation that firms leverage existing operational continuity requirements and OCIR record-keeping to document intragroup dependencies and make information readily available on request?
gold_answer: A ring-fenced body should treat the proposed intragroup outsourcing as both (1) a group transaction that must be structured on arm’s length terms when the counterparty is a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, and (2) an arrangement where it may be able to use existing operational continuity frameworks and OCIR record-keeping to evidence and manage intragroup dependencies. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] In practice, this means the firm should: (i) ensure the transaction terms with the relevant group member are arm’s length, because that is a condition on entering into the transaction at all; and (ii) where relevant, leverage compliance work already performed under Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook to help meet expectations for intragroup outsourcing (including business continuity and exit planning). [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] To support both strands, the PRA expects firms to consider using elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, provided the relevant information is clear and can be made readily available to the PRA upon request. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]

question: If a ring-fenced body wants to outsource something to another company in its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, what does it need to do about (1) the deal terms and (2) the way it records and documents intragroup dependencies using operational continuity and OCIR records?
gold_answer: It needs to do two things in parallel: make sure the transaction itself is on arm’s length terms, and use (where relevant) existing operational continuity and OCIR documentation to show it understands and can evidence the intragroup dependencies created by the outsourcing. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] On the deal terms, a ring-fenced body is only permitted to enter into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate if the terms are arm’s length, so the outsourcing-related transaction must be structured accordingly. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] On documentation and governance, the PRA indicates that firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other regulatory areas to help meet obligations for intragroup outsourcing arrangements; for some banks this can include Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook, and this may help meet expectations around business continuity and exit plans. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] The PRA also expects firms to consider using elements of OCIR record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, as long as the information is clear and readily available to the PRA on request. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]

question: For a firm using an internal model, how should it meet the annual requirement to provide template AoC.01 on the analysis of change, and what additional narrative documentation must accompany that submission, including any flexibility on the format used?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model must make an annual submission to the PRA of template AoC.01 that presents the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A, and it must prepare that template in line with the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] In addition to the AoC.01 template content (which includes quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis), the firm is also required to submit supporting narrative documentation tied to Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and to Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] The firm has discretion over the format for that supporting narrative documentation, meaning it may choose the format in which it provides those narratives, while still ensuring the narratives are submitted as required. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] Practically, this means the annual AoC.01 package should combine: (i) the AoC.01 template completed per Chapter 10 instructions, and (ii) the additional supporting narrative documentation required by the Reporting Part provisions, with the narratives delivered in a firm-selected format. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3]

question: If a firm uses an internal model, what does it have to send to the PRA each year about the “analysis of change,” and what extra narrative material is required (and can the firm pick the format for that narrative)?
gold_answer: Each year, a firm using an internal model must submit template AoC.01 to the PRA, and that template must cover the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] The AoC.01 submission is not just numbers: it must include quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, and it must be prepared following the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] Alongside that annual AoC.01 submission, the firm must also provide supporting narrative documentation required under Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] For this supporting narrative documentation, the firm can choose the format it uses, so long as it submits the narratives as required. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] In short, the annual package combines the AoC.01 template (completed per Chapter 10 instructions) plus the additional supporting narratives linked to the Reporting Part requirements, with flexibility on narrative format. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3]

question: When a firm seeks to include assets with contractually bounded but uncertain cash-flow timing (eg callable bond final redemptions or bonds where the start of repayments can vary within a bounded period) in an MA portfolio, how should it frame the application between the fixed cash flow requirement and the alternative treatment as assets with HP cash flows, and what portfolio-level limit applies to that HP treatment?
gold_answer: A firm should treat assets with bounded but uncertain cash-flow timing as requiring a tailored justification, because the PRA will decide whether they satisfy the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis when assessing the firm’s application to include them. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] In framing the application, the firm can also evaluate whether those same assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows (by reference to the criteria in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D) and, if they do, propose including them in the MA portfolio under the limited allowance for such assets rather than relying solely on fixed cash flow treatment. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] For that alternative route, the SS defines assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A as “assets with HP cash flows,” and indicates firms can demonstrate these do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (as discussed in Chapter 4). [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1] The firm must also respect the aggregate portfolio constraint: HP cash flows are limited to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and the PRA may apply additional safeguards to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio. [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]

question: If a liability is secured on property, when can it still be written down because the security is a floating charge, and how should the plan describe the order of writing it down compared with lower-ranking liabilities?
gold_answer: Even if a liability is secured on property, it can still be eligible for write-down where the security is a charge that, when created, was a floating charge, because FSMA section 377B treats other property-secured amounts as excluded liabilities but does not treat floating-charge-secured amounts the same way. [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc] The write-down plan should then connect that eligibility to the PRA’s expectation that write-down plans broadly respect the creditor hierarchy so that the overall outcome for policyholders and other creditors is better than if no order were made. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] The plan should also reflect the PRA’s concern that floating charges are often granted to inward reinsurance creditors who are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority), and that writing down floating-charge-secured liabilities is intended to prevent those creditors from receiving an inappropriate and unintended priority. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] As a result, where a floating-charge-secured liability is not subordinated in that way, the plan should generally state that it would be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in line with the creditor hierarchy. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]

question: When a firm is preparing the report that must be submitted periodically under Chapter 3 and then summarised for periodic publication under Chapter 4, how should it determine what the PRA expects for the report’s content and format, and how does the PRA handle the timing of the submission and disclosure?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the report it must submit periodically under Chapter 3 as a report whose content and format are governed by the PRA’s expectations set out in the chapter addressing that Chapter 3 report, and it should plan its submission and related disclosure around dates the PRA will provide in advance. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] Specifically, firms have an obligation to submit reports on a periodic basis under Chapter 3 and to publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4, so the reporting and disclosure cycle includes both submission and a separate summary publication step. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] For the Chapter 3 report itself, the relevant expectations for what the report should contain and how it should be presented are set out in the chapter that describes the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] In operational terms, the firm should align its internal drafting and review process to those content/format expectations for the Chapter 3 report, and then schedule both the Chapter 3 submission and the Chapter 4 summary publication using the expected dates that the PRA will communicate ahead of time. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c]

question: If a firm has to send a report regularly under Chapter 3 and also publish a regular summary under Chapter 4, where does it look for what the report should include and look like, and who tells it the expected dates?
gold_answer: The firm should use the chapter that explains the PRA’s expectations for the content and format of the report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3 to shape what the Chapter 3 report includes and how it is presented. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] At the same time, the firm must remember that the overall process is periodic and has two linked outputs: (1) submitting the report periodically under Chapter 3 and (2) publishing a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] For timing, the PRA will communicate the expected dates for both the firm’s submission and its disclosure in advance, so the firm should plan its internal timetable around those PRA-provided dates rather than guessing them. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] Putting these together, the firm should draft the Chapter 3 report to meet the PRA’s stated content/format expectations, then use the PRA’s advance communication of expected dates to schedule both the Chapter 3 submission and the Chapter 4 summary publication as part of the same periodic compliance cycle. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8]

question: When a firm includes assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, how should it determine and evidence any required FS additions, including how it should treat sources of cash flow variability versus uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount?
gold_answer: A firm should treat assets with HP cash flows as a trigger for additional risk assessment within its MA portfolio and, where those additional risks arise, it must increase the FS for those assets to provision for them, consistent with the requirement that such assets are likely to introduce additional risks and therefore require FS increases. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] In determining the size and scope of those FS additions, the firm should consider additional risks arising from sources of cash flow variability and ensure those risks are sufficiently captured by the required FS additions using the guidance in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of the chapter. [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6] The firm must also identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for them, so the FS additions should reflect both variability-driven risks and timing/amount uncertainty. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] To evidence compliance, the PRA expects the firm to document the details of the identified sources of uncertainty and explain how it has allowed for them, which should align with the firm’s application of the paragraph 5.17 to 5.29 guidance when demonstrating that FS additions sufficiently capture the relevant risks. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]

question: If a firm holds assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, what does it need to do about extra risks and FS increases, and what should it write down to show it has covered cash flow variability and uncertainty?
gold_answer: If a firm’s MA portfolio includes assets with HP cash flows, it should assume these assets can add extra risk and therefore plan for increases to the FS for those assets to cover the additional risks they introduce. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] To work out what those FS additions should be, the firm should look for extra risks coming from sources of cash flow variability and make sure the required FS additions capture those risks, using the guidance in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of the chapter. [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6] At the same time, the firm must identify every source of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for each one, so the FS work should not focus only on variability but also on timing/amount uncertainty. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] The PRA expects the firm to document the details of these uncertainty sources and describe how it has allowed for them, which should be consistent with the firm’s approach to ensuring the FS additions are sufficiently captured under the paragraph 5.17 to 5.29 guidance. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]

question: If a bank uses a global booking model, what does it need to do differently when its resolution strategy is MPE, and how should that show up in its plans to wind down trading books in an orderly way?
gold_answer: When the bank’s resolution strategy is MPE, the bank should treat the connections created by a global booking model between the UK authorised firm and the rest of the group as something that could block or complicate resolution, and it is expected to address that risk. [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d] This matters in MPE because the strategy is defined as one where resolution powers are expected to be applied to multiple entities within a group, so cross-entity linkages can directly affect how resolution would be carried out. [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459] The bank should then reflect that assessment in its contingency plans by ensuring the booking model it has chosen is fully built into those plans, rather than treated as an afterthought. [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d] In particular, where the bank relies on contingency plans to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly way as part of an orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy, the PRA expects those plans to have fully considered the specific booking model adopted. [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d] Because MPE is group-wide across multiple entities, the bank’s planning should be aligned to that multi-entity context when considering how global booking inter-connectivity could affect execution. [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459]

question: For a firm using an internal model, what quarterly submission to the PRA is required for internal model changes, and what additional materials and rulebook references must be followed when preparing that submission?
gold_answer: A firm that uses an internal model must make a quarterly submission to the PRA using template QMC.01, and that submission must cover model changes together with supporting qualitative/narrative material prepared in line with the relevant rulebook instructions and reporting provisions. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] Specifically, the firm must submit quarterly template QMC.01 and include information on model changes plus supporting qualitative information, following the instructions in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 (for the template referenced in Chapter 9). [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] In addition, the quarterly reporting obligation described for internal model change governance requires the firm to provide a quarterly summary of both minor and major model changes to the PRA using the QMC.01 template, accompanied by supporting narrative documentation, and to do so in line with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d] Taken together, this means the quarterly QMC.01 filing is not limited to a bare template: it must be completed with the specified model-change information and the required qualitative/narrative support, and it must be prepared consistently with both the template instructions (Chapter 10 section QMC.01) and the reporting provision that frames the quarterly summary requirement (Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part). [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d]

question: If a firm uses an internal model, what does it have to send to the PRA every quarter about model changes, and where do the instructions and reporting basis for that quarterly QMC.01 submission come from?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model has to send the PRA a quarterly QMC.01 submission about model changes, and it must include both the required model-change details and accompanying qualitative/narrative support, prepared under the relevant PRA Rulebook framework and template instructions. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The quarterly item is template QMC.01 (referenced in Chapter 9), and the firm must provide information on model changes along with supporting qualitative information, following the instructions in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The same quarterly reporting is also described as a requirement to report a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA using the QMC.01 template, together with supporting narrative documentation, and this is tied to Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d] So, in practice, the firm should treat the quarterly QMC.01 package as (i) the template plus (ii) qualitative/narrative supporting material, and it should build the submission by aligning the content with the Chapter 10 QMC.01 instructions while also meeting the quarterly summary reporting basis set out in the Reporting Part provision. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d]

question: In the PRA’s expectation for assessing potential dividend payments, how should an insurer evidence that a planned dividend is appropriate, and how does that assessment extend to other forms of distributions such as returns of premiums to members of a mutual or loans to a parent or holding company?
gold_answer: An insurer should treat the PRA’s expectation as requiring a documented, evidence-based assessment showing that any planned dividend payment is justified by the insurer’s actual and projected business performance and by its current and future capital position, explicitly considered against the insurer’s documented risk appetite. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] To make that assessment complete, the insurer should apply the same type of evaluation not only to dividends but also to distributions to any capital providers, since the scope of “distributions” includes (among other examples) a return of premiums to the members of a mutual and a loan to a parent or holding company. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9] Practically, this means the insurer should be able to demonstrate, for each planned payment or transfer, how the decision aligns with both performance (actual and forecast) and capital considerations (current and forward-looking), and how those considerations were weighed in light of the risk appetite that has been documented. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] Where the proposed transaction is not a dividend but instead a return of premiums or an intra-group loan, it should still be assessed as a distribution to a capital provider and therefore evaluated using the same appropriateness framework. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]

question: If an insurer is thinking about paying a dividend, what does the PRA expect it to be able to show, and does the same kind of check apply if the payment is instead a return of premiums to members of a mutual or a loan to a parent/holding company?
gold_answer: The insurer should be able to show that any planned dividend payment makes sense when compared to (1) how the business has performed and is expected to perform and (2) the insurer’s capital position now and in the future, and it should do this while taking its documented risk appetite into account. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] This is not limited to dividends in a narrow sense: the same assessment is meant to cover distributions to any capital providers, which can include returning premiums to the members of a mutual and making a loan to a parent or holding company. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9] In practice, the insurer should prepare an explanation (and supporting analysis) that links the planned payment or transfer to actual and projected business performance and to current and future capital strength, and shows how those factors were considered against the risk appetite that has been documented. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] If the transaction is a return of premiums or a loan to a parent/holding company, it should still be treated as a distribution to a capital provider and assessed using the same appropriateness logic. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]

question: How should a firm determine the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business when it has annual contribution income data for at least one preceding financial year, and how does the approach change if the firm has not existed long enough to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: A firm must set its minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business by first determining whether it has a “preceding financial year” from which annual contribution income can be assessed, because the calculation method depends on that threshold. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] Where the firm has existed long enough to have at least one preceding financial year, it must identify its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business in any preceding financial year and then use that figure to select the corresponding minimum guarantee fund amount from the referenced table (column 1 for the income band and column 2 for the minimum guarantee fund). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] In contrast, if the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, it does not use the table-based approach tied to highest annual contribution income; instead, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is a fixed amount of £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] Accordingly, the firm’s first compliance step is to confirm whether it has a preceding financial year, since that determines whether the minimum guarantee fund is derived from the table based on highest historical annual contribution income or set at the £90,000 default for newer firms. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]

question: If a firm is working out the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business, what should it do when it has at least one past financial year to look at, and what amount applies if it is too new to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The firm should start by checking whether it has a preceding financial year, because that determines whether it uses an income-based table or a fixed amount. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm does have one or more preceding financial years, it must look back across those years and find its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business, then match that highest income level to the table so it can take the minimum guarantee fund amount shown for that income band. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm is too new to have a preceding financial year, it cannot apply the table method that depends on identifying the highest annual contribution income in a preceding year; in that case, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] This means the same firm could have different minimum guarantee fund outcomes depending on whether it has historical annual contribution income data from a preceding financial year (table-based) or lacks that history (the £90,000 default). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]

question: For a new or growing bank that is still loss making and reliant on regular capital injections, what capital planning approach is expected to avoid entering capital requirements plus buffers, and how does this expectation address the risk of leaving investment to the last minute described for such banks—particularly in the period before the bank has clarity on its path to profitability around three years post-authorisation and up to five years post-authorisation?
gold_answer: A new or growing bank that is loss making should not rely on last-minute fundraising to keep operating outside its buffers; instead, it is expected to maintain a credible capital plan that ensures new capital is injected early enough to avoid breaching capital requirements plus buffers while it works toward profitability. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] This forward-looking approach directly mitigates the poor capital management pattern where banks delay securing investment until the last minute, which can lead to entering buffers in the normal course of business or having to raise capital under difficult conditions that distract management. [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431] In setting that plan, the bank should be focused on reaching profitability and organic capital generation within a reasonable period after authorisation, recognising that prolonged unprofitability increases uncertainty about continued investor support. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] The plan should be framed against the PRA’s profitability milestones: by around three years post-authorisation the bank is expected to have greater clarity on its path to profitability, and by five years it should be profitable or have a credible strategy to become profitable supported by definite capital support. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] Overall, the expectation is proactive capital planning and timely injections to avoid buffer entry and the operational disruption associated with late-stage capital raising. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431]

question: If a new bank is still losing money and needs investors to add capital, what should it do to avoid dipping into its capital buffers, and how does that connect to the warning about banks waiting until the last minute to secure investment—especially before it reaches clearer profitability plans around year 3 and by year 5 after authorisation?
gold_answer: The bank should plan ahead so it does not end up needing emergency investment right before it would enter its buffers; the expectation is a credible capital plan that brings in new capital in good time to prevent capital requirements plus buffers from being breached while the bank is still not profitable. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] This is meant to counter the common pattern in new and growing banks of delaying investment until the last minute, which can push them into buffers during normal business or force them to raise capital under tough conditions that distract management. [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431] The bank’s planning should also reflect the PRA’s view that relying on regular injections is not sustainable long term and creates vulnerability if capital is not available when needed, so the bank should focus on reaching profitability and organic capital generation within a reasonable time after authorisation. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] In practical terms, the bank should use the timeline expectations to structure its plan: by around three years post-authorisation it should have more clarity on its route to profitability, and by five years it should be profitable or have a credible profitability strategy backed by definite capital support. [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b] Taken together, timely capital planning reduces the likelihood of buffer entry and avoids the management disruption associated with last-minute fundraising. [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431]

question: For a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission, what specific matching adjustment-related factor are auditors expected to consider when forming the audit opinion required in relation to the SFCR, and how does the permission boundary affect that consideration?
gold_answer: Auditors forming the audit opinion required for the SFCR are expected, to the extent it is material to their opinion, to consider the scale of the MA claimed by the firm. [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03] This expectation is linked to the fact that the MA’s impact on technical provisions sits within the elements that fall inside the required audit scope described by Rule 2.2 in the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03] The relevance of the matching adjustment permission is that the Chapter’s requirements apply to a firm only where it has been granted a matching adjustment permission, which frames the context in which MA-related calculations and claims are being made. [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131] In applying that context, auditors should recognise that the scale of the MA is not driven solely by the calculation mechanics (which depend in part on applying MA calculation requirements referenced in the IRPR regulations and the Matching Adjustment Part), but can also be affected if the assets and liabilities used in the MA calculation are not within the scope of an MA permission. [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03] Accordingly, for a firm within the Chapter’s scope due to having the permission, auditors’ consideration of MA scale should include whether the inputs used to compute the MA align with what is permitted, because that can change the claimed MA and therefore the audited technical provisions impact. [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03] [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131]

question: If you need PRA approval before sending a Merger Notification Statement to members on time, what should your written application include (especially the board declaration), and what specific detail about payments to directors or officers must appear in the statement?
gold_answer: You should submit a written application to the PRA that includes a board-backed completeness declaration, and you must ensure the Merger Notification Statement itself contains the required compensation information before it is sent to members within the time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The Merger Notification Statement cannot be issued to members until the PRA has approved it, and it must be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application for approval must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board that the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should be aware of. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also say whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information about those proposals is correct. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] Separately, the Merger Notification Statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The submission should be supported with accompanying documents: for Merger Notification Statements, the final draft should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed for that purpose, adjusted to the case and the less extensive information required. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The Schedule 16 approval application is also described as being accompanied by documents. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]

question: If a UK trading bank receives trades that are booked into the UK from another location, what should it do to show the UK is really overseeing those remote books, and how does that fit with the expectation about trader seniority and headcount when remote trading is increased?
gold_answer: The bank should be able to show that remote booking into the UK is not just an administrative process but is actively overseen in the UK, and that its staffing model matches where the activity is managed. [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615] Specifically, any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure there is substantive UK oversight of the remote books as a risk mitigant, especially when there is no UK-based trader covering the book (often referred to as “orphan books”). [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615] If the bank uses “shared” books or desks with both local and remote traders, it should define those clearly in its booking taxonomy, identify the part of the risk that is remote-booked into the UK, and apply remote booking controls to that identified portion. [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615] When the firm plans to increase remote trading (including changes that may relocate traders to an overseas office or entity managing risk into the UK), it should normally keep the number and relative seniority of traders broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations, so oversight and accountability are proportionate to where risk is run. [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf] It should also recognize that arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK are expected to face greater scrutiny and need high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled, which should be supported by the UK oversight and control measures described above. [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]

question: When assessing the operational resilience of the firm and group, how should the firm treat risks arising elsewhere in the group (including intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements) in relation to its ability to deliver “important business services” versus “critical operations,” and which UK entity types are those two service concepts tied to?
gold_answer: In assessing operational resilience, the firm should explicitly consider how risks originating elsewhere in the group—including those created or transmitted through intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements—could impair the firm’s ability to continue delivering the services that matter most, and it should map that assessment to the correct service concept based on the relevant UK entity type. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] “Important business services” should be treated as the category of services defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook, and this framing applies to CRR firms, described here as UK subsidiaries of international groups. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Critical operations” should be treated as the category of services defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Principles for Operational Resilience (March 2021), and this framing is relevant for UK branches. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] Practically, the firm’s group-risk analysis should therefore: (i) identify group-originated risks that could disrupt delivery; (ii) include dependencies created by intragroup outsourcing and inter-affiliate arrangements; and (iii) classify the impacted services as “important business services” for CRR firms (UK subsidiaries) or as “critical operations” for UK branches, so the resilience assessment is aligned to the applicable service definition. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf]

question: If problems in another part of the group (like intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements) could stop the firm delivering key services, how do you decide whether to call those services “important business services” or “critical operations,” and which types of UK firms does each label relate to?
gold_answer: You should treat group-wide issues—including those coming from intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements—as part of the operational resilience assessment, because they can affect whether the firm can keep delivering its most important services. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] To choose the right label for the services at risk, use the service concept that matches the UK entity type described. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Important business services” is the term used for services defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook, and that approach applies to CRR firms, described here as UK subsidiaries of international groups. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Critical operations” is the term used for services defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Principles for Operational Resilience (March 2021), and that approach is relevant for UK branches. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] So, when you identify a group-originated risk that could disrupt delivery, you should (1) link it to the affected service(s), (2) note whether the disruption pathway is via intragroup outsourcing or another inter-affiliate arrangement, and (3) classify the service as an “important business service” for a CRR firm (UK subsidiary) or a “critical operation” for a UK branch, so the resilience assessment uses the correct service definition. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf]

question: Given that the PRA’s expectations in the SS primarily address risks for corporate bond assets but are intended to be considered more widely unless stated otherwise, what modelling approach does the PRA expect a firm to take for the FS where the firm has material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments) within its MA portfolio, and how should the firm justify its approach if it does not distinguish between asset classes?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the SS expectations as a starting point beyond corporate bonds, but develop a distinct FS modelling approach for less liquid assets when its MA portfolio has material exposure to them, rather than assuming the corporate bond approach automatically fits. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] Specifically, for less liquid assets (including illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for those assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] The firm may be able to use an approach similar to the corporate bond methodology, but the extent of any changes from the core corporate bond method and calibration should be driven by how similar the less liquid assets are to corporate bonds; where similarity is low, a more bespoke methodology may be needed. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] This aligns with the PRA’s framing that, although the SS primarily targets corporate bond risks, many expectations are intended to apply more broadly across assets in MA portfolios unless the SS says otherwise, including specific expectations for less liquid assets in identified parts of the SS. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] If the firm does not distinguish between asset classes in its modelling, it should clearly justify why the model remains appropriate for each asset class, including the less liquid assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]

question: If a firm’s MA portfolio includes a lot of less liquid assets, can it just use the same FS model it uses for corporate bonds, and what does it need to explain if it uses one model for all asset classes?
gold_answer: The firm should not assume that a corporate-bond FS model can be applied unchanged to less liquid assets when the firm has material exposure to those assets in its MA portfolio. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] Although the PRA’s expectations in the SS mainly focus on risks from corporate bond assets, the PRA expects firms to treat many of those expectations as more widely applicable across the MA portfolio unless the SS specifically says otherwise, and the SS also flags that it contains specific expectations for less liquid assets in certain places. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] For firms with material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for those assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] A similar approach to the corporate bond method may be possible, but how much the firm adapts the core corporate bond methodology and calibration should depend on how similar the less liquid assets are to corporate bonds; in some cases the firm may need a more bespoke method. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] If the firm uses one model without distinguishing asset classes, it should clearly justify that the model is appropriate for each asset class it covers, including the less liquid assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]

question: When the business of a society is proposed to be transferred to a company (including an existing company or a specially formed company), what form of application(s) for confirmation must be made to the PRA, and what key documents and information must accompany those application(s), including any items that differ between an amalgamation and a transfer of engagements?
gold_answer: Where the business of a society is proposed to be transferred to a company (whether an existing company or a specially formed company), that company is the successor for the transfer context and the parties must follow the confirmation-application process described for mergers. [#TGT:947693b65e3fbcb8] For an amalgamation, the parties must submit a single joint application for confirmation to the PRA, whereas for a transfer of engagements the parties must submit separate applications for confirmation of the transfer. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] Each application must state the intended effective date of the merger and include two authenticated copies of the relevant transfer instrument (the Instrument of Transfer or the amalgamation agreement) and the associated disclosure document (the Merger Document or a separate Schedule 16 Statement). [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] In addition, if the transaction is an amalgamation, three signed copies of the Memorandum and Rules of the successor to the amalgamating societies must be provided to both the PRA and the FCA. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] Finally, each application must enclose the scrutineers report referenced in the merger process and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e]

question: If a firm needs to mark eligible deposits so they can be spotted right away, can it do this by marking the depositor’s account instead of each deposit, and should the marker stay on the account even if the balance is zero or negative?
gold_answer: Yes—so long as the firm’s method makes eligible deposits immediately identifiable, marking can be implemented in a way that achieves that outcome by using an account marker for eligible depositors. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] The PRA explains that, for meeting Depositor Protection 11.1, marking eligible deposits may be done by marking accounts of eligible depositors that contain eligible deposits, which indicates that an account-level marker can be an acceptable way to implement the marking requirement. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] If an account that has the eligible deposit marker later has a nil balance, or its balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect the firm to remove the marker. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] Accordingly, the firm should design its marking process so the marker supports immediate identification of eligible deposits while remaining in place on the relevant account even through zero or negative balances. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5]

question: Where a merger’s terms provide for (i) compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income and (ii) bonus payments requiring members’ approval as part of the Merger Resolutions, how should the society structure member approvals, including when bonus approval must appear in the Merger Resolutions of only certain societies versus all participating societies?
gold_answer: Member approvals should be structured so that compensation for loss of office/income is approved through a distinct special resolution, while bonus payments are approved through the Merger Resolutions in the manner dictated by the prescribed-limit test. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] Specifically, if the merger terms include compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income, those proposed payments must be put to members under a separate special resolution (i.e., not merely embedded within the general merger approval). [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] In parallel, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] The placement of that bonus approval across the participating societies depends on whether the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), calculated without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the bonus approval need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, the bonus approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This approach ensures the distinct approval route for loss-of-office compensation is maintained while bonus approvals are correctly allocated across Merger Resolutions based on the prescribed-limit threshold. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]

question: If a merger plan includes payments to directors or other officers because they are losing their job or income, and it also includes bonus payments, what member votes are needed and where do the bonus votes have to appear if the bonus total is within the prescribed limit versus above it?
gold_answer: You need two coordinated member-approval tracks: a separate special resolution for the loss-of-office/loss-of-income compensation, and Merger Resolutions that include the required approval for bonus payments, with the scope of those Merger Resolutions depending on the prescribed-limit test. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] If the merger terms provide for compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or of income, the proposed payments must be approved by a separate special resolution. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] Separately, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] To decide which societies’ Merger Resolutions must carry that bonus approval, you look at the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If that gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the bonus approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If it exceeds the prescribed limit, the bonus approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This keeps the compensation vote separate while ensuring the bonus vote is placed in the correct Merger Resolutions based on the limit. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]

question: When calculating the leverage ratio for quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024 on the basis that Article 473a of the CRR is disregarded for the capital measure under Article 429(3) of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part, what specific form of capital must be used as the capital measure for the relevant paragraph 2 purpose?
gold_answer: For quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024, the leverage ratio must be calculated using a capital measure determined on the basis that Article 473a of the CRR is treated as not applying for the purposes of the capital measure under Article 429(3) in Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part. [#SRC:05bd855cd46919eb] In that same calculation context, where the rule refers to “paragraph 2” and requires a defined “capital measure” for those purposes, the capital measure is specified as tier 1 capital (leverage).
