question: If an own funds item is issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, what must you do to classify it, and when are you not allowed to say it is free from encumbrances?
gold_answer: Where an own funds item has been issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, you must classify the own funds item using the criteria for classification set out in Own Funds 3A – 3J, but only if the applicable requirements for using those criteria are met [#TGT:e82491299baf128a]. At the same time, you must not treat the item as free from encumbrances unless a specific condition about claim ranking is satisfied: the claims relating to the own funds item must rank after the claims of all policyholders of the Solvency II undertakings belonging to the group [#SRC:bc73a26522603455]. So, when you are doing the classification required for these issuer types, you need to check how the claims on the item rank compared with those policyholder claims. If the item’s claims do not rank after all such policyholder claims, then it is prohibited to consider the item free from encumbrances, and your classification work must proceed without that assumption, aligning the classification obligation [#TGT:e82491299baf128a] with the encumbrance restriction [#SRC:bc73a26522603455].

question: For a firm that has entered into a transaction in which it sold securities to or purchased securities from a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm, under an arrangement requiring a later trade back in equivalent securities, when does the Chapter’s defined “condition” become relevant for assessing whether the scope provision is engaged at the relevant date (including the timing trigger and the fact that the later trade has not yet occurred)?
gold_answer: The scope provision is engaged where a firm has sold securities to or purchased securities from a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm, and that sale or purchase was made subject to an agreement that the counterparty would later sell to or purchase from the firm equivalent securities, either on the firm’s demand or within six months. The scope text further makes applicability at the relevant date contingent on the fact that the subsequent sale or purchase has not taken place and that specified conditions are satisfied. The TARGET then defines what counts as the Chapter’s “condition” for these purposes: it is triggered “at any time after” the firm’s sale or purchase of securities under the type of agreement described in the scope provision, and it operates as the condition referenced when determining whether the scope’s prerequisites are met. Read together, the SOURCE sets the transactional and timing perimeter (including the six‑month/demand feature and the “not taken place” status at the relevant date), while the TARGET supplies the definition of the condition that must be applied once the post-transaction timing trigger is reached. [#SRC:a022765b252dd8d0] [#TGT:eeca91cf4aa90ee3]

question: If a firm sells securities to, or buys securities from, a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm and there is a deal to later trade back equivalent securities, when does the rule’s “condition” start to matter, and what else must be true at the relevant date for the scope to apply?
gold_answer: The “condition” starts to matter once there has been a sale or purchase of securities by the firm under the kind of agreement described in the scope provision—i.e., an agreement linked to a transaction where the firm sold securities to or purchased securities from a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm, and the counterparty is expected to later sell to or purchase from the firm equivalent securities. The TARGET clarifies that the condition is assessed at any time after that initial sale or purchase under such an agreement, so it is a post-transaction trigger tied to the existence of that agreement. The SOURCE then adds what must be true for the scope to apply at the relevant date: the later (subsequent) sale or purchase of equivalent securities has not yet taken place, and the specified conditions referred to in the scope text are satisfied. In other words, you use the TARGET to identify when the condition is in play (after the initial transaction under the agreement) and the SOURCE to confirm the transaction type, the demand/within-six-months feature, and the “not yet happened at the relevant date” requirement. [#SRC:a022765b252dd8d0] [#TGT:eeca91cf4aa90ee3]

question: Where a firm and a group are within scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and related PRA Rulebook Articles, what must the firm ensure is additionally included in its SFCR regarding capital management, and how must that content be presented?
gold_answer: When a firm and a group are in scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and the referenced Articles of Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, that disclosure context frames the broader set of information the firm is expected to address [#SRC:2ae4fedd8ca85f88]. In addition to whatever information is disclosed under those Reporting routes, the firm has a distinct SFCR obligation focused on capital management: the SFCR must go beyond the core items and include any other information that is material to the capital management of the firm. This additional material information is not to be embedded informally within other narrative; it must be presented in a dedicated, separate section of the SFCR, ensuring it is clearly identifiable as supplementary capital-management content [#TGT:6d803b1270670d13]. Read together, the scope provision clarifies the disclosure setting (information disclosed by a firm and a group under the listed Reporting provisions), while the SFCR requirement imposes an affirmative duty on the firm to capture any further material capital-management information and to structure it as a standalone section within the SFCR.

question: If a firm and a group have to disclose information under the listed Reporting provisions and PRA Rulebook Articles, what extra capital-management information must the firm put in its SFCR, and where in the SFCR must it appear?
gold_answer: If the situation falls within the scope where the information that a firm and a group discloses is made pursuant to the listed Reporting provisions and the referenced Articles in Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, that establishes the disclosure context the firm is operating in [#SRC:2ae4fedd8ca85f88]. In that context, the firm still has an additional SFCR requirement specifically tied to capital management. The firm must ensure the SFCR includes any other information that is material about the capital management of the firm, even if that information is not already covered by the disclosures made under those Reporting provisions. The SFCR also has a presentation requirement: this extra material capital-management information must be set out in a separate section, rather than being scattered across other parts of the report [#TGT:6d803b1270670d13]. Taken together, the scope language identifies when the firm-and-group disclosure framework applies, and the SFCR obligation ensures the firm adds and clearly segregates any further material capital-management information in the SFCR.

question: If an institution is a small CRR firm and is covered by the disclosure rules, what does it have to disclose about pay, and which staff does it have to focus on?
gold_answer: If an institution is in scope of the disclosure framework and it is a small CRR firm, the source text indicates that a specific disclosure requirement applies for that type of institution, and that this requirement is the one connected to the remuneration disclosure framework it references [#SRC:47c62d3f801c6d13]. In that situation, the institution must make disclosures about its remuneration policy and practices, but the target text makes clear that the disclosures are not for all employees; they are for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. Putting the two together: the source tells you when the special disclosure treatment is relevant (only for institutions subject to the framework that are small CRR firms, and only for the remuneration-related information set), and the target tells you what the institution must actually disclose (information about remuneration policy and practices) and who the disclosure must cover (staff categories that materially affect the institution’s risk profile).

question: When a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation, how must it be prepared to evidence to the PRA, on request, that its arrangements, processes and mechanisms prevent the use of underlying exposures that include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: A firm that acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation and is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook must be prepared to demonstrate to the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms to comply with the relevant requirements in that framework [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. In practical terms, that demonstration should include showing that the firm’s governance and controls are designed to avoid prohibited structures in the securitisation’s asset pool, including ensuring that the underlying exposures used in the securitisation do not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. The expectation is not merely that the firm intends to comply, but that it can evidence, on request, that it has put in place adequate mechanisms to support compliance across its securitisation activities, consistent with its role(s) in the transaction [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. Accordingly, the firm should be able to explain how its processes identify and exclude securitisation positions from the underlying exposures and how those processes are embedded within its overall compliance arrangements [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].

question: If you are updating a governance pack that lists SS5/16, SS21/15, the EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance, and SS28/15, what date should you show for SS28/15 and what Bank of England page should you use to pull the document?
gold_answer: If your governance pack groups SS28/15 (strengthening individual accountability in banking) together with SS5/16 on corporate governance and board responsibilities, SS21/15 on internal governance, and the EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance (EBA Governance Guidelines), you should keep SS28/15 aligned with that same governance reference set [#SRC:2c626199be43f728]. For the specific dating and sourcing details to include for SS28/15, the date shown should be December 2020, and the document should be pulled from the Bank of England’s prudential regulation publication page at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2015/strengthening-individual-accountability-in-banking-ss [#TGT:add0c244e780cb55]. This approach ensures your pack is internally consistent: it reflects that SS28/15 is the accountability-focused item within a broader governance list, and it uses the Bank of England page and December 2020 date as the concrete reference point for the SS28/15 source you are relying on.

question: If Firms have to oversee the calculation of technical provisions in certain cases, what do they have to do about the quality of the data used for that calculation?
gold_answer: When Firms are required to oversee the calculation of technical provisions in the relevant cases, they must also make sure the inputs to that calculation meet the required data quality standard. That means Firms must ensure the data used in calculating their technical provisions is appropriate for the calculation, complete (so key information is not missing), and accurate (so it is correct and not misstated). The oversight duty is therefore not limited to checking the final numbers; it must extend to ensuring the calculation is built on data that meets these criteria. Put another way, the obligation to oversee the calculation in the specified cases [#SRC:c69a5186a3609ccb] should be carried out in a manner that ensures compliance with the requirement that Firms ensure the data used in the calculation of their technical provisions is appropriate, complete and accurate [#TGT:e66de813d5b55075].

question: When determining the required margin of solvency, how must the calculation be performed for the portion of a contract that falls within general insurance business class 1 or 2, and how do the applicable conditions and limitations affect that determination?
gold_answer: In determining the required margin of solvency, the determination must be made subject to the conditions and limitations identified as 3.2 to 3.6 [#TGT:5e5b7b2850bdd40d]. Within that overall obligation, where the matter concerns the portion of a contract that is within general insurance business class 1 or 2, the calculation for that portion must follow the specified method of calculation referenced for that case [#SRC:d72adb022790b994]. Practically, this means the required margin of solvency is not determined in a single undifferentiated way for all business: the portion of the contract that falls within general insurance business class 1 or 2 is treated as a distinct case for calculation purposes, and the method applicable to that case must be used for that portion. At the same time, the overall determination remains expressly conditional: even when applying the correct method for the class 1 or 2 portion, the required margin of solvency must still be determined in a manner that is subject to 3.2 to 3.6, which frame or constrain how the determination is made.

question: If part of a contract is in general insurance business class 1 or 2, what method must be used to work out the required margin of solvency for that part, and what other conditions must be taken into account?
gold_answer: The required margin of solvency must be determined, but that determination is expressly subject to 3.2 to 3.6 [#TGT:5e5b7b2850bdd40d]. For the specific situation where you are dealing with the portion of a contract that is within general insurance business class 1 or 2, the calculation for that portion must use the stated method of calculation that applies “in the case” of that class 1 or 2 portion [#SRC:d72adb022790b994]. So you do two things together: (1) identify whether you are calculating for a portion of the contract that falls within general insurance business class 1 or 2, and if so apply the relevant method of calculation to that portion; and (2) ensure that, even after applying that method, the overall required margin of solvency determination is made subject to 3.2 to 3.6. In other words, the method governs how to calculate the class 1 or 2 portion, while 3.2 to 3.6 set the conditions under which the required margin of solvency must be determined.

question: How should the permitted asset exposure limits be determined for an asset exposure, and what is the defined limit where the relevant asset is not addressed by the specified set of covered assets (excluding derivatives)?
gold_answer: The definition of permitted asset exposure limits operates in two linked steps across the paired texts. First, the general rule is that permitted asset exposure limits are only those limits that are expressly set out in the identified range of provisions, meaning the limits are not open-ended or implied beyond what is specified [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Second, the TARGET clarifies the consequence for assets that fall outside that covered set: where an asset is not covered by the specified covered provisions (and the asset is not a derivative), the permitted asset exposure limit is defined to be nil, so no exposure is permitted for that asset under the definition [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315]. Read together, the SOURCE establishes that the universe of permissible limits is confined to those expressly set out, while the TARGET supplies an explicit default outcome for non-covered assets (other than derivatives) by setting the limit at zero. This combined definition therefore requires checking whether the asset is covered by the specified provisions; if it is not (and is not a derivative), the applicable permitted limit is nil.

question: When a firm applies the matching adjustment under the PRA Rulebook framework that restates the IRPR provisions, is it prohibited from incorporating any element of the fundamental spread that reflects risks retained by the firm, including where that fundamental spread is determined using the specified calculation approach?
gold_answer: Yes. Read together, the PRA Rulebook statement that Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part restates the relevant IRPR provisions and sets out a prohibition means the firm is not permitted to build the fundamental spread into the matching adjustment where that spread reflects risks the firm retains [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]. The corresponding operative requirement confirms the same prohibition in direct terms: the matching adjustment must exclude the fundamental spread, and it ties that excluded amount to the fundamental spread as calculated under the referenced calculation approach, while still characterising it as reflecting risks retained by the firm [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c]. In combination, these passages make clear that the prohibition applies to the fundamental spread component itself (not merely to a particular method of presentation), and it applies specifically where the spread reflects retained risks. Accordingly, a firm should treat any retained-risk fundamental spread—however calculated under the referenced approach—as an amount that must be kept out of the matching adjustment.

question: Where a transferor society and a transferee society propose to use bonus payments to equalise the reserves brought into the combined society (including any scenario where both sets of members may receive a bonus and the equalisation level could be set below the transferee society’s capital ratio if prudent), how must member approval be obtained through the Merger Resolutions, and how does the prescribed limit on total gross cost affect which societies’ Merger Resolutions must include that approval?
gold_answer: Bonus payments may be used to equalise the reserves that a transferor society and a transferee society bring to the combined society, including (if thought desirable) paying a bonus to members of the transferee society so that the combined society’s reserves are equalised at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio, but only where it is prudent to do so [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]. However, implementing any such bonus arrangement requires members’ approval as part of the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. The way that approval must be embedded depends on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) measured against the prescribed limit: if the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval need only appear in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8], even if the underlying rationale for the bonus is reserve equalisation permitted on prudence grounds [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6].

question: If a transferor society and a transferee society want to pay bonuses to help equalise the reserves going into the combined society, what approvals must members give in the Merger Resolutions, and when does the prescribed limit mean every participating society’s Merger Resolutions must include that approval?
gold_answer: A bonus may be paid to members of a transferor society where it has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society, to help equalise the reserves both bring to the combined society; and if it is also desired to pay a bonus to members of the transferee society, the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio, but only if it is prudent to do so [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]. Even where such payments are permitted on that basis, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. The prescribed limit then determines how widely that approval must be included: if the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) is within the prescribed limit, approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8], regardless of whether the bonus is being used to equalise reserves between the transferor society and the transferee society [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6].

question: When a firm selects methods for technical provisions calculations and considers applying simplifications to the best estimate or risk margin, how should it assess and evidence that those methods comply with the PRA Rulebook requirements and are genuinely proportionate, taking into account the relevant Technical Provisions materials?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the choice of methods for technical provisions calculations as a compliance decision that requires careful assessment against the applicable PRA Rulebook requirements, and not merely as a modelling preference. In practice, this means the firm should evaluate whether the methods it uses comply with the Technical Provisions rules and confirm that the approach is in fact proportionate, particularly where it is applying simplifications to the best estimate and risk margin elements. The firm should align its assessment to the relevant PRA Rulebook materials identified as the Technical Provisions and Technical Provisions – Further Requirements Parts, using them as the core reference point for determining what “compliance” entails for technical provisions methods. The firm should also be able to explain how its proportionality conclusion follows from the methods selected and the way simplifications are applied, consistent with the PRA’s expectations for insurers in this area. This combined focus on rule compliance and proportionality is central to the PRA’s expectations for insurers applying simplifications [#SRC:c49ed4ccd97f655e] and should be anchored to the Technical Provisions and Technical Provisions – Further Requirements Parts of the PRA Rulebook [#TGT:f2eb7b02b4dd8a14].

question: If a firm uses simplifications when calculating technical provisions (best estimate or risk margin), what should it check to make sure its methods follow the PRA Rulebook and are proportionate, and which Technical Provisions materials should it look to?
gold_answer: A firm should start by checking, carefully and explicitly, whether the methods it uses for technical provisions calculations comply with the Technical Provisions rules and whether those methods are truly proportionate, especially when it is applying simplifications to the best estimate and risk margin elements. This is not presented as optional: the passage stresses the importance of firms making a careful compliance and proportionality assessment of the methods used, and it frames the PRA’s expectations specifically around insurers applying simplifications to those technical provisions components. To ground that assessment, the firm should look to the relevant PRA Rulebook materials identified as the Technical Provisions and Technical Provisions – Further Requirements Parts, and use those Parts as the benchmark for determining whether the chosen methods meet the applicable rules. The firm’s conclusion should therefore connect (i) the methods and any simplifications it applies, (ii) how it determined those methods comply with the Technical Provisions rules, and (iii) why the approach is proportionate, consistent with the PRA’s expectations [#SRC:c49ed4ccd97f655e] and the referenced Rulebook Parts [#TGT:f2eb7b02b4dd8a14].

question: When applying the IRPR condition that limits the share of a firm’s relevant portfolio made up of assets with highly predictable cash-flows, which assets fall within that category, and what portfolio-level constraint applies to their contribution to the matching adjustment benefit?
gold_answer: For the IRPR condition that caps the proportion of a firm’s relevant portfolio comprising assets with highly predictable cash-flows, the relevant category is the set of assets that meet the criteria identified in the supervisory statement and that firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching; those assets are the ones referred to as “assets with HP cash flows” for these purposes [#SRC:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. The scope of the IRPR condition is explicitly portfolio-based: it applies to the proportion of the firm’s relevant portfolio of assets that comprises such highly predictable cash-flow assets, and that proportion is subject to limits under the condition [#TGT:4bd5490ed842efb0]. In addition to being within the defined category, the supervisory statement sets a portfolio-level constraint on their use: the proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate so that it creates no more than 10% of the matching adjustment benefit for the matching adjustment portfolio, and it may also be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate additional risks introduced into the portfolio [#SRC:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].

question: For the IRPR rule that limits how much of a firm’s relevant portfolio can be made up of assets with highly predictable cash-flows, what counts as those assets, and how is their use capped in the matching adjustment portfolio?
gold_answer: The IRPR condition is about the proportion of a firm’s relevant portfolio of assets that is made up of assets with highly predictable cash-flows, and it says that proportion is subject to limits [#TGT:4bd5490ed842efb0]. To know what assets are in scope for that limit, you use the definition in the supervisory statement: assets that meet the criteria referenced there, and that firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching, are the assets that are referred to as “assets with HP cash flows” [#SRC:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. Once assets fall into that category, their use is constrained at the portfolio level. The supervisory statement explains that the proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate so that it creates only up to 10% of the matching adjustment benefit for the matching adjustment portfolio, and it notes that additional safeguards may also apply to manage and mitigate the extra risks these assets could introduce into the matching adjustment portfolio [#SRC:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].

question: For a Northern Ireland credit union assessing whether it may treat a pre‑31 March 2012 loan as outside the Chapter 6 investment framework, how should it apply the Chapter’s definition that certain subordinated loans are not “investments,” and what maturity condition must still be satisfied to rely on the non-compliance permission?
gold_answer: A Northern Ireland credit union can determine whether Chapter 6’s investment-related requirements are engaged by first applying the Chapter’s definitional boundary: for the purposes of the Chapter, a loan is not treated as an “investment” where it is provided by a credit union on subordinated terms [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. Separately, the credit union has a specific permission not to comply with Chapter 6 in relation to any security invested in, or loan made, before 31 March 2012, but only if the relevant security or loan matures in line with the terms of the agreement that was in effect on 31 March 2012 [#SRC:28104f09a8f8bcc9]. Read together, the definition informs classification (whether the loan falls outside “investment” for Chapter purposes), while the permission provides a time- and maturity-conditioned route to non-compliance for legacy positions. Accordingly, even where a loan is treated as not an investment because it is subordinated, the credit union should still confirm whether it is relying on the legacy non-compliance permission for a pre‑31 March 2012 loan and, if so, ensure the maturity occurs according to the agreement terms in force on 31 March 2012 [#SRC:28104f09a8f8bcc9] and within the Chapter’s definitional framing [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1].

question: When can a Northern Ireland credit union avoid following Chapter 6 for an old loan, and how does the rule that a subordinated loan is not an “investment” affect that decision?
gold_answer: A Northern Ireland credit union has a limited ability to avoid complying with Chapter 6 for certain legacy positions: it need not comply with Chapter 6 for any loan made (or security invested in) before 31 March 2012, but only if that loan or security matures according to the terms of the relevant agreement that was in effect on 31 March 2012 [#SRC:28104f09a8f8bcc9]. Separately, for the purposes of the Chapter, a loan is not an “investment” if it is provided by a credit union on subordinated terms [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. Putting these together, the credit union should (1) classify the loan under the Chapter’s definition—if it is on subordinated terms, it is not treated as an investment for Chapter purposes [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]—and (2) if it is relying on the special non-compliance permission for pre‑31 March 2012 loans, confirm the timing and maturity conditions are met, meaning the loan must mature in line with the agreement terms that applied on 31 March 2012 [#SRC:28104f09a8f8bcc9]. The definition addresses what counts as an investment in the Chapter, while the permission addresses when Chapter 6 compliance is not required for older loans, subject to the maturity condition [#SRC:28104f09a8f8bcc9].

question: When an institution relies on internal hedges to recognise the effect of hedges against interest rate risks, how must it treat an internal hedge implemented via a trading book credit derivative that is intended to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, and what additional step is required before the exposure may be treated as hedged for capital calculation purposes?
gold_answer: Where an institution seeks recognition of the effect of hedges against interest rate risks, including internal hedges that meet the relevant requirements [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d], it must still apply the specific derogation governing internal hedges executed through a credit derivative booked in the trading book when the hedged item is a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]. In that case, the institution shall ensure that the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure is not deemed hedged for the purpose of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts solely because an internal hedge exists. The exposure may be treated as hedged for those purposes only if the institution purchases a corresponding credit derivative from an eligible third party protection provider that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Where that third-party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge for capital requirements, the institution shall also ensure that neither the internal credit derivative nor the external credit derivative hedge is included in the trading book for the purpose of calculating capital requirements.

question: If an institution wants to recognise the effect of internal hedges against interest rate risks, what must it do when the internal hedge is a trading book credit derivative used to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure?
gold_answer: Even where an institution is seeking recognition of the effect of hedges against interest rate risks and uses internal hedges that meet the applicable requirements [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d], it must follow the special rule for an internal hedge that uses a credit derivative booked in the trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]. In that situation, the institution shall ensure the non-trading book exposure is not treated as hedged for calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless it also buys matching protection from an eligible third party protection provider. That third-party protection must be a corresponding credit derivative that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. If the institution buys that third-party protection and recognises it as a hedge for capital requirements, it shall also ensure that neither the internal hedge nor the external hedge is included in the trading book for the purpose of calculating capital requirements. This means internal hedge recognition does not, by itself, allow capital relief for the non-trading book exposure.

question: How should a TWD firm use Template D and the related templates and instructions to evidence the expected breadth and granularity of data for wind-down, including the firm’s ability to provide and analyse information to support a materially accurate estimation of capital resource and RWA movements throughout the wind-down period?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should treat Template D as a practical benchmark for the level of detail and scope of information it needs to be able to generate and work with during wind-down. In particular, Template D is described as guiding the breadth and granularity of data that TWD firms should be able to provide and analyse in order to demonstrate a materially accurate estimation of capital resource and RWA movements throughout the wind-down period [#SRC:3a4ffe3be482ee12]. This expectation should be read alongside the broader set of templates and accompanying instructions, which are presented as the materials the PRA would expect TWD firms to be able to produce under the SS [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c]. Taken together, the firm should align its data production capabilities (what it can produce) with its analytical capabilities (what it can provide and analyse) so that the outputs are sufficiently detailed to support the estimation of capital resource and RWA movements across the full wind-down timeline, consistent with the PRA’s stated expectation that firms can produce the templates under the SS [#SRC:3a4ffe3be482ee12] [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c].

question: When a firm with a matching adjustment permission elects to use the EVT to support its attestation for a relevant portfolio of assets, what must it submit to the PRA, and how must the firm’s chosen assumptions be set and constrained when forming that attestation?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission is required to provide the PRA with the required attestation for each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole, and it must do so at the specified time, by the specified person, and in the specified form described in the attestation requirements [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d]. Where the firm chooses to use the EVT for attestation purposes, the PRA expects the firm to engage with the principles underlying the EVT and to base the attestation on the firm’s own assumptions that it judges to be appropriate for supporting the statement that the MA can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48]. Those assumptions must not fall below the PRA’s published minimum parameters where applicable, and the firm should also give additional consideration to any retained risks other than the NNEG that are not assessed by the EVT, so that the attestation submitted to the PRA appropriately reflects those risks while still meeting the required submission conditions (timing, signatory, and form) [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d].

question: When establishing technical provisions for insurance and reinsurance obligations to policyholders, what must a firm do to ensure the ceding entity’s balance sheet valuation is independent of the reinsurer’s, including where the insurer and reinsurer are in the same group, and what restriction applies to recognising any matching adjustment benefit available to the reinsurer?
gold_answer: A firm must establish adequate technical provisions for all of its insurance and reinsurance obligations towards policyholders, and it must do so on a basis that does not allow the technical provisions to be supported by balance sheet valuations that are dependent on a counterparty’s position [#TGT:61fda22d87d7b472]. Consistent with that obligation, the PRA expects that the ceding entity’s balance sheet is valued independently of the reinsurer’s, and that the reinsurer’s balance sheet is valued independently of the cedant’s, regardless of whether the insurer and reinsurer are within the same group [#SRC:70f319aac308143c]. This means the firm should structure its valuation and technical provisions process so that each party’s balance sheet is assessed on its own merits rather than by importing assumptions, benefits, or valuation outcomes from the other party. In particular, the cedant should not take credit for any matching adjustment benefit that is available to the reinsurer, because doing so would undermine the required independence of the ceding entity’s valuation and could distort the adequacy of the technical provisions established for obligations to policyholders [#SRC:70f319aac308143c] [#TGT:61fda22d87d7b472].

question: If a firm is setting technical provisions for its insurance and reinsurance obligations to policyholders, what must it do to keep the ceding entity’s balance sheet valuation separate from the reinsurer’s, even within the same group, and can the cedant count any matching adjustment benefit that the reinsurer has?
gold_answer: A firm must establish adequate technical provisions for all of its insurance and reinsurance obligations towards policyholders, and that requires a valuation approach that supports those provisions without relying on another party’s balance sheet outcomes [#TGT:61fda22d87d7b472]. The PRA expects that, to meet this requirement, the ceding entity’s balance sheet must be valued independently of the reinsurer’s and, in the same way, the reinsurer’s balance sheet must be valued independently of the cedant’s, regardless of whether the insurer and reinsurer are within the same group [#SRC:70f319aac308143c]. Practically, the firm should ensure its processes and governance treat the cedant’s and reinsurer’s valuations as separate exercises, so that the technical provisions are based on the firm’s own obligations and not on benefits or assumptions that arise only on the other party’s balance sheet. In particular, the cedant should not take credit for any matching adjustment benefit available to the reinsurer, because that would conflict with the expectation of independent valuation and could affect whether the technical provisions are adequate for policyholder-related obligations [#SRC:70f319aac308143c] [#TGT:61fda22d87d7b472].

question: When the PRA makes an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, what is the scope of that assessment for PRA authorisation and supervision, and how must the PRA distinguish it from any advice it may provide to HM Treasury for other equivalence purposes?
gold_answer: In making an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, the PRA’s assessment is scoped to whether the home state supervisor’s regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives, taking the relevant factors in the round and giving considerable weight to the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. Procedurally, the PRA also takes into account supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and considers the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK as part of that overall judgement [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. The applicability boundary is that this equivalence assessment is based on outcomes achieved and is undertaken for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, and it is separate from any advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. Where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes, the PRA may provide advice to HM Treasury, but that advisory role does not change the PRA’s own authorisation-and-supervision focus for its equivalence assessment [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581].

question: Where an insurance business transfer scheme involves more than one transferor or transferee, and the PRA decides to treat the arrangement as a single scheme for fee purposes, what fee must the transferor(s) pay and by when must payment be made in relation to any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert?
gold_answer: If an insurance business transfer scheme involves more than one transferor or transferee, the PRA may, in its discretion, treat it as a single scheme so that only one fee is applied, rather than multiple fees for each party or component of the scheme [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1]. In that case, the applicable regulatory transaction fee is £25,000, and it is payable by the transferor seeking regulatory consent for the scheme [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. The payment deadline is tied to the procedural step of seeking an independent expert: the fee must be paid on or before the date of any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. Where there is more than one transferor, responsibility for that single fee does not fall on only one of them; instead, the transferors are jointly and severally liable for the fee, meaning each transferor can be held responsible for ensuring the £25,000 is paid by the required time [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1].

question: If an insurance business transfer scheme has more than one transferor or transferee, and the PRA chooses to treat it as one scheme with one fee, what amount must be paid and when does it have to be paid before applying to the PRA to appoint an independent expert?
gold_answer: When an insurance business transfer scheme involves more than one transferor or transferee, the PRA can choose to treat the whole arrangement as a single scheme for fee purposes, so that only one fee applies to the scheme overall [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1]. In that situation, the transferor seeking regulatory consent must pay a regulatory transaction fee of £25,000 [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. The timing is specific: the fee is due on or before the date of any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert, so payment must be made no later than that application date [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. If there is more than one transferor involved, they do not split the obligation in a way that limits responsibility to a single party; instead, the transferors are jointly and severally liable for the fee, meaning each transferor remains responsible for ensuring the single £25,000 fee is paid on time even though the PRA is applying only one fee to the scheme [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1].

question: When a society has received a merger or takeover proposal, what must it do in parallel: (i) make a written application to the PRA for approval of the relevant Statement, including the required board declaration about completeness and any other proposals, and (ii) ensure members receive the prescribed notification particulars with the correct meeting notices?
gold_answer: Where a society has received a merger or takeover proposal, it must run two linked compliance tracks. First, it must submit a written application to the PRA for approval of the relevant Statement, ensuring the Statement is prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports, and that the application includes a declaration made on behalf of the board confirming the Statement is complete and contains all material information the directors consider members should be aware of. That declaration must also address whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm the information about them is correct, and the application should be accompanied by the specified supporting documents [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50]. Second, once a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must send notification of the prescribed particulars to every member entitled to notice of a meeting, either separately or together with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting, and—if not already provided—include it with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved [#TGT:e13932686034a534].

question: If the society receives a merger or takeover proposal, what must it do to (1) apply to the PRA for approval of the Statement and (2) notify members with the right meeting notices?
gold_answer: If the society receives a merger or takeover proposal, it must take steps both with the PRA and with members. On the PRA side, it must make a written application to the PRA for approval of the relevant Statement. The Statement must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports, and the application should include a declaration made on behalf of the board that the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware of. The declaration should also state whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information about them is correct, and the application should be accompanied by the required supporting documents [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50]. On the member-notification side, once a proposal of either kind has been received, notification of the prescribed particulars must be sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting, either separately or together with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting, and (if not already given) must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved [#TGT:e13932686034a534].

question: For the purposes of identifying what counts as a prescribed responsibility, how should a firm treat responsibilities that are stated to be disapplied, including any third country branch prescribed responsibilities—do those responsibilities still fall within the defined category of prescribed responsibilities, or are they excluded when the disapplication applies?
gold_answer: The definition establishes that a “prescribed responsibility” is any responsibility that is set out in the relevant rule, i.e., the category is determined by being listed as a responsibility in that rule rather than by whether it is currently operative in all circumstances [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39]. Separately, the prohibition-style provision states that the prescribed responsibilities set out in the referenced place, and the third country branch prescribed responsibilities set out in the referenced place, “shall not apply” in the circumstances addressed by that provision [#SRC:ee1cfc9a7e685892]. Read together, the responsibilities remain within the defined universe of “prescribed responsibilities” because they are responsibilities “set out” in the rule, but the source text makes clear that, where the disapplication applies, those otherwise-defined prescribed responsibilities are not applicable and therefore should not be treated as applying obligations in that context. Compliance mapping should therefore distinguish (i) classification (it is a prescribed responsibility because it is set out in the rule) from (ii) applicability (it does not apply where the disapplication is triggered), including for third country branch prescribed responsibilities [#SRC:ee1cfc9a7e685892] and the definition of prescribed responsibility [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39].

question: What does “prescribed responsibility” mean here, and what happens if the text says the prescribed responsibilities and the third country branch prescribed responsibilities do not apply—are they still “prescribed responsibilities” or not?
gold_answer: A “prescribed responsibility” is defined by reference to the responsibilities that are listed in the relevant rule: if a responsibility is set out in that rule, it is treated as a prescribed responsibility for classification purposes [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39]. However, the source passage adds an important limitation on when those responsibilities operate: it states that the prescribed responsibilities set out in the referenced place, and the third country branch prescribed responsibilities set out in the referenced place, “shall not apply” in the situation covered by that provision [#SRC:ee1cfc9a7e685892]. Putting the two together, you should treat the items as belonging to the defined category (because they are responsibilities set out in the rule), but you must also recognize that, where the disapplication applies, they are not applicable requirements in that context. In practical terms, your register can still label them as prescribed responsibilities under the definition, while your applicability analysis should mark them as disapplied for the relevant case, including for third country branch prescribed responsibilities [#SRC:ee1cfc9a7e685892] as defined by being set out in the rule [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39].

question: When a firm intends to innovate in how it takes deposits from retail customers (including tokenised deposits), what does it mean in practice to proceed in a way that aligns with the PRA’s expectations, given the PRA’s definition of when wholesale business becomes a financial-stability concern and can influence designation decisions based on UK scale and asset size?
gold_answer: A firm innovating in the way it takes deposits from retail customers, including by taking tokenised deposits, is expected to implement that innovation in a way that is aligned with the PRA’s relevant letter to deposit-takers, rather than treating the innovation as outside established supervisory expectations [#SRC:04c53a83fcea3bf0]. In applying that obligation, the firm should frame its approach with an understanding of the PRA’s description of when activities can pose risks to financial stability: wholesale business is particularly concerning where it reaches a scale in the UK such that significant losses or operational dependences could create problems in financial markets or contribute to the failure of other financial institutions [#TGT:309e0ad5d8f01b9e]. The PRA also treats size as a factor in deciding whether to designate investment firms as PRA-regulated firms, and its approach includes considering whether a firm’s total gross assets (or those of investment firms in the same group) exceed £15 billion [#TGT:309e0ad5d8f01b9e]. Accordingly, the firm should ensure its deposit-taking innovation is developed and executed consistently with the PRA’s stated expectations while being mindful of scale-related risk triggers described by the PRA.

question: If a firm wants to change how it takes deposits from retail customers (for example, using tokenised deposits), what must it do to stay aligned with the PRA, and how does the PRA define the kind of UK scale in wholesale business that can create financial stability risks and affect whether firms are designated?
gold_answer: A firm that intends to innovate in the way it takes deposits from retail customers, such as by taking tokenised deposits, is expected to do that innovation in a manner consistent with the PRA’s relevant letter to deposit-takers [#SRC:04c53a83fcea3bf0]. To understand what “consistent” should achieve in risk terms, the firm should also take account of how the PRA describes financial-stability risk from wholesale business: the risk is particularly relevant when the business reaches a scale in the UK where significant losses or operational dependences could cause problems in financial markets or contribute to the failure of other financial institutions [#TGT:309e0ad5d8f01b9e]. The PRA further indicates that size is a factor in deciding whether to designate investment firms as PRA-regulated firms, and that its approach includes considering whether total gross assets (or the total gross assets of investment firms in the same group) exceed £15 billion [#TGT:309e0ad5d8f01b9e]. In practice, the firm should align its deposit-taking innovation with the PRA’s letter while being mindful of these scale-based risk and designation considerations.

question: How must a firm align its risk-management system with the firm’s policies that relate to the specified areas listed in the referenced set of areas, including how those policies are to be set out in further detail, so that the firm can continuously identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks at both individual and aggregated levels and their interdependencies?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that its risk-management system is designed and operated in a way that is consistent with, and supported by, the firm’s policies that relate to the specified areas listed in the referenced set of areas, which are to be set out in further detail in the referenced materials [#SRC:01041daf6bcf6af2]. In practice, this means the firm’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures should be established, implemented, and maintained so they can continuously identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report the risks to which the firm is or could be exposed, both at an individual level and in aggregate, including the interdependencies among those risks [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. The policies provide the subject-matter coverage the firm must address, while the risk-management system provides the operational framework—through strategies, processes, and reporting procedures—to deliver continuous risk identification and oversight across the firm’s exposures and their connections. The firm should therefore treat the policies as inputs that shape the scope and content of the system’s ongoing risk measurement, monitoring, management, and reporting outputs.

question: A firm has policies that relate to certain listed areas and are set out in more detail elsewhere. What must the firm do to make sure its risk-management system uses those policies to continuously identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks (including linked risks) at both individual and overall levels?
gold_answer: A firm must connect its risk-management system to its policies that relate to the specified listed areas, which are described as being set out in further detail in the referenced materials [#SRC:01041daf6bcf6af2]. The firm’s obligation is not just to have policies, but to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system made up of strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that can work on a continuous basis [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. To satisfy both, the firm should use those policies to define what areas the system must cover, and then ensure the system’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures actually deliver continuous identification, measurement, monitoring, management, and reporting of the risks the firm is or could be exposed to. This must be done at the level of individual risks and also in aggregate, and it must take into account how risks depend on or affect each other (their interdependencies) [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].

question: When applying the procedure for the relevant subsidiaries, how must a firm incorporate the Bank’s views on whether the resolution group’s capabilities would achieve resolvability outcomes broadly comparable to those in the Bank of England’s approach to assessing resolvability, and what is the applicable publication date for the referenced update?
gold_answer: In applying the procedure “for the relevant subsidiaries,” the firm must explicitly take into account the Bank’s views on a specific comparative question: whether “the capabilities of the resolution group would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable” to the outcomes described in the Statement of Policy titled “The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability” [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a]. The cross-referenced material that updates the Bank of England’s approach is identified by a dated entry, which provides the timing context the firm should use when aligning its assessment to the Bank’s approach: “July 2019” [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e]. Read together, the source establishes the procedural requirement to incorporate the Bank’s views in evaluating the resolution group’s capabilities against the SoP’s resolvability outcomes, while the target supplies the concrete date associated with the update to that approach. Accordingly, the firm’s documentation and internal analysis for the relevant subsidiaries should reflect both (a) the Bank-view-informed comparability assessment and (b) the fact that the referenced update is dated July 2019, as the linked update is the identified point-in-time reference for the approach being applied [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a] [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e].

question: For the relevant subsidiaries, what does the procedure require you to do with the Bank’s views on whether the resolution group can achieve outcomes comparable to the Bank of England’s resolvability approach, and what date is given for the update you should be looking at?
gold_answer: For the relevant subsidiaries, the procedure requires you to take into account the Bank’s views on a defined issue: whether the resolution group’s capabilities would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable to those set out in the Statement of Policy called “The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability” [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a]. The related reference material that points you to an update of that approach is tied to a specific date, which is the concrete timing detail you should use when identifying the correct update: “July 2019” [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e]. Using both passages together, you should (1) frame your assessment around the Bank’s views on comparability between the resolution group’s capabilities and the SoP’s resolvability outcomes, and (2) ensure you are consulting the update identified as July 2019 when you look up the Bank of England’s updated approach. This ensures your work reflects the required Bank-view-informed comparison and is anchored to the dated update reference provided, rather than an undated or unspecified version of the approach [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a] [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e].

question: For purposes of meeting administration and vote validation, how must a society’s systems determine and recognise which persons qualify as members and, among those members, which are eligible to vote, given the defined categories of building society membership and the voting restriction applicable to minors?
gold_answer: A society’s systems must be able to identify who is a member and then distinguish which members are eligible to vote, because the meeting notice must be sent to all members entitled to receive it and scrutineers must be able to validate votes on the Transfer Resolutions [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]. Membership status is limited to persons who are either shareholding members or borrowing members, so systems must recognise shareholding members by confirming that the person holds a share in the society (including via a share account or other listed share investments) and recognise borrowing members by confirming indebtedness to the society in respect of a loan secured on land, subject to any Rules-based adjustments to when borrowing membership is conferred or ceases [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e]. To operationalise voting eligibility, systems should aggregate share account balances across multiple account holders to test for the requisite qualifying shareholding, check continuity of shareholding, and identify minors [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]. Even though a minor may be a member, the system must flag that the minor may not vote on any resolution, ensuring votes are not accepted or validated for that person [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e].

question: How should a society’s systems decide who counts as a member and then recognise which members can vote, including how to handle shareholding members, borrowing members, and minors?
gold_answer: A society’s systems must be capable of recognising members who are eligible to vote, because that information is needed to send the meeting notice to all members entitled to receive it and to allow scrutineers to validate votes cast on the Transfer Resolutions [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]. To do this correctly, the system first needs to identify who is a member under the membership definition: a person can only be a member if they are either a shareholding member or a borrowing member [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e]. The system should therefore recognise a shareholding member by confirming the person holds a share in the society (for example through a share account or other listed share investments), and recognise a borrowing member by confirming the person is indebted to the society for a loan secured on land, noting that the Rules may affect when borrowing membership is conferred or ends [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e]. Once membership is established, the system must determine voting eligibility by checking qualifying shareholding (including aggregating balances across multiple accounts), continuity of shareholding, and by identifying minors [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]. A minor may be a member but must be treated as not eligible to vote on any resolution [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e].

question: For firms and FMIs, what is the scope of the expectation to continue complying with Guidelines and Recommendations that are not captured in the non-exhaustive appendices, and how should that be applied given that only EIOPA materials in place at the end of the transition period are relevant for the purposes of this SoP and later EIOPA issuances are excluded?
gold_answer: The appendices are expressly non-exhaustive, so firms and FMIs must not treat inclusion in those lists as the sole determinant of what they should follow; instead, they should continue, where relevant, to comply with Guidelines and Recommendations even where those materials are not listed (including those made by predecessor committees to the ESAs), unless the relevant material has been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. At the same time, for the purposes of this SoP, the relevant EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations are those in place as at the end of the transition period, with links made available, and changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period being not relevant [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. Accordingly, firms and FMIs should align their ongoing compliance approach to the non-exhaustive nature of the appendices while applying the SoP’s temporal boundary for EIOPA-issued materials, and should also note that the Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of the linked materials [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980].

question: If a Guideline or Recommendation is missing from the appendices, do firms and FMIs still need to follow it, and which EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations count for this SoP given the end-of-transition-period cut-off and the exclusion of later EIOPA updates?
gold_answer: Yes. The appendices are not complete, so firms and FMIs should not assume that anything not listed can be ignored; they should continue, where relevant, to comply with Guidelines and Recommendations even if they are not included (including those made by predecessor committees to the ESAs), unless the material has been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. However, when determining what is relevant for the purposes of this SoP, the EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations that matter are those that were in place as at the end of the transition period, and links to those materials are provided [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. Any changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and any new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for this SoP [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. In using the linked materials, firms and FMIs should also recognise that the Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of those materials [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980].

question: If the PRA finds problems in a firm’s management, governance, or culture, what can it do to make the firm fix them, and what does the separate reference note mean for how you document the basis for those expectations?
gold_answer: If supervisors identify deficiencies in management and/or governance practices, including cultural deficiencies, the Proactive Intervention Framework (PIF) stage may change and the PRA can step up supervision in several ways: it can increase the intensity of supervision, set additional reporting requirements, and use additional information gathering powers; it can also require the firm to act to address the deficiencies over a set period, meaning the firm should plan and deliver remediation within that defined timeframe [#SRC:0ef314f548192f59]. Separately, the PRA sends an annual letter to each firm’s board outlining the key risks of greatest concern and expects to verify itself that action is taken on those key risks, telling the board when and how it expects to do this; for firms with the lowest potential impact, a standard letter may be used unless specific issues are identified [#SRC:0ef314f548192f59]. The reference note “9. Ibid, 194 and 196; ibid, 196 and 198.” is the linked citation marker (Section 9.) that points to where the underlying supporting material is located, so your compliance file should preserve that cross-reference alongside the firm’s evidence of actions taken and any self-certification of closure by the most appropriate senior individual [#TGT:3874969acb95d73a].

question: When establishing hedging sets, what must be done to ensure they are set up in accordance with the applicable requirements, and how must Institutions structure those hedging sets by risk category within a netting set while allocating transactions to them?
gold_answer: The requirements operate together to impose both a compliance condition and an operational structuring duty. First, all hedging sets must be established in accordance with the specified framework, meaning the act of creating any hedging set is not discretionary as to method and must follow the referenced requirements [#SRC:aad180c11178b9e8]. Second, Institutions must implement that compliant establishment in a way that is granular to the netting set: they shall establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and, in addition, they shall assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a]. Read together, this means Institutions cannot treat hedging sets as a single undifferentiated bucket; they must (i) create hedging sets that meet the “in accordance with” condition, and (ii) ensure the resulting hedging-set architecture is organized per risk category within each netting set, with every transaction mapped into the appropriate hedging set. The combined obligation therefore covers both how hedging sets are established and how transactions are allocated across them.

question: What do Institutions have to do to set up hedging sets the right way, and how do they have to group them by risk category for a netting set and place each transaction into the right hedging set?
gold_answer: Institutions have two linked duties that must be satisfied at the same time. One duty is about the standard they must follow when creating hedging sets: all hedging sets must be established in accordance with the specified requirements, so the establishment process must follow that referenced approach rather than being done ad hoc [#SRC:aad180c11178b9e8]. The other duty is about how those hedging sets must be organized and used in practice: Institutions shall establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and shall assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a]. Put simply, Institutions must (1) create hedging sets in the required manner, and (2) do so in a structured way for each netting set by setting up hedging sets per risk category, then (3) ensure every transaction is allocated into the appropriate hedging set. Together, these requirements ensure both compliant setup and consistent transaction-to-hedging-set assignment.

question: Which credit unions does the PRA expect to follow the concentration limits, and are there any investments that the PRA says those limits do not apply to?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation applies to credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets, and it also applies to any credit unions that hold investments falling within the specific PRA Rulebook investment categories referenced in the source. For those credit unions, the concentration limits are presented as limits they should adhere to in addition to other limits that are separately required. However, the scope is not absolute: the source text explicitly notes an exception for certain investments, indicating that some investments are carved out from the expectation to apply the concentration limits. The target text reinforces and explains this boundary by stating that the PRA considers the concentration limits described above would not apply to a set of investments, meaning those investments sit outside the limits’ application. In combination, the source identifies the in-scope credit unions and flags that there is an exception for specified investments [#SRC:6cdd849d0a0503ce], and the target confirms that the concentration limits are not applicable to certain investments, defining the exclusion from scope [#TGT:12c6683751f9137d].

question: When a large subsidiary of a UK parent institution, a UK parent financial holding company or a UK parent mixed financial holding company (or a large subsidiary of a parent undertaking established in a third country) is subject to disclosure duties, how must it apply the requirement to disclose information on exposure to credit risk and dilution risk, and at what level of reporting must that disclosure be made?
gold_answer: The obligation applies to large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, as well as large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country, and it requires them to make the disclosures specified in the relevant set of Articles on either an individual basis or a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. Within that broader disclosure package, Institutions are specifically required to disclose information regarding their exposure to credit risk and dilution risk [#TGT:e7ba9eb1cd7f5dc8]. Read together, this means that where the actor is one of the large subsidiaries identified in the source, it must ensure that the credit risk and dilution risk exposure information is included as part of the required disclosures and is presented at the appropriate reporting level permitted by the source (individual or sub-consolidated). The source frames who is in scope and the permissible basis for disclosure, while the target clarifies that the content must cover exposure to credit risk and dilution risk as part of what Institutions must disclose.

question: If an entity is a large subsidiary of a UK parent institution (or of a parent undertaking in a third country), what does it have to disclose about credit risk and dilution risk, and does it report that information individually or on a sub-consolidated basis?
gold_answer: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country, are required to make the disclosures specified in the listed Articles, and they must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. Separately, Institutions have a specific duty to disclose information regarding their exposure to credit risk and dilution risk [#TGT:e7ba9eb1cd7f5dc8]. Putting these together, if the entity is one of the large subsidiaries described in the source and it is making the required disclosures, it must ensure that its disclosure includes the information about exposure to credit risk and dilution risk and that it is presented using one of the two allowed reporting bases (individual or sub-consolidated). The source tells you which entities are covered and the level at which they can disclose, while the target tells you that the disclosure content must include credit risk and dilution risk exposure information.

question: Where the group-level application trigger in 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, how must a firm treat its obligations when establishing and implementing the remuneration policy referred to in 2A.1(12), given that certain requirements apply at the level of the group with any necessary changes?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the compliance baseline is that specified requirements apply at the level of the group, and they do so “with any necessary changes.” This group-level scope expressly includes the Conditions Governing Business provisions covering 2A.1 to 2A.6, among other listed modules, meaning the firm must treat the remuneration-related framework as applicable on a group basis rather than only on an entity-by-entity basis [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that context, when the firm is establishing and implementing the remuneration policy referred to in 2A.1(12), it must comply with all of the principles that apply to that activity, and it must do so in a way that reflects the group-level application and any necessary adaptations required to make the requirements workable at group level [#TGT:9c0a502a887dae03]. Practically, the firm should ensure that the remuneration policy’s establishment and implementation processes are designed to meet the applicable principles while being capable of operating across the group structure, consistent with the scope rule that extends the relevant Conditions Governing Business requirements to the group with appropriate modifications [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] and the obligation to comply with all principles when setting and applying the policy [#TGT:9c0a502a887dae03].

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, does a firm have to follow the remuneration-policy principles at group level (with needed adjustments) when it sets up and uses the remuneration policy referred to in 2A.1(12)?
gold_answer: Yes. The scope rule states that where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, a defined set of requirements applies “at the level of the group” and does so “with any necessary changes,” and that set includes the Conditions Governing Business provisions covering 2A.1 to 2A.6 [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. Separately, the obligation on the firm is that, when it is establishing and implementing the remuneration policy referred to in 2A.1(12), it must comply with all of the principles that apply to that activity [#TGT:9c0a502a887dae03]. Read together, this means the firm cannot treat remuneration-policy compliance as purely local to a single entity when the group-level trigger applies; instead, it must ensure the remuneration policy is established and implemented in compliance with all applicable principles in a way that works across the group, making only those adjustments that are necessary to translate the requirements to the group context [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. The firm’s duty to comply with all principles attaches to the act of establishing and implementing the policy, and the scope provision determines that the relevant requirements apply on a group basis in those circumstances [#TGT:9c0a502a887dae03].

question: When this Part applies at the level of the group, how must the definition of a group be applied for a mixed activity insurance holding company, and which related undertakings must be treated as within that group for compliance purposes?
gold_answer: Where this Part applies at the level of the group, the compliance analysis must be performed on a group basis rather than only on a single entity, and the definition of a group must be applied accordingly [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. In that situation, the definition of a group must be applied to the mixed activity insurance holding company and extended across the relevant perimeter of connected undertakings [#SRC:ccf34fdd6215630c]. Specifically, the group perimeter must include its subsidiary undertakings, the undertakings in which it holds a participation, and undertakings to which it is linked by a common management relationship. Where applicable, the same approach must also be applied to the undertakings in a mutual-type group. The practical effect is that, once the Part’s group-level scope is engaged, the required group definition is not limited to direct subsidiaries; it also captures participations and common-management links, and may additionally capture mutual-type group undertakings where that structure applies. This ensures the group-level application of the Part aligns with the required breadth of the group definition.

question: If this Part applies at the group level, what does it mean to apply the group definition to a mixed activity insurance holding company, and which other undertakings must be included with it?
gold_answer: If this Part applies at the level of the group, you must treat the requirements as applying to the group as a whole, not just to one company [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. In that case, the definition of a group must be applied to the mixed activity insurance holding company and to the connected undertakings that fall within the required group perimeter [#SRC:ccf34fdd6215630c]. That perimeter includes: (1) its subsidiary undertakings, (2) the undertakings in which it holds a participation, and (3) undertakings linked to it by a common management relationship. Also, where applicable, the definition must be applied to the undertakings in a mutual-type group. So, once the Part’s scope is triggered at group level, you must include not only subsidiaries but also participations and common-management links, and potentially mutual-type group undertakings, when determining what entities are treated as part of the group for compliance purposes.

question: Where a firm has permission to use a partial or full internal model and is using an internal model for reporting to the PRA, what must it submit each quarter to evidence minor and major model changes, and what content must that quarterly submission cover?
gold_answer: A firm that has permission to use a partial or full internal model and is using an internal model must provide the PRA with a quarterly submission that both (i) delivers a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes and (ii) is made using the PRA’s prescribed quarterly reporting template for model changes.
