Its role is to absorb losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, and it is designed so that it does not duplicate what is already covered by the combined buffers [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224]. To understand what the PRA buffer is avoiding duplicating, the combined buffer must be treated as the set of buffers that includes the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs), and—only for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies—the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer) [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]. Taken together, these definitions explain that the PRA buffer is a separate capital layer above TCR and the combined buffer, while the combined buffer itself is made up of those specific named components [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7].

question: If you must identify measures to reduce the risks and include documentation changes to better match the preferred resolution strategy, what counts as standardised documentation versus non-standardised documentation, and how should that definition shape what you change?
gold_answer: You must identify the measures required to alleviate the risks, and that identification must include any changes required to documentation—covering both standardised and non-standardised documentation—to better align with the preferred resolution strategy [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5]. To do that correctly, you need to use the definition that standardised documentation refers to ISDA agreements, while non-standardised documentation refers to bilateral or bespoke agreements [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad]. This definition shapes the scope of your documentation work: you should treat ISDA agreements as the standardised set that may need changes, and separately review any bilateral or bespoke agreements as the non-standardised set that may also require changes. Your measures should therefore not be limited to one type of agreement; they must address documentation changes across both categories where needed, because the obligation is to identify measures that alleviate the risks and include documentation changes that improve alignment with the preferred resolution strategy. In short, the definition tells you exactly which agreements fall into each bucket, and the obligation requires you to consider and specify changes for each bucket as part of the risk-alleviation measures [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5] [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad].

question: When preparing a group recovery plan, how must firms that are parent entities of an international group demonstrate coverage of entities in other jurisdictions, and how must they document and explain dependencies between recovery options, including where options are mutually exclusive, in light of dependencies between group entities?
gold_answer: Firms that are parent entities of an international group must be able to show, within their group recovery plan, how they have covered the different entities located in other jurisdictions, rather than treating the plan as applying only to the parent or a single location [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. In doing so, the PRA expects firms to understand and reflect the dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, because these linkages affect how recovery actions can be executed across the group [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. Consistently, firms must detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive, so that the plan makes clear which actions can be pursued together and which cannot be combined [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6]. Taken together, this means the group recovery plan should connect entity coverage across jurisdictions with a clear mapping of option-to-option and entity-to-entity dependencies, enabling the PRA to assess whether proposed recovery actions are coherent across the international group and whether any constraints or incompatibilities have been explicitly identified [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41].

question: What must the firm do in its ongoing systems maintenance plan to make sure its systems keep meeting the rule on how eligible deposits are identified?
gold_answer: The firm must have a plan for the ongoing maintenance of its systems, and that plan must be geared toward keeping the systems able to meet the firm’s compliance obligations. Applied to eligible deposits, the maintained systems must continue to support a process where eligible deposits are marked so they can be identified immediately. So, the maintenance plan should be set up to preserve the system functionality needed to apply the marking and to keep that marking reliable over time, ensuring the firm can still distinguish eligible deposits without delay. The SOURCE requires the firm to have a plan for ongoing maintenance of its systems to support compliance [#SRC:af2ac33ab57b004e]. The TARGET specifies the concrete operational requirement that the firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Together, these mean the maintenance plan must sustain the system capability that enables that immediate identification through appropriate marking.

question: If a building society plans to transfer its business to a company that has permission under FSMA for the regulated activities it will take on after the transfer, what does this chapter cover and which Transfer Regulations does it point you to?
gold_answer: In this situation, the chapter applies only in a defined way: it provides information on the requirements of the 1986 Act that are relevant to the proposed transfer and on the procedures the building society should follow when transferring its business to a company having permission under FSMA to carry on the regulated activities it will undertake because of the transfer [#SRC:4b00e8966116b888]. To understand what “Transfer Regulations” means in that same context, the referenced instrument is The Building Societies (Transfer of Business) Regulations 1998 (SI 1998/212) [#TGT:f397656126935443]. The chapter also makes clear limits on reliance: it is not intended to be exhaustive and is not a substitute for looking directly at the 1986 Act and the Transfer Regulations, and it indicates the society should seek its own legal advice on those materials [#SRC:4b00e8966116b888]. So, you use the chapter for guidance on relevant 1986 Act requirements and procedures for this specific transfer scenario, but you must also consult the 1998 Transfer of Business Regulations as the Transfer Regulations it points to, alongside the 1986 Act itself [#SRC:4b00e8966116b888] [#TGT:f397656126935443].

question: For insurers that are general insurers in run-off, how should compliance teams integrate the obligation to comply with relevant provisions in the PRA Rulebook (including risk management expectations such as undertaking an ORSA) with the PRA’s stated approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006?
gold_answer: For general insurers in run-off, compliance should treat PRA Rulebook compliance—specifically the requirement to follow relevant provisions including the Risk Management chapter and to undertake an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA)—as a continuing baseline obligation that must be maintained alongside any work on a scheme of arrangement. In parallel, where the insurer is considering or progressing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, the firm should use the PRA’s supervisory statement on schemes as the complementary supervisory framework and ensure it is read together with the supervisory statement that reiterates the PRA Rulebook and ORSA expectations for run-off firms. Practically, this means governance, risk management, and solvency self-assessment processes should remain aligned with the PRA Rulebook while the scheme is developed and assessed, and the firm should cross-reference the PRA’s approach to schemes as set out in PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14 (April 2014) when planning and documenting the scheme process. This combined reading is explicitly indicated for general insurers in run-off [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] and is anchored by the identified SS3/14 publication [#TGT:8d6a107327860924].

question: If an insurer is a general insurer in run-off and is looking at a scheme of arrangement, what does it need to do about PRA Rulebook compliance (including ORSA) and how should it use PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14?
gold_answer: An insurer that is a general insurer in run-off should continue to comply with the relevant provisions in the PRA Rulebook, including the Risk Management chapter that contains requirements to undertake an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA). At the same time, if the insurer is considering a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, it should use the PRA’s supervisory statement on the PRA’s approach to such schemes as an additional, complementary supervisory reference. The key point is that the supervisory statement describing the PRA Rulebook and ORSA expectations is not a substitute for the schemes guidance; instead, it is intended to be read together with the PRA’s schemes supervisory statement for general insurers in run-off, so that the firm’s run-off risk management and solvency assessment work remains consistent while it plans or executes the scheme. The schemes document is specifically identified as PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14, dated April 2014, and should be treated as the relevant companion statement when aligning scheme planning with ongoing PRA Rulebook compliance [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] [#TGT:8d6a107327860924].

question: When the consolidated group SCR is calculated wholly or partly using the standard formula, which currency must be treated as the local currency for that calculation, and how does that choice determine whether another currency is a foreign currency for the purposes of this Chapter?
gold_answer: Where the consolidated group SCR is calculated, wholly or in part, on the basis of the standard formula, the local currency that must be applied for that SCR context is the currency used for the preparation of the consolidated accounts [#SRC:41e05ebdb62ac6a9]. The definition in this Chapter then uses that same concept of “local currency” as the reference point for classifying currencies: a currency is a foreign currency if it is not the currency used for the preparation of the firm’s financial statements (which the definition labels as the local currency) [#TGT:5b64a5c8fc45561c]. Read together, the obligation fixes the relevant “local currency” for the standard-formula consolidated group SCR by tying it to the consolidated accounts, and the definition explains the consequence of that designation—any other currency, i.e., any currency other than the currency used to prepare the relevant financial statements, is treated as foreign currency for the purposes of this Chapter. Accordingly, in the standard-formula consolidated group SCR setting, the currency of the consolidated accounts is the benchmark against which other currencies are assessed as foreign.

question: If a consolidated group SCR is worked out using the standard formula (even only partly), what currency do you have to use as the local currency, and what does that mean for deciding whether a currency counts as a foreign currency in this Chapter?
gold_answer: If the consolidated group SCR is calculated wholly or in part on the basis of the standard formula, the rule requires that the “local currency” for that purpose is the currency used to prepare the consolidated accounts [#SRC:41e05ebdb62ac6a9]. The Chapter’s definition then explains how to identify a “foreign currency”: it is any currency that is not the currency used for the preparation of the firm’s financial statements, and that financial-statement currency is what the definition calls the local currency [#TGT:5b64a5c8fc45561c]. Putting the two together, you first identify the currency used to prepare the consolidated accounts (because that is mandated as the local currency in the standard-formula consolidated group SCR context). Then, for the purposes of this Chapter, you treat any other currency—anything other than the currency used to prepare the relevant financial statements—as a foreign currency. In short, the required local-currency choice sets the baseline, and the definition tells you that all non-baseline currencies are foreign currencies.

question: When Institutions prepare disclosures about exposures to counterparty credit risk, what must they also disclose regarding their risk management objectives and policies, and how should this be framed across separate categories of risk?
gold_answer: Institutions must treat disclosures on exposures to counterparty credit risk as part of a broader disclosure package that also covers how they manage risk. Specifically, when Institutions make the required disclosures on their exposures to counterparty credit risk [#SRC:d9acbf70a085c485], they must also disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, explicitly including the risks referred to in the relevant Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. In practice, this means the counterparty credit risk exposure disclosures should not stand alone; they should be accompanied by an explanation of the objectives Institutions pursue in managing that risk and the policies they apply, presented in a way that is organized by distinct risk categories. The required risk management disclosures must be comprehensive enough to cover each category separately, and they must include the relevant risks within scope, so that the exposure information is contextualized by the corresponding governance and policy approach. This combined approach ensures that exposure disclosures are linked to the Institutions’ stated objectives and policies for managing those risks.

question: When a critical third party appoints a skilled person, what must the critical third party ensure the contract with that skilled person expressly states about the regulators’ right to enforce the relevant contractual provisions, and what related limitations and conditions must also be included to protect that enforcement right?
gold_answer: When a critical third party appoints a skilled person, the critical third party must ensure the contract with that person is in writing and expressly provides that the regulators have a right to enforce the specified provisions included in the contract, so that the regulators can bring proceedings to enforce those provisions directly [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2] [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. The contract must also expressly provide that, in any proceedings brought by the regulators to enforce those provisions, the skilled person cannot rely on any defence, set-off, or counterclaim that is not relevant to those provisions, thereby limiting the skilled person’s ability to resist enforcement on unrelated grounds [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. In addition, if the contract includes an arbitration agreement, it must expressly provide that the regulators, when exercising their enforcement right, are not treated as a party to or bound by that arbitration agreement [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. Finally, the contract must expressly provide that the relevant provisions are irrevocable and cannot be varied or rescinded without the regulators’ consent, preserving the regulators’ enforcement right against later contractual changes [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2].

question: If a critical third party hires a skilled person, what does the contract have to say about the regulators being able to enforce the contract terms, and what extra protections must be written in (for example, about defences, arbitration, and changing the terms)?
gold_answer: If a critical third party appoints a skilled person, the critical third party must put the required terms into the written contract with that skilled person [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2] [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. The contract must clearly state that the regulators have a right to enforce the relevant provisions included in the contract, meaning the regulators can bring proceedings to enforce those provisions directly [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. It must also state that, if the regulators bring enforcement proceedings, the skilled person cannot use any defence, set-off, or counterclaim unless it is relevant to those provisions, so unrelated disputes cannot be used to block enforcement [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. If the contract contains an arbitration agreement, the contract must also state that the regulators are not treated as a party to, and are not bound by, that arbitration agreement when they exercise their enforcement right [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f]. Finally, the contract must state that the relevant provisions are irrevocable and cannot be varied or rescinded without the regulators’ consent, preventing later changes that would undermine the regulators’ enforcement right [#SRC:cb41603f1ad1730f] [#TGT:c019810a830ee7a2].

question: For purposes of a TWD scenario, how must a TWD firm determine what constitutes an exit cost for positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated, and how should that defined exit cost be incorporated into the firm’s ability to project exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period?
gold_answer: A TWD firm’s obligation to be able to project its exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period requires it to apply the defined meaning of “exit cost” when identifying and quantifying those projected amounts [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. Under the definition, an exit cost is not simply any expense of winding down; it is specifically the gap between (i) the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and (ii) the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that, under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario, are to be novated, terminated or liquidated [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. Accordingly, when projecting exit costs over the wind-down period, the firm should (a) identify the relevant positions subject to novation, termination, or liquidation under its TWD actions and measures, (b) estimate the expected exit value for those positions under the TWD scenario, and (c) compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to calculate the gap that constitutes the exit cost. This defined gap then forms the basis of the firm’s exit cost projections across the relevant timeframe [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].

question: In a TWD scenario, what exactly counts as an “exit cost,” and how should a TWD firm use that definition when it needs to project its exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period?
gold_answer: An “exit cost” in a TWD scenario has a specific meaning that a TWD firm should use when meeting the expectation that it can project its exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. The definition ties exit cost to certain positions and to a particular calculation: it is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. So, when the firm projects “exit costs” over time, it should not treat the term as a general label for all wind-down spending. Instead, it should focus on the relevant positions that its TWD actions and measures would novate, terminate, or liquidate, estimate what those positions are expected to exit for under the TWD scenario, and then compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to determine the gap. That gap is what the firm should project as its exit costs across the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].

question: For a small run-off firm, how should the scope of “prescribed responsibilities” be determined, and what is the firm required to do with each such responsibility in terms of allocation to individuals approved for that firm?
gold_answer: For a small run-off firm, “prescribed responsibilities” are the responsibilities that are identified as such for that category of firm—i.e., the responsibilities that are described as prescribed in respect of a small run-off firm [#TGT:7d6962dad3a0f5f0]. Once the firm has identified that set, it has a mandatory allocation duty: it must allocate each of those prescribed responsibilities (as set out for the small run-off firm) to one or more persons [#SRC:c50521665b420fab]. The allocation is not optional and applies to each responsibility within the prescribed set, meaning the firm cannot leave any prescribed responsibility unassigned. The persons to whom responsibilities are allocated must be persons who, in relation to that small run-off firm, are approved under section 59 of FSMA by the relevant approving authority referenced in the obligation [#SRC:c50521665b420fab]. Read together, the definition establishes which responsibilities count as “prescribed” for a small run-off firm, and the obligation establishes the required action: complete allocation of each such responsibility to appropriately approved individuals for that firm.

question: What counts as a “prescribed responsibility” for a small run-off firm, and what must the small run-off firm do with each one in terms of assigning it to approved people?
gold_answer: For a small run-off firm, a “prescribed responsibility” is any responsibility that is specified as being a prescribed responsibility in respect of a small run-off firm [#TGT:7d6962dad3a0f5f0]. After identifying that list of responsibilities, the small run-off firm has to take a specific step: it must allocate each prescribed responsibility (the ones set out for it) to one or more persons [#SRC:c50521665b420fab]. This means every responsibility that falls within the prescribed set for a small run-off firm must be assigned; none can be left without an owner. The allocation must be made to persons who, in relation to that small run-off firm, are approved under section 59 of FSMA by the approving body referenced in the obligation [#SRC:c50521665b420fab]. In practical terms, the definition tells you which responsibilities are in scope for the firm, and the obligation tells you what the firm must do with each in-scope responsibility: assign it to appropriately approved individuals.

question: For variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate drawing up accounts under the Accounts Directives framework, International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, how must the yield be determined when the undertaking’s accounting period is longer or shorter than a year, and what profit-or-loss figure must be used in the yield ratio?
gold_answer: Where the yield is being determined for variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate that draw up accounts in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives, or in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, the yield on an asset is defined as a ratio to the value of the asset [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d]. In that context, if the undertaking’s accounting period is not exactly one year (i.e., it is longer or shorter than a year) and the relevant rule applies, the undertaking must annualise the amount of profits or losses for that accounting period. The annualised profit-or-loss figure is then the figure that must be used when calculating the yield under the ratio-based definition, rather than the unadjusted profits or losses for the non‑annual period [#SRC:f994473a44562eb1]. This ensures the numerator used in the yield ratio reflects a one‑year equivalent amount whenever the accounting period length differs from a year, while still applying the yield definition that ties the calculation to the asset’s value [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d].

question: If an undertaking has an accounting period that is shorter or longer than a year, what does it have to do to the profits or losses before working out the yield ratio for variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate using Accounts Directives, International Accounting Standards Committee standards, or US GAAP accounts?
gold_answer: For variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate that draw up accounts under legislation implementing the Accounts Directives, or under International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or under US generally accepted accounting practice, the yield on an asset is defined as a ratio to the value of the asset [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d]. If, in that situation, the undertaking’s accounting period is not a full year (because it is longer or shorter than a year) and the relevant provision applies, the undertaking must first annualise the amount of profits or losses for that period. The annualised amount is the figure that must then be used in calculating the yield, rather than using the raw profits or losses from the non‑standard period [#SRC:f994473a44562eb1]. In practical terms, the definition tells you the yield is calculated by comparing an amount to the asset’s value, and the obligation tells you that when the accounting period length differs from a year, the profit-or-loss amount feeding into that comparison must be converted to a one‑year equivalent before you compute the yield ratio [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d] [#SRC:f994473a44562eb1].

question: When a firm refers to the FS in its materials, how should the firm apply the definition that the FS comprises three elements, and what is the PRA’s expectation as to whether all elements must be taken into account absent an express carve-out?
gold_answer: The FS is defined as comprising three elements, meaning that any use of the term “FS” is not limited to a single component but instead points to a three-part construct [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. In consequence, where a firm makes a reference to the FS in its documentation, analysis, or communications, the PRA’s expectation is that the firm should treat that reference as engaging the full three-element definition and therefore consider all three elements together, rather than selecting only one or two elements, unless the context explicitly states otherwise [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. Practically, this requires the firm to check whether the particular reference to the FS is accompanied by any statement that narrows the scope; if no such limitation is stated, the firm should assume the reference is to the FS in its complete, three-element sense and ensure its work product reflects consideration of each element. This aligns the firm’s treatment of the FS with both the definitional structure (three elements) and the PRA’s stated expectation for how firms should interpret references to the FS in the absence of an express exception.

question: For compliance purposes, what is the defined structural composition of the FS, and what must a firm do with that structure whenever it makes a reference to the FS unless the reference expressly indicates a different approach?
gold_answer: The FS is structured as a concept with three elements, so the definition of the FS is inherently multi-part rather than singular [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. Building on that definition, the PRA expects that whenever a firm makes a reference to the FS, the firm should consider all three elements that make up the FS, treating the reference as encompassing the entire three-element structure unless it is stated otherwise in the relevant context [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. Accordingly, the firm’s compliance approach should be to interpret “FS” as shorthand for the complete three-element construct and to ensure that its assessment, explanation, or application addresses each element. Only where the firm can point to an explicit statement that modifies the scope of the reference should it depart from considering all three elements. This ensures that the firm’s use of the term “FS” remains consistent with the defined composition of the FS and with the PRA’s expectation about how firms should handle references to it.

question: If a firm mentions the FS, what does FS mean in terms of how many parts it has, and what does the PRA expect the firm to do with those parts unless the text says otherwise?
gold_answer: FS is defined as having three elements, so it is a three-part concept rather than a single item [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. Because of that definition, the PRA’s expectation is that when a firm makes a reference to the FS, the firm should consider all three elements of the FS together, not just one element, unless the relevant context clearly states otherwise [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. In practical terms, the firm should read any mention of “FS” as pointing to the full three-element structure and should ensure its work (for example, an internal assessment or an external explanation) reflects consideration of each element. The only time the firm should narrow its focus is when the reference itself includes an explicit statement that changes what is being covered. This approach keeps the firm aligned with both what FS is (three elements) and how the PRA expects firms to treat references to it (consider all three unless an exception is stated).

question: What are the key parts of the FS, and when a firm refers to the FS, does the PRA expect the firm to look at every part or only some of them?
gold_answer: The FS is described as having three elements, so the term “FS” refers to a set made up of three parts [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. Based on that, the PRA expects that where a firm makes a reference to the FS, the firm should consider all three elements of the FS, meaning the firm should not treat the FS as if it were only one element or an incomplete subset [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. The default position is therefore comprehensive: a reference to the FS should trigger consideration of every element that forms the FS. The only exception is where it is stated otherwise—i.e., where the context of the reference clearly indicates that the firm is not expected to apply all three elements. So, to comply with the PRA’s expectation, the firm should first recognize that FS is a three-element concept and then ensure that any reference to it is handled in a way that addresses all three elements unless an explicit limitation is stated.

question: When determining the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set, what must institutions do to identify the relevant equity reference entities for that netting set, and how does that identification relate to the calculation requirement?
gold_answer: Institutions have two linked obligations that apply to the same object (a netting set) and must be read together. First, for the purposes of paragraph 2, institutions shall establish the relevant equity reference entities of the netting set, doing so in accordance with the specified approach that follows in that provision [#SRC:a43b7a94ebe76894]. Second, for the purposes of Article 278, institutions shall calculate the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set, following the method set out in that provision [#TGT:0ebfaf3bc04a9c8f]. Practically, this means the calculation obligation under Article 278 is performed for a netting set whose relevant equity reference entities have been established under the paragraph 2 purpose statement, so the institution’s workflow must include (i) establishing the relevant equity reference entities for the netting set and (ii) calculating the equity risk category add-on for that same netting set. The explicit section reference that frames the calculation purpose is Article 278, and the actor responsible in both cases is institutions.

question: In a compliance framework for equity risk on netting sets, how shall institutions align the step of establishing relevant equity reference entities with the step of calculating the equity risk category add-on, given that each step is triggered by a different purpose clause?
gold_answer: The passages impose complementary, purpose-scoped duties on institutions that must be aligned in a single control process. Under the source obligation, for the purposes of paragraph 2, institutions shall establish the relevant equity reference entities of the netting set in accordance with the approach that follows [#SRC:a43b7a94ebe76894]. Under the target obligation, for the purposes of Article 278, institutions shall calculate the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set as specified [#TGT:0ebfaf3bc04a9c8f]. To align these, institutions should treat “establishing the relevant equity reference entities” as an upstream determination tied to the netting set, and “calculating the equity risk category add-on” as the downstream computation performed for that same netting set once the relevant equity reference entities have been established. The two purpose clauses indicate distinct regulatory hooks—paragraph 2 for the establishment step and Article 278 for the calculation step—so compliance documentation should evidence both: that the relevant equity reference entities were established for the netting set and that the equity risk category add-on was then calculated for that netting set under Article 278.

question: If institutions must calculate the equity risk category add-on for a netting set, what else must they do about the netting set’s equity reference entities, and how do these two requirements fit together?
gold_answer: Institutions must complete two connected tasks for the same netting set, each framed by a different purpose statement. One requirement is that, for the purposes of paragraph 2, institutions shall establish the relevant equity reference entities of the netting set, and they must do this in accordance with the approach that follows in that provision [#SRC:a43b7a94ebe76894]. The other requirement is that, for the purposes of Article 278, institutions shall calculate the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set, using the method set out there [#TGT:0ebfaf3bc04a9c8f]. Read together, this means the institution cannot treat the add-on calculation as detached from identifying what equity reference entities are relevant to the netting set: the netting set must have its relevant equity reference entities established (under the paragraph 2 purpose) and then the equity risk category add-on must be calculated for that netting set (under the Article 278 purpose). The concrete section label that must be reflected in the calculation context is Article 278, and the responsible actor in both obligations is institutions.

question: What must institutions do first for a netting set so they can properly calculate the equity risk category add-on, and which section is named for the calculation step?
gold_answer: Before institutions can carry out the required calculation for a netting set, they must ensure the netting set has been set up with the right equity reference information. Specifically, for the purposes of paragraph 2, institutions shall establish the relevant equity reference entities of the netting set in accordance with the approach that follows [#SRC:a43b7a94ebe76894]. Separately, for the purposes of Article 278, institutions shall calculate the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set as set out in that provision [#TGT:0ebfaf3bc04a9c8f]. These obligations fit together because both are about the same unit of analysis (the netting set): establishing the relevant equity reference entities is a required preparatory step tied to the netting set, and calculating the equity risk category add-on is the required computation performed for that netting set. The named section for the calculation step is Article 278, and institutions are the actor that must perform both the establishment and the calculation.

question: For compliance referencing purposes, how should an Authorised Person identify and locate the specific joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication that is cross-referenced as the first item in the list of joint publications, including where it is made available?
gold_answer: The SOURCE identifies a set of joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publications and indicates that the first listed publication is “A review of requirements for banks entering into or expanding in the banking sector (the 2013 report)”, followed by a cross-reference marker that distinguishes it from the subsequent “one year on” publication [#SRC:af42f23c6a6fad15]. The TARGET then provides the availability information for that same first cross-referenced item by specifying that it is available at a particular FCA web address, which functions as the retrieval location for the referenced publication [#TGT:f7d87ccbb522927b]. Read together, the SOURCE supplies the correct identification of the joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication within the list (i.e., the 2013 report as the first item), while the TARGET supplies the practical access point (the URL) for that specific cross-referenced entry. This combined approach supports accurate citation and document control by ensuring the correct joint publication is both named and locatable.

question: Which joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication is the first one listed, and where can you find it online?
gold_answer: The SOURCE lists joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publications and shows that the first one is “A review of requirements for banks entering into or expanding in the banking sector (the 2013 report)”, before it moves on to a separate “one year on” publication [#SRC:af42f23c6a6fad15]. The TARGET then tells you where the first listed item can be accessed by stating that it is available at a specific FCA webpage address [#TGT:f7d87ccbb522927b]. Using both passages together, you can (1) pick the correct document from the list—i.e., the initial 2013 report rather than the later follow-up—and (2) retrieve it using the online location provided. This pairing matters for basic compliance work because the SOURCE alone gives the titles but not the access details, while the TARGET alone gives the access link but not the full context of which joint publication in the list it corresponds to.

question: When an Applicant describes an instrument as common equity shares that are traded within a major stock index, how should that description be cross-referenced to the numbered example in the paired material, and what identifying marker must be carried through to maintain alignment between the two texts?
gold_answer: To keep the two texts aligned, the Applicant should treat the instrument description in the SOURCE—i.e., common equity shares that are traded within a major stock index—as the substantive classification anchor, and then explicitly map that classification to the corresponding numbered example presented in the TARGET. The key control is to preserve the shared identifying marker that appears in both passages, so the cross-reference is unambiguous and traceable across the pair. In practice, this means the Applicant should carry forward the same marker used in the SOURCE (“19”) when pointing to the TARGET’s numbered example (“19.”) and ensure the cross-reference is made at the level of the example rather than introducing a different label or renumbering. This approach maintains a consistent linkage between the SOURCE’s instrument description and the TARGET’s example framing, enabling reviewers to confirm that the described common equity shares traded within a major stock index are being referenced to the intended numbered item without relying on any additional context beyond the paired texts [#SRC:f05ed682c39fcd42] and [#TGT:8adf58c7c75b7bcd].

question: When a firm uses a sub-portfolio approach for calculating the MA and needs to decide where to reflect the additional FS allowance, how should it apply the procedure for assessing overall matching that involves splitting the relevant portfolio into components, and what options does it have for allocating that allowance across those components while still reflecting CoD and any LTAS floor elements of the FS?
gold_answer: In applying the method for assessing the overall level of matching, the firm should start by using the procedure that splits the relevant portfolio of assets into components, because that component structure provides the framework within which matching is evaluated [#TGT:2134ecf080d8fdd6]. Where, for the purpose of calculating the MA, the firm explicitly identifies the sub-portfolio of assets whose expected cash flows are used to demonstrate cash flow matching (the sub-portfolio approach), it is permitted to capture the additional FS allowance in either of two component groupings—component A assets or component B assets—provided those components also provision for the CoD and any LTAS floor components of the FS [#SRC:b30d9dd92d8ced93]. Practically, this means the firm should (i) perform the component split for the relevant portfolio as part of the overall matching assessment, (ii) identify the sub-portfolio used in the cash flow matching demonstration for MA purposes, and then (iii) choose whether the additional FS allowance is reflected within the component A or component B bucket, ensuring the chosen bucket is the one that also includes the required CoD and any LTAS floor elements.

question: If a firm is calculating the MA using a sub-portfolio approach, what steps should it follow to split the portfolio into components for the matching assessment, and where is it allowed to put the additional FS allowance within those components (taking into account CoD and any LTAS floor parts of the FS)?
gold_answer: The firm should use the matching-assessment method that begins by splitting the relevant portfolio of assets into components, because that is the stated procedure for assessing the overall level of matching [#TGT:2134ecf080d8fdd6]. Once that component structure is in place, and where the firm is calculating the MA using a sub-portfolio approach (meaning it explicitly identifies the sub-portfolio of assets whose expected cash flows are used to demonstrate cash flow matching), it has flexibility on how to reflect the additional FS allowance [#SRC:b30d9dd92d8ced93]. Specifically, the additional FS allowance may be captured in either the component A assets or the component B assets, but the firm must ensure that the component in which it captures the allowance is one that also provisions for the CoD and any LTAS floor components of the FS [#SRC:b30d9dd92d8ced93]. In sequence: split the portfolio into components for the overall matching assessment, identify the MA sub-portfolio used for the cash flow matching demonstration, then allocate the additional FS allowance to either component A or component B in a way that aligns with where CoD and any LTAS floor elements are provisioned.

question: In the context of an RFTS application, how should the term “applicant” be defined, and what procedural timetable must the court set for that applicant at a Directions hearing regarding public notification and the handling of written submissions from potentially adversely affected persons?
gold_answer: For an RFTS application, the “applicant” is defined as the transferor, the transferee, or both, where that party (or those parties) submits the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]. In procedural terms, a Directions hearing is the point at which the court sets out a timetable specifically for that applicant to carry out two linked steps: first, to notify the public of the RFTS application, and second, to receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. Read together, the definition identifies which entity is responsible for complying with the court-directed timetable, and the Directions hearing procedure clarifies the scope of what the timetable must cover—public notification and the receipt of written submissions from those claiming adverse impact. This means the applicant (as transferor/transferee/both) must be prepared to follow the court’s sequencing and timing for these communications and submissions as part of progressing the application to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e].

question: Who counts as the “applicant” for an RFTS application, and what does the court set a timetable for the applicant to do at a Directions hearing about telling the public and collecting written submissions from people who say they would be adversely affected?
gold_answer: The “applicant” for an RFTS application is usually the transferor, the transferee, or both, where that party (or those parties) is submitting the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]. When a Directions hearing takes place, the court sets out a timetable for that applicant to complete key steps connected to the application: the applicant must notify the public of the RFTS application and must receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. Putting these together, the definition tells you which party is responsible for acting (transferor/transferee/both), and the Directions hearing procedure tells you what the court’s timetable will cover (public notice and receiving written submissions) [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. In practice, the applicant should expect the court to sequence and time these actions so that public notification occurs and written submissions can be gathered from those who claim adverse effects before the application proceeds further [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e].

question: A TWD firm must be able to run sensitivity analysis on key assumptions. How should it use that analysis to show the range of impacts on capital and liquidity while still building its TWD capabilities on a full wind-down of its trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to conduct sensitivity analysis that measures how changing key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) affects outcomes, and it should use that capability to set out upper and lower bounds for those assumptions so senior management can see the range of plausible impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. At the same time, the firm should treat this sensitivity analysis as supporting work that sits within, and does not alter, the expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]. The sensitivity analysis capability should include the ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors that form part of the TWD scenario, and then vary assumptions around that baseline to quantify how projections move under different plausible conditions [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. In other words, the firm uses sensitivity analysis to stress and bound its wind-down planning assumptions, while keeping the overall capability design grounded in a full trading wind-down [#TGT:67153071a209f68a].

question: If the Merger Document includes the Schedule 16 Statement, what does the board have to say about any material financial changes since the period covered by the financial information, and what should it do if it cannot put a number on the impact?
gold_answer: When the Merger Document is being provided and it includes the Schedule 16 Statement (along with the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments), the board must deal with the fact that the financial information will cover a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Specifically, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim, so members have a clear, direct statement rather than assumptions [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. If there has been a change but the effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members at least know it has been identified and that it matters to their consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. This obligation sits within the broader requirement to provide the Merger Document including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1].

question: If K is meant to be the loan principal plus expected interest built up by time T, what do firms need to do for ERM loans when a borrower’s actions can change that K amount through principal or interest?
gold_answer: K is defined as the loan principal plus the expected accrued interest at time T, and it is to be calculated using the relevant principles referenced for that calculation [#SRC:f62ad92b67a510fd]. For ERM loans, if the value of K at time T depends on borrower behaviour that affects principal or interest, the PRA expects firms to follow the applicable principles for how K should be determined in that situation [#TGT:3683522dee3bbc3a]. Putting these together, firms should (1) identify K’s components at time T (principal and expected accrued interest), and (2) treat borrower-behaviour dependency as the condition that requires applying the PRA’s expected approach. The obligation is not just to label K correctly, but to calculate it in line with the principles when borrower behaviour can influence the principal or interest that make up K. This ensures the K figure used at time T reflects both the defined elements and the PRA’s expectation for ERM loans where borrower behaviour is relevant [#SRC:f62ad92b67a510fd] [#TGT:3683522dee3bbc3a].

question: When an institution is required to determine the potential future exposure for a netting set, how must it apply the defined concept of PFE and what action is it obliged to take to ensure the calculation is performed in the prescribed manner?
gold_answer: An institution must treat “PFE” as a defined term that refers specifically to the potential future exposure calculated in accordance with the referenced calculation framework, and it must then apply that defined meaning when performing its required calculation for a netting set. In practice, this means the institution cannot use an alternative or informal notion of potential future exposure when it is calculating the potential future exposure of a netting set; instead, it must align the calculation with the definition of PFE as “the potential future exposure calculated in accordance with” the specified reference [#SRC:564987096a7d6a76]. Consistently with that definition, the institution is obliged to carry out the calculation for the netting set using the prescribed approach, because the requirement is that “Institutions shall calculate the potential future exposure of a netting set” following the stated method [#TGT:992a256dbd55bc1c]. Read together, the definition fixes what “PFE” means (and therefore what “potential future exposure” must be for these purposes), while the obligation fixes who must do the calculation (Institutions) and the fact that it must be performed for a netting set using the specified method.

question: In the PRA’s procedure for assessing an application for authorisation as a third-country branch, how must the PRA sequence its evaluation so that the decision is demonstrably grounded in its statutory objectives, and what specific equivalence and supervision-related determinations must it reach before it can be satisfied with the application?
gold_answer: In handling an application from a firm for authorisation as a third-country branch, the PRA must apply an assessment procedure that is explicitly grounded in its statutory objectives and then work through the determinations it needs to be satisfied on as part of its assessment process [#TGT:611c096a35f50289]. Substantively, that procedure must include evaluating regulatory and supervisory equivalence (described as ‘supervisory equivalence’) and assessing ‘supervisability’, meaning the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer operating in the UK through a branch [#TGT:611c096a35f50289]. This aligns with the PRA’s broader approach to authorisation and supervision of third-country branches, which is likewise anchored in its statutory objectives and underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and supervisability [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]. In applying the procedure, the PRA should also treat the applicant as a third-country branch undertaking that, if operating in the UK, will be subject to the PRA’s rules relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings as set out in the PRA Rulebook, reinforcing that the assessment is tied to the PRA’s supervisory capability and the applicable rule framework [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501].

question: When the PRA considers whether it can be satisfied on a third-country branch application, how should the PRA connect its equivalence and ‘supervisability’ assessments to the ongoing authorisation-and-supervision framework that will apply to the third-country branch undertaking once operating in the UK?
gold_answer: The PRA’s application-assessment procedure for authorisation as a third-country branch requires it to be satisfied, as part of its assessment, on matters that include regulatory and supervisory equivalence (‘supervisory equivalence’) and ‘supervisability’—the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer operating in the UK through a branch [#TGT:611c096a35f50289]. Those determinations should be made in a way that is anchored in the PRA’s statutory objectives, because the PRA’s approach to both authorisation and supervision of third-country branches is framed by those objectives and is underpinned by the same equivalence and supervisability concepts [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]. Practically, connecting the application-stage findings to the post-authorisation framework means recognising that third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, as set out in the PRA Rulebook [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]. Accordingly, the PRA’s satisfaction on equivalence and supervisability in the application procedure should support its ability to supervise the branch effectively under the rule framework that will govern the undertaking once it operates in the UK, consistent with the statutory-objectives anchor stated in the procedure [#TGT:611c096a35f50289].

question: When the PRA reviews a firm’s application to become a third-country branch, what are the key checks it must make so the review is based on its statutory objectives, and how do those checks relate to the PRA’s ability to supervise the insurer once it operates in the UK through a branch?
gold_answer: When the PRA considers a firm’s application for authorisation as a third-country branch, it must run an assessment that is anchored in its statutory objectives and includes specific checks on regulatory and supervisory equivalence (called ‘supervisory equivalence’) and on ‘supervisability’, meaning whether the PRA can effectively supervise an insurer operating in the UK through a branch [#TGT:611c096a35f50289]. These checks are not standalone: they match the PRA’s wider approach to the authorisation and supervision of third-country branches, which is also anchored in its statutory objectives and is underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and supervisability [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]. The link to what happens after approval is that third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, as set out in the PRA Rulebook [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]. So, the application-stage procedure should test whether the PRA can supervise the insurer in practice and whether the supervisory context is sufficiently equivalent, because those points support the PRA’s ability to oversee the branch under the applicable PRA rules once it is operating in the UK [#TGT:611c096a35f50289].

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission, how must the firm determine the permissible range for the transitional deduction it applies, and how is the “maximum amount” defined for that purpose? Where the firm elects to apply less than that maximum, what disclosure and supervisory-sharing steps does the PRA expect, and how must the firm ensure consistency of this approach across its Solvency II reporting and governance materials?
gold_answer: For all firms with a TMTP permission, the firm must ensure the amount of the transitional deduction it applies sits within a defined range: it must be no less than zero and no more than the maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” for this purpose is defined as the maximum number derived either from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach set out in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm decides to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. In addition, the firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the TMTP benefit it is applying, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed consistently across all Solvency II reporting, including Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs), and to be reflected within the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].

question: If a firm has a TMTP permission, what does “maximum amount” mean when setting the transitional deduction, and what range must the firm stay within? If the firm uses less than the maximum, what does the PRA expect the firm to disclose and share, and where must the firm apply the same approach consistently?
gold_answer: A firm with a TMTP permission must apply a transitional deduction amount that is within a required range: it must be between zero and a maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” is defined as the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach described in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm chooses to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to (i) include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and (ii) share this information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. Beyond disclosure, the firm should keep its method for deciding the TMTP benefit transparent, and the PRA expects the firm to follow that method consistently across all Solvency II reporting, including Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs) [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The same approach should also be reflected in the firm’s ORSA and its risk management framework, so the firm’s reporting and governance materials align with how it determines and applies the deduction [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].

question: When you calculate the CET1 ratio, what goes on top and what goes on the bottom, and what does the rule mean when it says the exposure amount is the CRR ‘total risk exposure amount’?
gold_answer: Using both passages, the CET1 ratio is a simple ratio with a specified numerator and a denominator whose meaning is fixed by a separate definition. The SOURCE says the CET1 ratio is calculated as CET1 capital divided by risk-weighted assets [#SRC:4751cd1c8d385d48]. The TARGET adds that the relevant exposure amount is defined as the “total risk exposure amount,” and that this term must be understood as it is defined in the CRR [#TGT:5ef87f6cdf1558a3]. Put together, you calculate the ratio by placing CET1 capital in the numerator and using the risk/exposure measure in the denominator, but you should not interpret that denominator loosely: the exposure concept is anchored to the CRR’s definition of total risk exposure amount. This combined reading matters because it links the denominator used in the CET1 ratio calculation to a specific, externally defined exposure amount, rather than leaving it to a general description. The result is a CET1-capital-to-exposure calculation where the exposure side is tied to the CRR-defined total risk exposure amount.

question: Where one or more of the specified circumstances arise, is the FSCS permitted to postpone paying compensation beyond the standard time period, and is that permission limited to cases where those circumstances are present?
gold_answer: Yes. The scope trigger is that one or more of the specified circumstances must arise; that condition defines when the relevant framework applies and therefore when any related timing flexibility can be engaged [#SRC:815814104eb16d96]. In that same situation, the permission granted to the FSCS is that it may decide to defer the payment of compensation beyond the otherwise applicable time period, but only where the deferral condition is met—namely, where the relevant circumstances arise [#TGT:e7ff6bd16d34a149]. Read together, the SOURCE establishes the applicability boundary (the occurrence of one or more of the listed circumstances), and the TARGET provides the operational consequence within that boundary (a discretionary decision by the FSCS to defer payment beyond the standard period). Accordingly, absent the arising of at least one of those circumstances, the SOURCE does not indicate that the deferral condition is satisfied, and the TARGET’s permission to defer is not engaged; conversely, once the condition is met, the FSCS has discretion to defer rather than an obligation to do so.

question: When applying the European Banking Authority Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements, how does the PRA expect banks to use the version hosted on the PRA website, and how should banks treat the Supervisory Statement’s additional PRA requirements and expanded expectations (including on data security and business continuity/exit planning)?
gold_answer: Banks should start from the European Banking Authority (EBA) ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ as the baseline set of outsourcing guidelines, using the version made available via the PRA website, which hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period and provides access to the EBA Outsourcing GL. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] The PRA then expects banks to apply those EBA Outsourcing GL through the lens of the PRA’s own requirements and expectations, as clarified in the relevant Supervisory Statement. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] In practice, this means banks should not treat the EBA Outsourcing GL as a standalone document; they should read and implement it in the context of the PRA’s framework as articulated in the Supervisory Statement. The Supervisory Statement also indicates that certain chapters go beyond clarification by expanding on the expectations in the EBA Outsourcing GL, including in areas such as data security and business continuity and exit plans. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] Accordingly, banks should use the hosted EBA Outsourcing GL as the reference text while ensuring their outsourcing arrangements also meet the PRA’s clarified and expanded expectations described in the Supervisory Statement. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0]

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one important risk driver, and one of those drivers is linked to climatic conditions, what must institutions do to map the transaction to the right risk category or categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must map the transaction in a way that captures both the climatic-conditions rule and the rule for transactions with multiple material risk drivers. If the primary risk driver is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]. Also, because the transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions shall map it to more than one risk category when the drivers belong to different risk categories, mapping it once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If, instead, all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, institutions only need to map the transaction once to that single category, using the most material driver as the basis [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Putting these together: the presence of a climatic conditions variable as the primary driver (or as the most material driver within a risk category used for mapping) requires commodity mapping, and the multi-driver framework then determines whether additional mappings are required to other risk categories as well [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad].

question: For transactions within scope, how should a firm determine who falls within its relevant senior management population, and what external supervisory material should it consult to support its approach to individual accountability in banking?
gold_answer: For the purposes of the transactions in question, a firm should treat “relevant senior management” as a defined population that includes (a) any individuals performing Senior Management Functions (SMFs) who have oversight of those transactions and (b) any employees who are subject to the Certification Regime and are involved in the transactions, including relevant Material Risk Takers (MRTs) under the Remuneration rules. This means the identification exercise is not limited to SMF holders; it must also capture certified staff who participate in the transactions, with particular attention to those whose roles align with MRT status under remuneration requirements. To support and evidence its approach to strengthening individual accountability in banking, the firm should also refer to the Bank of England Prudential Regulation Authority’s Supervisory Statement SS 28/15, “Strengthening Individual Accountability in Banking,” as the cited supervisory material available online [#TGT:b4a4d930ae66ef1e], alongside applying the transaction-specific definition of relevant senior management described in the source definition [#SRC:3035bf91c8e1c057].

question: When your firm is working on these transactions, who counts as relevant senior management, and which Bank of England supervisory statement should you look at for guidance on individual accountability in banking?
gold_answer: For these transactions, your firm should treat “relevant senior management” as a practical list of people that includes two groups: first, any individuals performing Senior Management Functions (SMFs) who have oversight of the transactions; and second, any employees who are subject to the Certification Regime and are involved in the transactions, including relevant Material Risk Takers (MRTs) under the Remuneration rules. In other words, you should not stop at identifying only the SMF holders—your scope must also include certified staff who take part in the transactions, and you should consider whether any of those individuals are MRTs for remuneration purposes. To anchor this identification and accountability approach in supervisory material, you should consult the Bank of England Prudential Regulation Authority’s Supervisory Statement SS 28/15, “Strengthening Individual Accountability in Banking,” which is referenced as being available online [#TGT:b4a4d930ae66ef1e]. Apply that supervisory reference together with the definition of relevant senior management provided for these transactions [#SRC:3035bf91c8e1c057].

question: For a firm, what is the scope of the PRA’s expectations on managing and monitoring a solvent exit, and how does that scope align with the point at which a solvent exit execution plan must be produced and then applied during execution?
gold_answer: Across the SS and the Chapter, the PRA’s expectations on how a firm should manage and monitor a solvent exit are scoped to the period when solvent exit has moved beyond BAU preparation and into execution planning and execution itself. In the SS, the PRA distinguishes between (i) BAU preparations for an orderly solvent exit, including producing a solvent exit analysis, and (ii) the point at which solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, at which time the firm is expected to produce a solvent exit execution plan and to manage and monitor the execution of the solvent exit. This frames the applicability boundary: management and monitoring expectations are tied to execution, not merely preparatory BAU activity [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. The Chapter then narrows and confirms the same scope by stating that its expectations apply specifically when a solvent exit execution plan is needed and during the firm’s execution of a solvent exit, covering both the trigger condition (need for the plan) and the execution phase itself [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f]. Read together, the expectations apply once the execution plan is required and continue through the execution period, rather than applying solely to earlier BAU preparation steps.

question: When do the PRA’s expectations in this Chapter apply to a firm, and how does that connect to the SS’s point that the firm must manage and monitor the solvent exit once an execution plan is needed?
gold_answer: The Chapter’s scope is limited to the period when a solvent exit execution plan is needed and the period when the firm is actually carrying out the solvent exit. In other words, it is not framed as applying to all BAU preparation work; it applies at the point the execution plan becomes necessary and then throughout execution [#TGT:295c30baa6788d7f]. The SS explains how this boundary is reached: it sets expectations for both preparation and execution, but it separates BAU preparation (including producing a solvent exit analysis) from the later stage when solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect. At that later stage, the PRA expects the firm to produce a solvent exit execution plan and also expects the firm to manage and monitor the execution of the solvent exit [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. Putting both together, the Chapter’s expectations are meant to operate in the same window described in the SS: once the execution plan is required (because solvent exit is a reasonable prospect) and continuing during the execution itself, including the firm’s management and monitoring of that execution.

question: When responding to a request from the PRA or any other relevant competent authority for information needed to supervise compliance of outsourced activities, how must a third country branch meet that obligation where the branch and the service provider are members of the same group and the branch may assess the degree of control or influence it has over the service provider’s actions?
gold_answer: A third country branch must be able to provide, on request, all information necessary for the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise whether the performance of outsourced activities complies with the requirements of the regulatory system [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]. Where the third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch is permitted, for the relevant purposes, to take into account the extent to which it controls the service provider or has the ability to influence the service provider’s actions [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47]. In practice, this means the branch should not treat group membership as reducing the information it must be able to make available; rather, it may use its control or influence assessment to inform how it ensures the requested information can be obtained and provided. The branch should therefore be prepared to explain, consistently with its control/influence position, how it can access and deliver the information needed for supervisory review of outsourced activities, including where the service provider’s actions are shaped by the branch’s control or influence within the group structure.

question: For compliance documentation, how should an institution identify the EBA guidance that sets a minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, and where should it direct readers to access the authoritative version online?
gold_answer: An institution should identify the relevant guidance by naming it as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” ensuring the reference clearly ties the document to recovery plan indicators and the minimum qualitative and quantitative set expected under that guidance [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. In the same compliance documentation (e.g., a recovery planning policy, indicator framework, or internal governance memo), it should also provide an access point to the authoritative online location by directing readers to the EBA webpage where the guidelines are made available, using the provided “Available at” link to the EBA site [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Taken together, this approach both (i) specifies the exact EBA guidelines being relied upon for the minimum list of recovery plan indicators and (ii) enables reviewers, auditors, and supervisors to retrieve the current official version from the EBA’s published source. This pairing supports traceability between the named guidelines and the official online publication location, reducing ambiguity about which EBA recovery indicator guidance is being applied.

question: If you need to cite the EBA document about the minimum qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, what is the document called and where can someone find it online?
gold_answer: You should cite the document by its name as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” which makes clear that it covers both qualitative and quantitative indicators and that it is focused on recovery plan indicators and a minimum list [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. To help someone actually locate the official text, you should also include the online location where it is available by pointing to the EBA webpage indicated as the access source, i.e., the “Available at” link to the EBA site hosting the guidelines [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Using both elements together in your citation or internal reference note ensures that readers understand exactly which EBA guidelines you mean and have a direct route to retrieve the authoritative version from the EBA’s own publication page. This is especially useful when sharing recovery planning materials internally or with reviewers, because it links the named guidelines to the official online source.

question: To support transparency in the regulatory regime and implement the outcome referenced in the government’s Solvency II review response, what reporting must the PRA produce on the MA framework, what specific metrics must it cover, and when must the first publication occur?
gold_answer: The PRA is expected to publish regular reports on the MA framework as a transparency measure within the regulatory regime, and this reporting is explicitly framed as implementing the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review 15 [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. The cross-reference for that outcome is identified in the government material as Paragraph 1.17 of the ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3], which anchors the policy context for the PRA’s reporting commitment. The reports must be published alongside the PRA Annual Report and must cover two concrete content elements: (i) application review timelines and (ii) decision rates, so that stakeholders can see both how long reviews take and how frequently decisions are made [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. The first report has a specified timing requirement: it is to be published in 2025 [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. Taken together, the PRA’s obligation is not merely to report periodically, but to do so in a defined publication channel (alongside the PRA Annual Report), with defined metrics, and with an initial delivery date tied to the 2025 milestone, in line with the Paragraph 1.17 cross-referenced outcome [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3].

question: What does the PRA need to publish about the MA framework to improve transparency, and how does this link to the government’s Solvency II consultation response reference?
gold_answer: The PRA must publish regular reports on the MA framework as part of promoting transparency in the regulatory regime, and it states that this is to implement the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review 15 [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. The related government reference that links to this outcome is Paragraph 1.17 of the ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3], which is the specific paragraph cited as the relevant cross-reference. In practical terms, the PRA’s reports are not standalone publications: they must be issued alongside the PRA Annual Report [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. The reports must also include specific information so readers can track how the MA framework is working in practice—namely, they must cover application review timelines and decision rates [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. There is also a clear timing detail for implementation: the first report is to be published in 2025 [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4]. So, the obligation is defined by what is published (regular MA framework reports), where it is published (alongside the PRA Annual Report), what it contains (timelines and decision rates), and when it starts (2025), with the policy linkage anchored to Paragraph 1.17 in the government consultation response [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3].

question: When a firm is a member of a group whose parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is treated as an overseas jurisdiction for insurance group supervision, how does that affect whether the firm must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems comply with the Operational Resilience obligations, and are any group provisions disapplied in that scenario?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group that falls within the group categories that trigger the requirement, the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (noting the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3)) [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19]. However, the scope text also creates a conditional disapplication: where the firm is a member of a group covered by the specified group coverage condition, certain provisions (22.2, 22.3 and 22.4) do not apply if the third country in which the group’s parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated for insurance group supervision and the stated condition about the IRPR regulations applies [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8].
