Together, these materials can help a firm demonstrate that intragroup arrangements and dependencies are understood and documented while the ring-fenced body still adheres to the arm’s length transaction requirement [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c].

question: If a ring-fenced body does a deal with a group company that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, what must it do to keep the deal on arm’s length terms, and what existing compliance work may the firm reuse (including OCIR record-keeping) to document intragroup dependencies and show the PRA the information if asked?
gold_answer: The ring-fenced body must make sure that any transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate is entered into only on arm’s length terms, meaning the terms should be set as they would be between independent parties rather than being influenced by group relationships [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c]. At the same time, where relevant, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations for intragroup outsourcing arrangements; for some banks, those arrangements may already be subject to requirements in Operational Continuity and in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook, and compliance with those requirements may also mean the banks meet certain expectations in the supervisory statement for intragroup outsourcing (including expectations linked to business continuity and exit plans) [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. The PRA also expects firms to consider using elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, as long as the information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. Using these existing materials can support how the firm evidences its intragroup arrangements while still meeting the arm’s length transaction obligation [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c].

question: Where a firm uses an internal model and is required to provide supporting narrative documentation, what must it submit to the PRA on an annual basis, what content must that submission cover, and how does the firm’s discretion over format apply to the supporting narrative material?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model has an annual reporting obligation to submit to the PRA the AoC.01 template that sets out the required analysis of change. That annual submission must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, and it must be prepared in line with the applicable instructions for the AoC.01 template. In addition to completing and submitting the AoC.01 template annually, the firm is also required to submit supporting narrative documentation connected to these reporting requirements. While the AoC.01 template content and instructions govern what must be provided in the annual template submission, the firm has discretion to choose the format in which it provides the supporting narrative documentation, provided it is submitted as required. Taken together, the obligations mean the firm must (i) deliver the annual AoC.01 analysis-of-change package to the PRA with the specified quantitative and qualitative components, and (ii) provide the associated supporting narrative documentation in a format of its choosing, as part of meeting the overall reporting expectations. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3]

question: For assets with contractually bounded but uncertain timing of cash flows, how should a firm determine whether it may treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and what portfolio-level limit applies to the MA benefit created by that HP cash flow proportion?
gold_answer: Where a firm is considering assets whose cash-flow timing is uncertain but bounded (eg, where redemption or repayment timing can vary within contractual bounds), the firm should assess whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and can be demonstrated not to present a material risk to the quality of matching. In the SS, assets that meet the relevant criteria and for which firms can demonstrate no material risk to matching quality are defined as “assets with HP cash flows” [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. The SOURCE indicates that, if the assets meet the HP cash flow criteria, firms may include them in the MA portfolio as part of a limited proportion permitted for such assets, rather than relying solely on a case-by-case assessment against the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. In applying this permission, the firm must also observe the aggregate portfolio constraint: the proportion of the MA portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].

question: If a firm has assets where the cash-flow timing is not certain but is still within a contractual range, when can it treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and how much MA benefit can that HP cash flow slice create overall?
gold_answer: If a firm holds assets with cash flows whose timing is uncertain but bounded (for example, where redemption or the start of repayments can vary within a contractually bounded period), the firm should consider whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and, if they do, it may include them in the MA portfolio within the limited proportion allowed for such assets [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The TARGET explains what “assets with HP cash flows” means in this SS: they are the assets meeting the relevant criteria that firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. This definition matters because it is the trigger for the portfolio treatment described in the SOURCE (including them as part of the permitted limited proportion) rather than only seeking case-by-case assessment under the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The firm must also apply the portfolio-level cap described in the TARGET: in aggregate, the proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and it may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate added risks [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].

question: When a large subsidiary of a UK parent institution, a UK parent financial holding company or a UK parent mixed financial holding company is preparing its required disclosures, how must it align the required article-based disclosures (including the leverage-ratio-related disclosure duty) with the requirement to disclose leverage ratio information and excessive leverage risk management, and at what level must those disclosures be made?
gold_answer: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, as well as large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country, have a duty to disclose specified information by reference to a set of Articles, and they must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. In parallel, Institutions have a specific obligation to disclose information regarding their leverage ratio and their management of the risk of excessive leverage, with the leverage ratio being calculated in accordance with Article 429 of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part [#TGT:01b09661643bb171]. Read together, the disclosure package for an in-scope large subsidiary must include the leverage-ratio-related information required of Institutions (including the Article 429 calculation basis and the related risk-management information) while also meeting the broader article-specified disclosure set applicable to those large subsidiaries, and the entity must ensure the disclosures are presented at the required level (individual or sub-consolidated) rather than assuming a different reporting perimeter [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:01b09661643bb171].

question: If an Institution is also a large subsidiary of a UK parent institution (or similar parent), what must it disclose about its leverage ratio and excessive leverage risk, and can it make those disclosures at the individual or sub-consolidated level?
gold_answer: An Institution must disclose information about its leverage ratio and how it manages the risk of excessive leverage, and the leverage ratio it reports must be calculated in accordance with Article 429 of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part [#TGT:01b09661643bb171]. Separately, large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies (and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country) must disclose the information specified in a list of Articles, and they are expressly permitted/required to make those disclosures either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. Putting these together for an entity that is both an Institution and an in-scope large subsidiary, the leverage ratio disclosure (including the Article 429 calculation basis) and the disclosure about managing excessive leverage risk must be included as part of its required disclosures, and the entity may present the disclosures at the level allowed for large subsidiaries—individual or sub-consolidated—rather than being limited to only one perimeter [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:01b09661643bb171].

question: For which firms does the chapter on the PRA’s expectations for report content and format apply, and how does that scope align with the obligation to submit reports periodically and publish a periodic summary, including how firms should determine the relevant timing?
gold_answer: The chapter applies to a firm’s report that is required under the rules’ reporting requirement, because it is expressly framed as setting out the PRA’s expectations for the content and format of that required report [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c]. In practical compliance terms, this means that any firm that must submit reports periodically under the relevant reporting requirement must use this chapter to shape what it submits (content) and how it presents it (format), while separately meeting the obligation to publish a summary of that report periodically under the disclosure requirement [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8]. The scope is therefore limited to the report itself (and not the summary), but it is directly connected to the periodic submission obligation because it governs the report that must be produced for submission. Firms should not infer fixed dates from the chapter; instead, they should follow the PRA’s process for timing, as the PRA will communicate the expected dates for firms’ submission and disclosure in advance, covering both the report submission and the summary publication cycles [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8].

question: Who needs to follow this chapter’s guidance on what goes into the report and how it should look, if the firm must send reports regularly and also publish a regular summary? How will the firm know when to submit and publish?
gold_answer: A firm needs to follow this chapter when it is preparing the report that it is required to produce under the rules’ reporting requirement, because the chapter is specifically about the PRA’s expectations for the content and format of that required report [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c]. That connects directly to the broader obligation on firms to submit reports periodically, since the chapter tells the firm what the PRA expects the submitted report to contain and how it should be structured or presented [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8]. At the same time, the firm has a separate but related obligation to publish a summary of that report periodically under the disclosure requirement; the chapter’s scope is the report itself, but the firm should treat the report and summary as linked deliverables because the summary is of the same report that is being submitted [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8]. For timing, the firm should not guess dates from the chapter; the PRA will communicate the expected dates for both submission and disclosure in advance, and firms should plan their reporting and summary publication around those communicated dates [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8].

question: If a firm holds assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, what must it do to find all the cash flow timing/amount uncertainties and make sure the extra risks from cash flow variability are properly covered in the FS, and what does the PRA expect the firm to write down?
gold_answer: If a firm includes assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, it must recognise that these assets are likely to add extra risk and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required to provision for those additional risks [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. The firm must also identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for those uncertainties, so that the FS outcome reflects the full set of relevant uncertainties rather than only a subset [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. Alongside this, the firm should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, using the guidance referenced in the source passage to support that assessment [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. The PRA expects the firm to document the details of the sources of uncertainty it has identified and to document how it has allowed for them, providing a clear record that the FS increases and other FS additions are grounded in the firm’s identified variability and uncertainty drivers [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121].

question: In the context of a resolution strategy that applies resolution powers to multiple entities within a group, what impediment can arise from inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the group associated to a global booking model, and what must the bank do to mitigate it, including in its contingency planning for winding down trading books?
gold_answer: Where the bank operates a global booking model, the key concern under an MPE resolution strategy is that the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the wider group associated to that global booking can become an impediment to resolution that the bank should address [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d]. This obligation is specifically triggered in an MPE context, which is defined as a resolution strategy that envisages applying resolution powers to multiple entities within a group [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459]. Because MPE involves action across multiple group entities, the bank should treat cross-entity linkages created or reinforced by the booking model as a potential barrier to executing resolution and should take steps to reduce or manage that barrier. In addition, the PRA expects the bank’s contingency plans for winding down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion—plans that support an orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy—to have fully taken into account the particular booking model adopted by the bank [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d]. Accordingly, addressing the impediment is not limited to structural considerations; it must also be reflected in practical wind-down planning that is aligned to the MPE strategy definition [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459].

question: If the bank is using an MPE resolution strategy (one that applies resolution powers to multiple entities in a group), what problem can a global booking model create, and what should the bank do about it in its trading book wind-down plans?
gold_answer: Under an MPE approach, the bank should focus on how a global booking model can create inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the wider group associated to that global booking, because that inter-connectivity could be an impediment to resolution that the bank should address [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d]. This is specifically relevant when the strategy is MPE, which is defined as a resolution strategy that envisages applying resolution powers to multiple entities within a group [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459]. In practical terms, because MPE contemplates resolution actions across more than one group entity, the bank should identify and manage the added complexity and barriers that arise from those cross-entity connections created by the booking model. Separately, the PRA expects that contingency plans to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion—plans that support an orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy—will have fully taken into account the particular booking model adopted by the bank [#SRC:9fcb3c210c05859d]. So, the bank should not only address the MPE-related impediment structurally, but also ensure its wind-down contingency planning reflects the realities of the chosen booking model in an MPE setting [#TGT:ec6dce35a155a459].

question: How should a branch evidence that its organisational arrangements are both comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of its business, and where should it look for the PRA’s further expectations that apply specifically to systemic wholesale branches?
gold_answer: A branch should structure and document its organisational arrangements so they are comprehensive in coverage while remaining proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of its business, because the PRA expects this baseline standard to apply across all branches [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. In practice, that means the branch should be able to demonstrate that its arrangements are sufficiently complete for its activities, but not unnecessarily burdensome relative to its business profile, and that it has considered how its own scale and complexity affect what “proportionate” looks like. Where the branch is a systemic wholesale branch, it should also recognise that the PRA has additional expectations beyond the all-branches baseline [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. To identify and apply those additional expectations, the branch should refer to the supervisory statement indicated in the cross-reference, which directs readers to SS4/16 on internal governance of third-country branches [#TGT:88729e1f70d7220c]. The branch should therefore align its governance approach to both the general PRA expectation for all branches and the further, systemic wholesale-specific expectations set out in that referenced material.

question: What does the PRA expect from a branch’s organisational arrangements so they are complete but still proportionate to its business, and where can you find the extra expectations for systemic wholesale branches?
gold_answer: The PRA expects a branch to have organisational arrangements that are comprehensive, but also proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of the branch’s business [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. For a compliance analyst, this means you should check that the branch’s arrangements cover what is needed for how it operates (comprehensive), while also being sized appropriately for what it does (proportionate), taking into account how big, complex, and wide-ranging the business is. The same baseline expectation applies to all branches, but the PRA also states that it has additional expectations for systemic wholesale branches, so you should not assume the all-branches standard is the full set of expectations for that type of branch [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. To locate those additional expectations, use the cross-reference provided, which points you to SS4/16 on internal governance of third-country branches [#TGT:88729e1f70d7220c]. In other words, assess proportionality and completeness against the general PRA expectation, then consult the referenced SS4/16 for the systemic wholesale branch-specific additions.

question: When assessing whether risks are sufficiently addressed, how should an Applicant determine that the relevant risks are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, and how should it treat a case where the risk of a local entity is mitigated at the group level through group-level risk management processes or internal control mechanisms?
gold_answer: An Applicant should treat the assessment as a two-part determination: first, whether the risks in question are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework, and second, whether they are mitigated by other means that achieve a comparable risk-reducing effect [#SRC:38e88c1cbf288dce]. In applying the “other means” limb, the Applicant should recognize that mitigation can occur beyond the local entity itself, including at the group level, where group-level risk management processes or internal control mechanisms are established and operate to reduce the risk exposure of the local entity [#TGT:7a8270fc93e6d439]. Practically, this implies the Applicant should document (i) how the risk based capital framework addresses the relevant risk drivers, and (ii) where reliance is placed on “other means,” how the group-level processes or controls are designed, implemented, and maintained to mitigate the local entity’s risk. The conclusion that a risk is “already mitigated” should therefore be supported either by the capital framework’s effect or by evidence that group-level governance and controls provide effective mitigation for the local entity.

question: If a local entity’s risk is reduced by group-level risk management or internal controls, can that count as being mitigated “by other means” instead of through the risk based capital framework, and what should the Applicant check to support that view?
gold_answer: Yes. The Applicant can treat group-level risk management processes or internal control mechanisms as a form of mitigation “by other means,” provided they actually reduce the risk faced by the local entity and therefore support the conclusion that the risk is already mitigated [#TGT:7a8270fc93e6d439]. This fits alongside the alternative route where risks are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework [#SRC:38e88c1cbf288dce]. To support this view, the Applicant should check and record which risks are being addressed, whether the mitigation is achieved through the capital framework or through other means, and—where relying on group-level arrangements—how those group-level processes or controls operate in practice to mitigate the local entity’s risk. The Applicant should also ensure the explanation clearly links the group-level mechanisms to the specific local risk being mitigated, so it is evident why the risk can be treated as already mitigated either through the capital framework or through the group-level “other means.”

question: Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, at what level must the group solvency calculation be performed, and how does the scope rule requiring certain provisions to apply with any necessary changes affect the application of those requirements at that level, including where the relevant holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar?
gold_answer: Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, the group’s solvency calculation must be carried out at the level of that insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, and it must be done by applying the specified set of requirements referenced for that calculation [#TGT:bfadda41c802247a]. In parallel, the scope provision establishes that, when its stated trigger condition is met, a defined package of provisions (including External Audit requirements) applies “with any necessary changes” at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, and it expressly contemplates application at that level even where the holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, as well as in relation to third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, subject to an “unless” carve-out [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Read together, the obligation fixes the calculation level at the holding company, while the scope rule clarifies that the relevant supporting provisions are adapted to operate at that same level, within the stated territorial and entity-type boundaries and any applicable exception.

question: If Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiaries of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, where must the group solvency calculation be done, and do the rules that apply “with any necessary changes” also apply at that holding company level even if it is not based in the UK or Gibraltar?
gold_answer: If Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, the solvency of the group must be calculated at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, using the set of requirements identified for that calculation [#TGT:bfadda41c802247a]. The separate scope provision then explains how other related requirements are meant to operate at that same level: when its stated condition is met, it applies a specified range of provisions (including External Audit provisions) “with any necessary changes” at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. It also makes clear that this adapted, holding-company-level application is contemplated even where the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, and it also references third country insurance undertaking and third country reinsurance undertaking, while indicating there is an exception introduced by an “unless” clause [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Together, these passages mean the calculation is anchored at the holding company level, and the surrounding requirements are intended to be applied at that level in an adjusted way, within the stated scope limits.

question: If you are working out NMCR (linear,gi) for general insurance business, what does NMCR (linear,gi) mean and what must the notional linear minimum capital requirement be equal to?
gold_answer: NMCR (linear,gi) is the term used to denote the notional linear general insurance minimum capital requirement for general insurance business, and it is described as the prescribed requirement for that business [#SRC:2bacc9c08c975647]. Once you are calculating that requirement, the rule is mandatory about how it is expressed: the notional linear minimum capital requirement for general insurance business must be set equal to the items that are listed immediately after the statement introducing the calculation [#TGT:923a989e2d2555f8]. In other words, the definition tells you that NMCR (linear,gi) is the name of the prescribed notional linear minimum capital requirement for general insurance business, and the obligation tells you that this requirement cannot be left as a standalone concept—it must be equated to the specified following elements in the rule [#SRC:2bacc9c08c975647] [#TGT:923a989e2d2555f8].

question: For a branch seeking supervision and authorisation under the past version of the additional considerations framework, what risk management policies and procedures must the branch have in place, and what evidence will the PRA expect to review for a systemic wholesale branch, including whether firm-wide documentation can be relied upon?
gold_answer: Under the past version of the additional considerations framework for the supervision and authorisation of branches, a branch should have in place an adequate risk management framework that is established, implemented, and maintained, with policies and procedures that include effective risk assessment processes. Those processes should identify risks arising from the branch’s activities, processes, and systems, and, where appropriate, articulate the branch’s risk appetite or the level of risk the branch is prepared to tolerate [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. In that same supervisory and authorisation context, for systemic wholesale branches the PRA will expect to see evidence that these arrangements exist and will seek to understand the firm’s policies governing the nature and amount of risk associated with business undertaken through the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. The PRA can obtain this understanding either by reviewing policies written specifically at the branch level or by reviewing firm-wide policies, provided those firm-wide policies identify how the branch’s risks are to be managed [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. This expectation is framed as part of the past version of the additional considerations applicable before 20/05/2025 [#TGT:a4124945f86f0647].

question: In applying the past version of the additional considerations for branch supervision and authorisation, how should a branch demonstrate that its risk assessment procedures adequately identify branch-specific risks and, where relevant, define risk tolerance, and what documentation pathways does the PRA accept for systemic wholesale branches?
gold_answer: When applying the past version of the additional considerations for the supervision and authorisation of branches, a branch should be able to demonstrate that it has established, implemented, and maintained adequate risk management policies and procedures that include effective risk assessment procedures. These procedures should identify risks connected to the branch’s activities, processes, and systems, and, where appropriate, set out the branch’s risk appetite or the level of risk tolerated by the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. For systemic wholesale branches in particular, the PRA will expect evidence of these arrangements and will want to understand the firm’s policies governing the nature and amount of risk associated with business undertaken through the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. The PRA indicates that it can reach this understanding through two acceptable documentation routes: policies written at the branch level, or policies written for the firm as a whole, so long as those firm-wide policies identify how the branch’s risks are to be managed [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. This evidencing approach should be aligned to the past version of the additional considerations framework applicable before 20/05/2025 [#TGT:a4124945f86f0647].

question: Under the past version of the additional considerations for branch supervision and authorisation, what does a branch need to do to manage risk properly, and what will the PRA look for if the branch is a systemic wholesale branch?
gold_answer: In the past version of the additional considerations for the supervision and authorisation of branches, a branch should have adequate risk management policies and procedures that it establishes, implements, and maintains. These should include effective risk assessment procedures that identify the risks linked to the branch’s activities, processes, and systems, and, where appropriate, set the branch’s risk appetite or the level of risk the branch is willing to tolerate [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. If the branch is a systemic wholesale branch, the PRA will expect to see evidence that these arrangements exist and will want to understand the firm’s policies that govern the nature and amount of risk connected to business undertaken through the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. The PRA can do this by reviewing policies written specifically for the branch, or by reviewing policies written for the firm as a whole, as long as those firm-wide policies explain how the branch’s risks are to be managed [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. These expectations are tied to the past version of the additional considerations framework that applied before 20/05/2025 [#TGT:a4124945f86f0647].

question: If a branch uses firm-wide risk policies instead of branch-only documents, when will the PRA accept that under the past version of the additional considerations for branch supervision and authorisation, and what must those policies cover?
gold_answer: Under the past version of the additional considerations for the supervision and authorisation of branches, a branch should establish, implement, and maintain adequate risk management policies and procedures, including effective risk assessment procedures that identify risks arising from the branch’s activities, processes, and systems. Where appropriate, the framework should also set the branch’s risk appetite or the level of risk tolerated by the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. For systemic wholesale branches, the PRA will expect evidence of these arrangements and will want to understand the firm’s policies governing the nature and amount of risk associated with business undertaken through the branch [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. The PRA will accept firm-wide policies as an alternative to branch-level policies, but only where those firm-wide policies identify how the branch’s risks are to be managed, so that the PRA can see how branch-specific risks are addressed within the broader firm framework [#SRC:33330dafdf11715e]. This acceptance and the related evidencing expectation sit within the past version of the additional considerations applicable before 20/05/2025 [#TGT:a4124945f86f0647].

question: When a credit union undertakes an additional activity or provides an additional service of the kind described in the relevant chapters, is it permitted to hold an investment, and what compliance condition must be satisfied before doing so?
gold_answer: The SOURCE defines the relevant trigger as an “additional activity carried out” or an “additional service provided” by a credit union, limited to those additional activities or services that are described in the specified parts of the framework (including the referenced chapter) [#SRC:addcc036bf114cd9]. The TARGET then sets out a permission that applies to a credit union in that regulatory context: the credit union may hold an investment, but only on the condition that it first meets the stated compliance requirement. In other words, where the credit union’s conduct falls within the defined category of additional activity or additional service, the ability to hold an investment is not automatic; it is conditional. Specifically, the credit union is permitted to hold an investment only if it complies with the identified compliance provision, and the permission is framed as “may” rather than “must,” indicating discretion once the condition is met [#TGT:14b9f67e8bc5eebb]. Accordingly, a credit union should (i) confirm that the activity/service it is undertaking is within the defined additional activity/service category, and (ii) ensure it satisfies the compliance condition before relying on the permission to hold the investment.

question: If a credit union is doing an extra activity or offering an extra service that falls within the described categories, can it hold an investment, and what does it need to do first?
gold_answer: The SOURCE explains what counts as the relevant “extra” conduct: it is an additional activity carried out or an additional service provided by a credit union, but only where that additional activity or service is one of the types described in the listed parts of the framework (including the referenced chapter) [#SRC:addcc036bf114cd9]. The TARGET then answers the permission question about investments: a credit union is allowed to hold an investment, but only if it meets a specific precondition. That precondition is compliance with the identified requirement; the permission is expressly conditional on that compliance step being satisfied first [#TGT:14b9f67e8bc5eebb]. Put simply, if the credit union’s conduct fits the definition of an additional activity or additional service, it can rely on the investment-holding permission only after it has ensured it complies with the stated compliance provision. The practical sequence is: classify the activity/service under the SOURCE definition, then confirm compliance with the TARGET’s condition, and only then proceed to hold the investment under the permission.

question: When assessing whether planned dividend payments are appropriate, what must insurers be able to demonstrate about the relationship to business performance and capital position, and how should that assessment be applied to distributions to capital providers such as returns of premiums to members of a mutual or loans to a parent or holding company?
gold_answer: Insurers should treat the appropriateness assessment for planned dividend payments as a demonstrable, evidence-based linkage between the proposed payment and the insurer’s actual and projected business performance, alongside its current and future capital position, explicitly taking account of the insurer’s documented risk appetite, as the PRA expects [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469]. That same assessment should not be limited to dividends in a narrow sense; it should be applied to distributions to any capital providers, including scenarios such as a return of premiums to the members of a mutual and the provision of a loan to a parent or holding company, because these are included within the scope of distributions that would be assessed [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]. In practice, this means the insurer should be able to show, for each planned distribution type, how the payment aligns with performance expectations and does not undermine capital resilience on both a current and forward-looking basis, and that the decision is consistent with the risk appetite framework that the insurer has documented.

question: If an insurer plans to pay a dividend, what does it need to show about how appropriate the payment is, and does the same kind of check also cover things like returning premiums to mutual members or making a loan to a parent or holding company?
gold_answer: An insurer needs to be able to demonstrate that any planned dividend payment is appropriate when set against both (i) the insurer’s actual and projected business performance and (ii) the insurer’s current and future capital position, and it must do so while taking account of its documented risk appetite, because that is what the PRA expects when assessing potential dividend payments [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469]. The same kind of assessment is not confined to dividends alone: it would also include the assessment made for distributions to any capital providers, which explicitly covers examples such as a return of premiums to the members of a mutual and a loan to a parent or holding company [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]. So, when the insurer considers any of these distribution forms, it should apply the same appropriateness logic—linking the proposed outflow to performance and capital impacts, and checking consistency with the risk appetite it has documented—so the rationale is coherent across different ways value might be transferred to capital providers.

question: When business is transferred from a firm using the legacy approach to a TMTP method firm, what must the transferee and transferor do to update ‘Z A’, ‘Z B’ and ‘C 0’, and how does the two‑month deadline from the effective date of the transfer event apply to those actions?
gold_answer: In a transfer where a firm using the legacy approach transfers business to a TMTP method firm, the PRA expects the transferee to update ‘Z A’, ‘Z B’ and ‘C 0’ using the transferor’s TMTP immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction, and then to update those parameters again in accordance with the referenced update process. The transferee also needs to designate MA-eligible business for calculating the dynamic portion, and the transferor should split the TMTP into (i) the risk margin portion of transferred TMTP, (ii) the dynamic portion of transferred TMTP based on the transferee’s designation, and (iii) the amount attributable to the non-dynamic portion, so the transferee can complete the required updates. These steps describe what must be done to effect the update of ‘Z A’, ‘Z B’ and ‘C 0’ in the transfer context [#SRC:23a78ae14011fcd7]. Separately, the timing overlay is that, within two months of the effective date of any transfer event, a firm must meet the applicable transfer-event requirements, so the firm should ensure the above update and designation/splitting actions are completed within that two-month window measured from the effective date [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9].

question: Where a model covers more than one UK firm, how must the model maintenance fee be set by reference to aggregated figures across those UK firms, and how does that interact with the definition of periodic fees payable by firms in a fee year as a summed amount (so far as applicable)?
gold_answer: Where a model incorporates more than one UK firm, the model maintenance fee must be determined by reference to aggregated figures for all UK firms within the scope of that model, rather than by looking at each firm in isolation [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. In practice, this aggregation approach links to how periodic fees payable by firms in any fee year are defined as a sum of applicable components: the firm that pays the largest periodic fee (as that summed amount, so far as applicable to it) will usually be the firm that pays the model maintenance fee for the multi-firm model [#TGT:be7e091f57b18a8f] [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. If the usual “largest periodic fee” approach is not applied, the PRA may instead direct that the fee is payable by such firms and in such proportions as it specifies, which still presupposes the periodic fee concept as an amount built up from applicable elements for each firm [#TGT:be7e091f57b18a8f] [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. For aggregation where the model includes one or more CRD credit institutions and one or more designated investment firms, the calculation is facilitated by rounding each relevant designated investment firm’s total assets for fees purposes to the nearest £1 million and deeming each £1 million of those assets equivalent to £0.4 million in modified eligible liabilities, then adding total modified eligible liabilities across all UK firms in scope [#SRC:062242588b894af5].

question: If a credit union is in the group the PRA expects to follow extra concentration limits, what does it mean when a corporate bond cap “overrides” a higher general limit, and how should the credit union apply the limits?
gold_answer: A credit union is within the PRA’s stated scope for these expectations if it has more than £10 million in total assets, or if it holds investments that fall within the specified investment categories referenced in the PRA Rulebook; for those credit unions, the PRA expects adherence to the listed concentration limits in addition to other required limits, while noting there is an exception for certain investments identified elsewhere [#SRC:6cdd849d0a0503ce]. The definition of “overrides” in this context is that the 5% cap on corporate bonds takes priority over, and therefore displaces, the 75% limit that would otherwise be applied under the broader limit [#TGT:04d63159fcbb266b]. So, when the credit union applies the concentration limits it is expected to follow, it must treat corporate bonds as subject to the stricter 5% cap even if a general limit might appear to allow up to 75%. In other words, for corporate bonds, the operative limit is 5%, and the higher percentage does not expand what is permitted for that asset type, for credit unions in scope of the PRA’s expectation [#SRC:6cdd849d0a0503ce] as clarified by the override meaning [#TGT:04d63159fcbb266b].

question: When demonstrating compliance with the countercyclical capital buffer requirement, what information must Institutions disclose, and how must that disclosure reflect a firm’s obligation to calculate the buffer as common equity tier 1 capital based on its total risk exposure amount and institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer rate?
gold_answer: Institutions are required to disclose information that relates to their compliance with the requirement for a countercyclical capital buffer, and that disclosure must be aligned with the underlying calculation obligation that applies to a firm. Specifically, the disclosure should be framed by the fact that a firm must calculate a countercyclical capital buffer, and that this buffer is defined as an amount of common equity tier 1 capital equal to the firm’s total risk exposure amount multiplied by its institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer rate [#TGT:fc114541fca3e60f]. In other words, the compliance-related information Institutions disclose should be capable of evidencing that the countercyclical capital buffer requirement is being met in a manner consistent with the required calculation mechanics, including the capital quality (common equity tier 1 capital) and the multiplication basis (total risk exposure amount and the institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer rate) [#TGT:fc114541fca3e60f]. The disclosure obligation is expressly tied to compliance with the countercyclical capital buffer requirement referred to in Chapter 3 of the Capital Buffers Part, so the information disclosed should be presented as compliance information in relation to that requirement [#SRC:00e7b892d108a9c9].

question: What do Institutions have to disclose about meeting the countercyclical capital buffer requirement, and how should that connect to the rule that a firm must calculate the buffer as common equity tier 1 capital using total risk exposure amount and its institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer rate?
gold_answer: Institutions must disclose information about how they comply with the countercyclical capital buffer requirement, and that disclosure should connect directly to the way the buffer is required to be calculated for a firm. The calculation obligation is that a firm must calculate a countercyclical capital buffer, and it must be an amount of common equity tier 1 capital equal to the firm’s total risk exposure amount multiplied by its institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer rate [#TGT:fc114541fca3e60f]. Because Institutions’ disclosure is “in relation to” compliance with the countercyclical capital buffer requirement referred to in Chapter 3 of the Capital Buffers Part, the disclosed information should be suitable to show compliance with that requirement in a way that is consistent with those calculation components (the capital type, the exposure base, and the institution-specific rate) [#SRC:00e7b892d108a9c9]. Put simply, the disclosure should be framed as compliance information and should be coherent with the required calculation approach for the countercyclical capital buffer of common equity tier 1 capital [#TGT:fc114541fca3e60f] as part of the Chapter 3 requirement [#SRC:00e7b892d108a9c9].

question: For a firm carrying on long-term insurance business, how must the minimum guarantee fund be determined when the usual table-based calculation tied to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in a preceding financial year cannot be applied because the firm lacks a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The definition operates in two linked steps that must be read together. Ordinarily, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is determined by selecting the amount shown in column 2 of the relevant table, matched to the firm’s highest annual contribution income for that business in any preceding financial year (with the income band identified in column 1) [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993]. However, that table-based approach depends on the existence of a preceding financial year from which the firm’s highest annual contribution income can be identified. Where the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, the definition provides a specific substitute amount: the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000 [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]. In practice, this means a newly established firm (or one without a completed preceding financial year) does not attempt to infer or approximate a “highest annual contribution income” for table selection; instead, it applies the fixed £90,000 minimum guarantee fund until it has a preceding financial year that enables the standard table correspondence to be used.

question: If a firm does not yet have a preceding financial year, what minimum guarantee fund amount applies for long-term insurance business, instead of using the table based on the firm’s highest annual contribution income?
gold_answer: Normally, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is worked out by using a table: you identify the firm’s highest annual contribution income for that business in any preceding financial year, find the matching income band in column 1, and then take the corresponding amount from column 2 [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993]. But that method only works if the firm has a preceding financial year to look back to. If the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, the definition provides a direct fallback amount rather than requiring any table lookup or income comparison. In that situation, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000 [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]. So, for a newer firm without a preceding financial year, you apply the fixed £90,000 figure; once the firm has a preceding financial year, the table-based approach tied to the highest annual contribution income becomes the relevant way to determine the amount.

question: For the purposes of applying the MREL buffer policy alongside the Threshold Conditions policy, how should the Threshold Conditions be defined, and in what scope does the PRA apply these policies where MREL is set by the Bank for interim and end-state requirements?
gold_answer: In this context, the Threshold Conditions should be understood as the PRA’s statutory minimum requirements that firms must meet to be permitted to carry on the regulated activities in which they engage, and which are intended to promote safety and soundness as a core element of the PRA’s regulatory regime [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff]. The scope point for applying that definition is that the PRA will apply both the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy specifically in respect of MREL set by the Bank, and this application covers both interim MREL requirements and end-state MREL requirements [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. Read together, this means the PRA’s use of the MREL buffer policy is not standalone: it is applied in tandem with the Threshold Conditions policy, and the relevant Threshold Conditions are those that function as the statutory gateway for firms to continue conducting their regulated activities, with the stated regulatory purpose of supporting safety and soundness [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff], across the full timeline of MREL calibration (interim through end-state) where the Bank is the MREL setter [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe].

question: When the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy to MREL set by the Bank (for both interim and end-state MREL), what do the Threshold Conditions mean and why do they matter?
gold_answer: Here, the Threshold Conditions mean the PRA’s statutory minimum requirements that firms must meet so they are permitted to carry on the regulated activities they undertake, and they are intended to promote safety and soundness as a crucial part of how the PRA’s regulatory regime operates [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff]. The scope for using that meaning is that the PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy together with the Threshold Conditions policy in respect of MREL that is set by the Bank, and it will do so for both interim MREL requirements and end-state MREL requirements [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. Putting these together, when MREL is set by the Bank, the PRA’s application of the MREL buffer policy is linked to its application of the Threshold Conditions policy, and the relevant Threshold Conditions are those minimum statutory requirements that determine whether a firm can continue to conduct its regulated activities, with the stated objective of supporting safety and soundness [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff], across both the interim and end-state stages of MREL requirements [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe].

question: If the PRA says a firm’s scenario analysis does not lock it into taking specific actions in a real stress, what can a firm include about which recovery options it may use, and what must it still explain about the order, fit to each stress, and expected benefits?
gold_answer: A firm can use scenario analysis to describe potential recovery actions without being locked into taking those actions in a real-life stress, because the PRA recognises stresses differ and the analysis does not commit the firm to any particular actions [#TGT:bffc8c656af6bbfe]. Even so, firms should explain which recovery options would be used in each scenario and show that those options are appropriate for restoring the firm to viability [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5]. The scenarios should map the recovery options and set out the order in which they would be used, so the reader can see how the firm expects the response to unfold under stress [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5]. The options should also be tailored to each type of stress, with justification for selecting each option and an explanation of the quantum of benefits that can be realised for each selected option under each stress [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5]. Finally, firms should consider dependencies between options, internal resource constraints, and external factors that might affect feasibility, while keeping clear that this remains analysis rather than a binding commitment [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5].

question: For new and growing banks that are initially loss making and dependent on regular capital injections, what must a credible capital plan achieve to ensure capital is raised in time to avoid breaching capital requirements plus buffers, and how does this expectation address the supervisory concern that banks may secure investment only at the last minute and thereby enter capital buffers in the ordinary course of business?
gold_answer: New and growing banks that are loss making initially and reliant on regular capital injections are expected to move toward profitability and organic capital generation within a reasonable period after authorisation, and—until profitability is achieved—to maintain a credible capital plan that ensures new capital is injected in good time so that capital requirements plus buffers are not entered [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b]. This expectation directly targets the supervisory concern that poor capital management is common among such banks, including leaving investment raising to the last minute, which can lead to entering capital buffers during normal business conditions and may force banks to seek additional capital under challenging circumstances [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431]. In practice, the plan should be forward-looking and timed so that capital is secured before pressures materialise, rather than reacting when buffers are already at risk. It should also support the bank’s stated path to profitability, recognising that prolonged unprofitability increases uncertainty about continued positive investor sentiment, and that delayed capital raising can distract management at critical moments. Together, these points frame credible planning as both a prudential safeguard and a governance discipline to avoid buffer entry driven by avoidable timing failures.

question: If a new and growing bank is loss making at first and needs regular capital injections, what does it need to do to make sure it gets new capital early enough to avoid going into capital buffers, and why is this important given that some banks wait until the last minute to secure investment?
gold_answer: A new and growing bank that is loss making initially and relies on regular capital injections is expected to work toward profitability and organic capital generation within a reasonable time after authorisation, and—until it becomes profitable—to have a credible capital plan that ensures new capital is injected in good time so it does not enter capital requirements plus buffers [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b]. This matters because poor capital management is described as a common issue for new and growing banks, including waiting until the last minute to secure the investment needed to keep operating without entering capital buffers [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431]. When investment is delayed, a bank can end up entering its capital buffers in the normal course of business, which is not aligned with PRA policy, or it may have to raise extra capital under difficult conditions. That kind of reactive fundraising can also become a major distraction for management. So the credible plan is not just about having access to capital in theory; it is about timing and certainty so capital is available before buffers are threatened.

question: For a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission, what must auditors take into account about the size of the matching adjustment the firm claims when forming the audit opinion on the SFCR, and how does the permission boundary affect that assessment?
gold_answer: Where the Chapter applies—i.e., for a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131]—auditors, in providing the audit opinion required in relation to the SFCR, are expected (to the extent material to their opinion) to consider the scale of the MA claimed by the firm [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03]. This expectation is linked to the fact that the MA’s impact on technical provisions falls within the relevant elements that are within the required scope of audit. In assessing the scale, auditors should recognise that the MA calculation depends in part on the application of MA calculation requirements, and that the apparent scale could be affected if the assets and liabilities used to calculate the MA were not within scope of an MA permission. Accordingly, for a firm within the Chapter’s scope, the auditor’s consideration of scale is not limited to arithmetic; it also includes whether the MA claimed could be influenced by using assets and liabilities that fall outside what the firm’s MA permission covers, because that could change the scale of MA presented and therefore be material to the SFCR audit opinion.

question: How must a firm apply the requirement to avoid undermining continuous and satisfactory service to policyholders when deciding whether it must not outsource a critical or important operational function or activity in a way that could trigger prohibited outcomes?
gold_answer: A firm must treat outsourcing decisions for any critical or important operational function or activity as constrained by two linked expectations: first, it must not structure or execute the outsourcing in a way that leads to the prohibited types of outcomes associated with such outsourcing arrangements [#TGT:29109d9e373a4183]; second, it must ensure that its approach to outsourcing does not undermine the continuous and satisfactory service to policyholders [#SRC:ddf6251d9d3bbb87]. Read together, this means the firm should only proceed with outsourcing where it can demonstrate that the arrangement will preserve continuity and satisfactory delivery of service to policyholders while also avoiding the kinds of adverse consequences that the prohibition is designed to prevent. In practice, the firm should assess the proposed outsourcing’s impact on ongoing service delivery and ensure the arrangement is designed so that it does not create conditions that would amount to outsourcing “in such a way as to lead” to the prohibited outcomes, while maintaining the required standard of continuous and satisfactory service to policyholders [#TGT:29109d9e373a4183] [#SRC:ddf6251d9d3bbb87].

question: When a firm is thinking about outsourcing an important function, what does it mean in practice that it must not outsource in a way that leads to prohibited outcomes, and it also must not undermine continuous and satisfactory service to policyholders?
gold_answer: When a firm considers outsourcing a critical or important operational function or activity, it has to apply a clear “must not” constraint: it must not outsource in a way that leads to the prohibited outcomes tied to that kind of outsourcing [#TGT:29109d9e373a4183]. At the same time, the firm must meet the separate but related requirement that its actions do not undermine the continuous and satisfactory service to policyholders [#SRC:ddf6251d9d3bbb87]. Putting these together, the firm should treat continuity and service quality for policyholders as a core test of whether the outsourcing is acceptable, and it should avoid any outsourcing structure or delivery model that could result in the kinds of negative consequences captured by the prohibition. The firm’s decision should therefore be based on whether the outsourcing can be set up and run so that policyholders continue to receive a continuous and satisfactory service, while ensuring the outsourcing is not carried out “in such a way as to lead” to the prohibited outcomes [#SRC:ddf6251d9d3bbb87] [#TGT:29109d9e373a4183].

question: If a firm uses an internal model to calculate its solo-level SCR, which supervisory statement should it also look at, and how does the definition describe that statement (name, topic, and date)?
gold_answer: If a firm calculates its solo-level SCR using an internal model, the SOURCE indicates that firms should also refer to a specific supervisory statement: PRA Supervisory Statement SS6/15 [#SRC:271703a0633133c4]. The TARGET then defines exactly what that TERM refers to, so the firm can identify the right document: “PRA Supervisory Statement SS6/15”, titled ‘Solvency II: the internal model treatment of participations’, published in November 2024 [#TGT:466b960f164be1d8]. Using both passages together matters because the SOURCE provides the condition that makes the reference relevant (the internal model being used for solo-level SCR) and the action expected (also refer to the supervisory statement), while the TARGET supplies the defining details that remove ambiguity about which SS6/15 is meant (its full title and publication date). The TARGET also includes the web address (www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2015/solvency2-the-internal-model-treatment-of-participations-ss), which supports locating the defined supervisory statement the SOURCE points firms to [#TGT:466b960f164be1d8].

question: For credit unions within the PRA’s expected scope for concentration limits based on asset size or holding certain investments, when may those limits be treated as inapplicable because the funds are only being held temporarily pending an investment decision, and how should that boundary be understood alongside the stated scope and exceptions?
gold_answer: Taken together, the two passages indicate that the PRA’s expectation to adhere to concentration limits applies to a defined set of credit unions—those with more than £10 million in total assets and any credit unions that hold investments falling under the specified Rules—subject to stated exceptions for certain investments. Within that overall scope, the PRA also indicates a specific circumstance in which the relevant limits are not intended to bite: where funds are held only temporarily in an account before an investment decision is made. In practice, this means a credit union that would otherwise be expected to follow the concentration limits because it meets the asset threshold or holds the relevant types of investments should treat the limits as not applying to the interim holding of cash-like balances that are merely parked pending a decision, rather than representing an investment position. This temporary-holding carve-out sits alongside (and does not replace) the broader scope statement and the separate exception for listed investments, so the credit union should distinguish between pre-decision temporary funds and actual investments to which the concentration limits are expected to apply. [#SRC:960de0d328d37ad1] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce]

question: If a credit union is expected by the PRA to follow concentration limits because it is over £10 million in assets or holds certain investments, do those limits still apply when money is only sitting in an account for a short time before an investment decision is made?
gold_answer: Reading the two statements together, the PRA sets an expectation that certain credit unions should adhere to concentration limits: specifically, credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets and any credit unions that hold investments that fall under the referenced Rules, with an additional note that there are exceptions for certain listed investments. At the same time, the PRA also explains that the limits are not intended to apply in a particular, narrow situation—where funds are held temporarily in an account before an investment decision is made. So, even if a credit union is within the group the PRA expects to follow the concentration limits, it can treat those limits as not applying to money that is merely parked on a short-term basis while the credit union has not yet decided how to invest it. The key boundary is the purpose and timing of the holding: the carve-out is tied to pre-decision, temporary holding, whereas the expectation to adhere to concentration limits is directed at credit unions meeting the asset-size or investment-holding conditions, subject to the separate investment exceptions. [#SRC:960de0d328d37ad1] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce]

question: When determining whether this Part applies at the level of the group, how must a firm treat an undertaking that is required to be left out of the group for the relevant purposes, and how does that exclusion affect whether the group falls within the types of groups to which this Part applies?
gold_answer: In assessing applicability, the analysis must be performed “at the level of the group” and only for those “types of groups” that fall within the stated scope trigger for this Part [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. At the same time, where the rules require that a particular undertaking is not to be treated as part of the group for the relevant purposes, that undertaking must be excluded from the group used for the scope assessment [#SRC:bed810e25ab93114]. Practically, this means the group perimeter you use to decide whether the Part applies is not necessarily the consolidated or economic group as a whole; it is the group as defined after applying the mandatory exclusion of the undertaking. The compliance consequence is that the inclusion or omission of that undertaking can change whether the remaining entities constitute a group that matches the “types of groups” to which the Part applies, and therefore can change whether the Part applies at all at group level. The required step is to apply the exclusion first, then evaluate applicability on the resulting group.

question: This Part applies at the group level only for certain types of groups. If an undertaking must be left out of the group for the relevant purposes, do you assess whether this Part applies using the group with or without that undertaking?
gold_answer: You assess whether this Part applies by looking at the group as it must be defined for the relevant purposes, which includes excluding any undertaking that the rules say must be excluded [#SRC:bed810e25ab93114]. The scope statement makes clear that the Part’s application is determined “at the level of the group” and only for the “types of groups” that meet the stated conditions [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. Putting these together, the group you use for the scope test is the group after you have removed the undertaking that must be excluded. That exclusion is not optional or a matter of judgment; it is a required adjustment to the group perimeter for the purposes in question. As a result, whether the Part applies can depend on the composition of the group once the undertaking is excluded, because the remaining entities may or may not fall within the types of groups covered by the Part. The key compliance step is to apply the mandatory exclusion first and then evaluate the Part’s applicability at group level on that adjusted basis.

question: Where the firm is required to calculate on the basis of specified accounts, what accounting records must a composite firm maintain for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, and how must those records support the firm’s calculation basis?
gold_answer: The firm’s calculation must be performed using the relevant accounts, and this requirement operates alongside (and does not override) the SCR Rules and the Minimum Capital Requirement Part [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678]. For a composite firm, the accounts that underpin that calculation basis must be structured as separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. Those separate accounts must be maintained in a way that shows the sources of the results for each activity separately, so that the firm can evidence that the figures used in its calculations are derived from the appropriate business line and are not blended across activities [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. In practice, this means the firm should ensure that the calculation basis referenced in the source obligation is traceable back to the distinct long-term and general insurance accounts, enabling clear attribution of results by activity while still applying the SCR Rules and Minimum Capital Requirement framework as applicable [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678] [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0].

question: If the firm must do its calculations using certain accounts, what separate accounts does a composite firm have to keep, and what do those accounts need to show so the calculations are properly based on them?
gold_answer: The firm is required to carry out its calculations using the relevant accounts, and this obligation applies without affecting the SCR Rules and the Minimum Capital Requirement Part [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678]. For a composite firm, that means it must keep separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. Those separate accounts must be maintained so they show the sources of the results for each activity separately, which supports using them as the basis for the firm’s calculations by making clear which results come from which business activity [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. Put together, the firm should ensure that when it calculates on the basis of the specified accounts, the underlying records are split between long-term and general insurance and are detailed enough to demonstrate the origin of the results used in the calculation, while still operating alongside the SCR Rules and Minimum Capital Requirement Part [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678] [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0].

question: When a firm is a UK subsidiary of an international group and parental support may be the most credible recovery option, what must the firm set out in its plan regarding UK-specific recovery options and the implementation timelines for those options, including any consistency expectations for O-SIIs with the group plan?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its plan goes beyond relying solely on parental support by identifying and documenting UK-specific recovery options available at the level of the UK subsidiary, reflecting that subsidiaries of international groups may have a more limited set of options but are still expected to consider additional actions that could be taken locally [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. Where the firm is an O-SII, the recovery options it sets out should be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, so that the UK subsidiary’s actions align with the wider group approach while still being articulated at the UK level [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. In addition to describing the options themselves, the firm should include the timelines over which each recovery option could be implemented, so the plan indicates how quickly the firm could execute the identified UK-specific measures (and any parental support option) in practice [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Taken together, the plan should present a coherent set of UK subsidiary recovery options and a clear view of when each could be deployed, enabling assessment of credibility and practicality in stressed conditions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8].

question: How must firms evidence that they have considered additional recovery options at the UK subsidiary level (beyond parental support) and what must they include to demonstrate the practical executability of those options over time?
gold_answer: Firms must evidence in their plan that, even where parental support may be the most credible recovery option for a UK subsidiary within an international group, they have still considered what additional recovery options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and have set out those recovery options in the plan [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. This requires the plan to articulate the UK-specific options the firm could take locally, acknowledging that the set of options may be more limited for a subsidiary but not treating that limitation as a reason to omit subsidiary-level actions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. To demonstrate that these options are not merely theoretical, firms should also include the timelines over which the recovery options could be implemented, so the plan shows the expected implementation horizon for each option and supports an assessment of feasibility and responsiveness [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Where applicable, and particularly for O-SIIs, the options described should be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still being presented with UK subsidiary specificity and associated implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8].

question: If a firm is a UK subsidiary in an international group and may mainly rely on parental support, what does its plan need to cover about UK-specific recovery options and how quickly those options could be put in place?
gold_answer: The firm’s plan needs to cover UK-specific recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary, even if the PRA recognises that a subsidiary may have fewer options and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. This means the firm should not stop at describing parental support; it should consider what additional options are available locally and set out those recovery options in the plan as UK subsidiary actions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. Alongside describing each recovery option, the firm should include the timelines over which the recovery options could be implemented, so the plan shows when each option could realistically be carried out [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. If the firm is an O-SII, the recovery options it includes should also be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still being clearly described for the UK subsidiary and paired with implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Together, these elements help show both what the firm could do in the UK and how quickly it could do it.

question: What should a firm write in its plan to show it has looked for extra recovery options in the UK subsidiary (not just group support), and what timing information should it add for those options?
gold_answer: To show it has looked for extra recovery options at the UK subsidiary level, the firm should set out UK-specific recovery options in its plan and explain them as actions available to the UK subsidiary, recognising that subsidiaries of international groups may have a more limited set of options and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. The key is that the firm is expected to consider what additional options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and include those options in the plan, rather than relying only on group-level measures [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. The firm should also add timing information by including the timelines over which recovery options could be implemented, so the plan indicates how long it would take to put each option into effect [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. If the firm is an O-SII, it should ensure the options it describes are consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still providing UK subsidiary detail and the related implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8].

question: Where a firm’s MA portfolio includes a wide range of assets beyond corporate bonds, including material exposure to less liquid assets, how must the firm ensure its FS modelling approach remains appropriate across asset types, given that the PRA’s expectations are intended to apply more widely unless stated otherwise?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s expectations as applying beyond corporate bond risks unless the SS explicitly limits them, because the PRA recognises that MA portfolios can contain a wide range of assets with differing liquidity and complexity, including non-traded assets, and expects firms to consider the SS more widely applicable in that context [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec]. Where the firm has material exposure to less liquid assets (for example illiquid, direct investments) within the MA portfolio, the firm is expected to develop a separate approach to model the FS for those assets, rather than assuming the core corporate bond approach is automatically suitable [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]. If the firm uses an approach similar to the corporate bond methodology, it should adapt the methodology and calibration to a degree that reflects how similar the less liquid assets are to corporate bonds, and in some cases a more bespoke methodology may be necessary [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]. If the firm does not distinguish between asset classes in modelling, it must clearly justify the model’s appropriateness for each asset class, consistent with the expectation of broader applicability across assets [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a].

question: If a firm holds many different assets in its MA portfolio, including less liquid ones, what does it need to do to make sure its FS model works for each asset type, given that the PRA’s expectations generally apply even when the assets are not corporate bonds?
gold_answer: Because the PRA recognises that many firms’ MA portfolios include a relatively wide range of assets that vary in liquidity and complexity (and may not be traded), firms should not treat the SS as relevant only to corporate bonds; instead, many expectations should be considered applicable regardless of the assets held unless the SS says otherwise [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec]. When the firm has material exposure to less liquid assets in the MA portfolio (such as illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects the firm to develop a separate approach to model the FS for those assets [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]. The firm may be able to use an approach similar to the corporate bond method, but it should adapt the core methodology and calibration based on how similar the assets are to corporate bonds, and it may need a more bespoke methodology in some cases [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a].
